		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Swiss Cheese Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Swiss Cheese Plants, also known as Monstera, are definitely one of our favourite plants. They bring the wow factor and are pretty easy to care for. Below you will find all the information to properly care for your Monstera.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Monstera plants thrive in bright, indirect light</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Monsteras won't do so well in direct sunlight as this will burn their leaves, so make sure they are getting plenty of indirect light. If you find that your Monstera doesn't have split leaves, this is most often caused by insufficient light. You can find out more about a lack of split leaves in your Monstera plant in our separate post <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-doesnt-my-monstera-have-splits-in-its-leaves/">here.</a></span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Let your Monstera's soil dry out</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">We would recommend watering your Monstera once a week, maybe slightly less in winter. Monsteras don't like sitting in water and prefer to dry out between waterings so maybe stick your finger in the soil before watering just to check they need it. Otherwise, it can quickly lead to <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">root rot</a>. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Swiss Cheese plants can grow pretty wild, and not always in the desired direction. They require a lot of space in your home but will reward you with incredible dark green split leaves. ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Swiss Cheese Plants</h2>
<p style="text-align: center;">Monsteras can be a little sensitive to their surroundings so it's good to know how to respond to any warning signs. The most common issues are brown leaves and drooping leaves.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">There are no splits in the leaves</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">If your plant is matured and there are no splits in the leaves this will be caused by too little light. Try moving your monstera to a sunnier spot and the new growth should have splits in. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The leaves are turning yellow/brown </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">This is most often a symptom of overwatering. Check whether the soil at the bottom of the pot is water-logged and replace accordingly. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The leaves are drooping </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">This can either be caused by over or underwatering. The easiest way to check is simply by taking the plant out of its pot and checking how damp the soil is. Adjust your watering schedule accordingly. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">My plant isn't standing up </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Monsteras can grow pretty wildly and not always in the desired direction. The easiest option is to stake your plant with a moss pole to encourage upwards growth. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Avoid repotting your Monstera too often</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">If you repot your Monstera too often, it may cause some instability in the plant. They don't mind being a little root-bound! If you feel it is time to repot, make sure it is in Spring so that it can adapt to its new home in the growing period. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Propagating your Monstera can be a little tricky </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">We have written a whole guide on how to propagate your Swiss Cheese Plant <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-propagate-a-monstera-plant/">here</a>. Some top tips are to always take a cutting that has an ariel root attached as</span><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot=""> this will increase the chances of success. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">You must dust your Monstera's leaves </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The luscious dark green leaves of your Monstera are very good at attracting and building up dust. But this can be quite unhealthy for your Monstera plant so make sure to dust the leaves or wipe them down with a damp cloth. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Monsteras love a humid environment </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Swiss Cheese plants are originally from the rainforest so they thrive in very humid conditions. But to keep them happy in your home, make sure to mist the leaves once a week. It's better to do it in the mornings so it can evaporate during the day). Check out our full guide to humidity <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">here</a>. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Monstera leaves can be toxic </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot=""> If your pet ingests part of a Monstera leaf or stem, it can be mildly toxic. It may cause stomach irritation and vomiting so make sure to keep your Monstera out of reach of children and your furry friends. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Try moving your Monstera to a sunnier spot and the new growth should have splits in. We have written a whole guide on getting splits in your Monstera leaves <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-doesnt-my-monstera-have-splits-in-its-leaves/">here</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown leaves on a Swiss Cheese Plant tend to be caused by a few main issues; over- or underwatering, dry air or leaf burn. Check out our guide on <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-are-my-monstera-leaves-turning-brown/">brown Monstera leaves</a> for more information on diagnoses and how to fix the problem.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Monstera plants thrive in bright, indirect light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Swiss Cheese Plants won't do so well in direct sunlight as this will burn their leaves, so make sure they are getting plenty of indirect light. If you find that your Monstera doesn't have split leaves, this is most often caused by insufficient light. You can find out more about a lack of split leaves in your Monstera plant in our separate post <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-doesnt-my-monstera-have-splits-in-its-leaves/">here.</a></span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Let your Monstera's soil dry out]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">We would recommend watering your Monstera once a week, maybe slightly less in winter. Monsteras don't like sitting in water and prefer to dry out between waterings so maybe stick your finger in the soil before watering just to check they need it. Otherwise, it can quickly lead to <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">root rot</a>. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Avoid repotting your Monstera too often]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">If you repot your Monstera too often, it may cause some instability in the plant. They don't mind being a little root-bound! If you feel it is time to repot your Monstera, make sure it is in Spring so that it can adapt to its new home in the growing period.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

The most important thing when propagating a Monstera is to always take a cutting that has an ariel root attached as</span><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot=""> this will increase the chances of success.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The luscious dark green leaves of your Monstera are very good at attracting and building up dust. But this can be quite unhealthy for your Monstera plant so make sure to dust the leaves or wipe them down with a damp cloth.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Monsteras love a humid environment]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Swiss Cheese plants are originally from the rainforest so they thrive in very humid conditions. But to keep them happy in your home, make sure to mist the leaves once a week. It's better to do it in the mornings so it can evaporate during the day). Check out our full <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">guide to humidity</a> to learn more.  </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">If your pet ingests part of a Monstera leaf or stem, it can be mildly toxic. It may cause stomach irritation and vomiting so make sure to keep your Monstera out of reach of children and pets.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Native to the rainforests of Central America, the Monstera Deliciosa has very quickly become the most fashionable and photographed houseplant ever. And it’s not difficult to understand why... If their large dark green glossy heart-shaped leaves weren’t enough, their unique splits surely will be! \n\nYou might be surprised to learn that the Monstera isn’t actually a fussy plant and is pretty easy to take care of. Bright but indirect light, moderate amounts of water and regularly misting are really the main things to remember. \n\nYou’ll find that a lot of more mature Monstera plants are sold with a moss pole as they are climbing plants. In the rainforest, the ariel roots that pop out from the stems will attach themselves to other plants as the plant matures. So a moss pole is a good substitution to help your plant grow and mature. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Native to the rainforests of Central America, the Monstera Deliciosa has very quickly become the most fashionable and photographed houseplant ever. And it’s not difficult to understand why... If their large dark green glossy heart-shaped leaves weren’t enough, their unique splits surely will be!

You might be surprised to learn that the Monstera isn’t actually a fussy plant and is pretty easy to take care of. Bright but indirect light, moderate amounts of water and regularly misting are really the main things to remember.

You’ll find that a lot of more mature Monstera plants are sold with a moss pole as they are climbing plants. In the rainforest, the ariel roots that pop out from the stems will attach themselves to other plants as the plant matures. So a moss pole is a good substitution to help your plant grow and mature.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Chinese Money Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Chinese Money Plants, also known as Pilea, are famous for their unique dark green round leaves. Below you will find our complete Chinese Money Plant care guide so you can help your Pilea thrive!</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_pull_quote]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The Chinese Money Plant gets its name from its beautiful round leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_pull_quote]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fc584bd3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Common Issues For Pilea</h2>
Pilea plants are incredible plants that can be easy to care for. However, they can be quite sensitive to any changes in their environment so make sure to keep an eye out for any signs of distress. The most common issues tend to be your Pilea's leaves curling inwards, leaves dropping or turning yellow.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[8]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[118]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pileas will thrive in bright, indirect light. </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Pileas are definitely light lovers and will struggle in low-light. Do not place your pilea in direct sun as this will burn the leaves. You may begin to notice that your pilea is reaching for the light and is growing lopsided. If this is the case, make sure to rotate your pilea every few days to make sure it grows straight. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4 style="text-align: center;"><strong>My Pilea's leaves are curved</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This is often a sign of insufficient light as the leaves are trying to maximise the surface area that is exposed to the light. </span></p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Yellow leaves at the base of the plant</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This is often simply due to natural shedding. However, if you feel it's losing leaves quickly you may want to fertilise your plant and move it to a sunnier spot.</span></p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">P</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">ileas are very sensitive to overwatering</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">They hate sitting in water so make sure the soil has time to dry between waterings. Pileas are great at letting you know when they need a water as their leaves will begin to droop a little. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">They are relatively easy plants to propagate</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Little babies, known as Pilea Pups, pop up from the main root system and all you need to do it carefully cut off the pup and place it in one water or straight into the soil. Once the pup is divided from the mother plant it is best to place it in bright indirect light. We have a whole guide on propagating your Pilea <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-propagate-a-pilea-peperomioides/">here</a>.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pilea are generally non-toxic for humans and pets. </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Pilea are a pretty safe plant to have around. However, if ingested in very large quantities, they can cause a mild digestive reaction so just be a little careful if you have pets or small children around who like to taste anything and everything!</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Repotting your Pilea can really encourage growth </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Repotting also gives your Chinese Money Plant room to encourage the growth of pups. By adding some rocks to the bottom of the Pilea's pot this can help with drainage, preventing the delicate root system from developing root rot. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">It is best to use a high quality well-draining potting mix. </span></h3>
Chinese Money Plants don't like sitting in water, as this will very quickly cause the root system to rot, essentially killing your Pilea. So make sure that you use soil that is well draining. You can find out more about dealing with root rot in your Pilea in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">guide.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>It is important to clean your Pilea's leaves</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Use a damp cloth to lightly wipe any dust that has formed on the leaves. A build up of dust will mean that the plant is not receiving as much light as usual, which will mean it'll struggle even in bright areas. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Yellow leaves on all of the plant </span></h4>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">This could be due to either too much light or overwatering. Make sure that you allow your pilea to dry out between waterings. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Leaves are staying very small </span></h4>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">This could be down too over-fertilisation which is encouraging too much new growth all at once. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">White spots on the leaves </span></h4>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">This happens a lot when you are watering with tap water in a hard-water area. It is nothing to worry about. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Leaves are curling inwards</span></h4>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">This could be due to your plant being too warm so make sure it is not too close to a radiator or other heat source. </span>

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are my Pilea's leaves curved?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Curved and cupping leaves on a Pilea are often a sign of insufficient light as the leaves are trying to maximise the surface area that is exposed to the light. Using a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter</a> can help you figure out the best spot to move your Pilea to, as going the other way and giving your Pilea too much light can also cause a new range of issues.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you find that your Pilea's leaves are looking quite sad and drooping down, it may be due to issues with watering. Alternatively a lack of sunlight or other stressful indicators such as repotting may have caused your Pilea's leaves to droop.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Curated information on how to best care for your %%title%%. Learn all about Pilea basic care, propagation, repotting, and any common issues, such as curling leaves, that you might run into.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pileas will thrive in bright, indirect light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Pileas are definitely light lovers and will struggle in low-light. But it is also important that you do not place your Pilea in direct sun as this will burn the leaves. You may begin to notice that your Pilea is reaching for the light and is growing lopsided. If this is the case, make sure to rotate your Pilea plant every few days to make sure it grows straight. </span>

If you aren't sure how much light your Pilea is getting (and if this is right), we recommend using a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pileas are very sensitive to overwatering]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">They hate sitting in water so make sure the soil has time to dry between waterings. Pileas are great at letting you know when they need a water as their leaves will begin to droop a little.  </span>

To help us avoid overwatering, we always use a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to check the moisture levels in the soil before watering our Pilea. We recommend <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">this one available from Amazon.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They are relatively easy plants to propagate]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Little babies, known as Pilea Pups, pop up from the main root system and all you need to do is carefully cut off the pup (as close to the main root system as possible) and place it in one water or straight into the soil. Once the Pilea pup is divided from the mother plant it is best to place it in bright indirect light. We have a whole guide on <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-propagate-a-pilea-peperomioides/">propagating your Pilea</a> if you want to find out more.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pilea are generally non-toxic for humans and pets.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Pilea are a pretty safe plant to have around and are non-toxic to dogs and cats. However, if ingested in very large quantities, they can cause a mild digestive reaction so just be a little careful if you have pets or small children around who like to taste anything and everything!</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Repotting your Pilea can really encourage growth]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Repotting also gives your Chinese Money Plant room to encourage the growth of pups. By adding some rocks to the bottom of the Pilea's pot this can help with drainage, preventing the delicate root system from developing root rot. We also recommend using <a href="/a/terracotta-pots">terracotta pots</a> instead of plastic ones as they allow some of the moisture to evaporate out of the sides which helps avoid waterlogged soil. We love <a href="/a/terracotta-pots">these terracotta posts from Amazon.</a></span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is best to use a high quality well-draining potting mix. ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Chinese Money Plants don't like sitting in water, as this will very quickly cause the root system to rot, essentially killing your Pilea. So make sure that you use a high-quality potting mix <a href="/a/houseplant-soil">like this one from Miracle Gro.</a>It will make sure that your plant gets all of the needed nutrients.

You might also want to add some <a href="/a/perlite">perlite</a> into the potting mix to help with drainage and aeration.

You can find out more about dealing with root rot in your Pilea in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">root rot guide.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is important to clean your Pilea's leaves]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Use a damp cloth to lightly wipe any dust that has formed on the leaves. A build up of dust will mean that the plant is not receiving as much light as usual, which will mean it'll struggle even in bright areas. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yoast_wpseo_primary_plant-cats]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Room temperature is fine for your Pilea]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Average room temperature is the ideal condition for your Pilea. They don't tend to do well in extreme temperatures so try to avoid placing it in a really hot room, and make sure it is away from drafty doors and windows as the cool air from outside can affect your Pilea's health. Using a <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometer</a> can help you to avoid extreme temperatures damaging your plant's health.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pileas don't like dry air ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Another important thing to take into consideration when taking care of a Pilea plant is humidity. They don't like rooms with really dry air and might start showing signs such as crispy leaf edges. We recommend misting your Pilea using a <a href="/a/spray-bottles">spray bottle,</a> using a <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier</a> or making a pebble tray. You can find out more in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">humidity guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Otherwise known as the Chinese Money Plant (they are believed to bring good luck and fortune to its owner), Pilea plants are a must-have! They initially became popular because they are so easy to propagate which meant Pilea pups got passed around a lot between friends and family, earning itself the nickname ‘pass it on plant’ \n\nWhen it comes to care, Pilea’s are somewhere in-between fussy and low maintenance. They aren’t great in low light areas, and also hate soggy or super dry soil so finding the right balance is key for Pilea care. \n\nAs your Pilea matures, the leaves can reach up to about 15cm in diameter which is incredible and makes all of the effort worth it! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Otherwise known as the Chinese Money Plant (they are believed to bring good luck and fortune to its owner), Pilea plants are a must-have! They initially became popular because they are so easy to propagate which meant Pilea pups got passed around a lot between friends and family, earning itself the nickname ‘pass it on plant’

When it comes to care, Pilea’s are somewhere in-between fussy and low maintenance. They aren’t great in low light areas, and also hate soggy or super dry soil so finding the right balance is key for Pilea care.

As your Pilea matures, the leaves can reach up to about 10cm in diameter which is incredible and makes all of the effort worth it!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Fiddle Leaf Fig Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">With their densely-packed glossy leaves, Fiddle Leaf Figs one of our must-haves for any home and they are quite easy to care for too. Below you will find all the information you need to care for your Fiddle Leaf Fig.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_intro_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Make sure to dust your Fiddle Leaf Fig Tree as they are very prone to a build up of dust.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_pull_quote]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fc584bd3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Common Issues for Fiddle Leaf Fig Trees</h2>
Fiddle Leaf Figs are known for their large luscious dark green leaves. but sometimes they will show signs of distress or illness so it is important that you know how to spot the signs. The most common issue tends to be brown or drooping leaves on your Fiddle Leaf Fig Tree.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your Fiddle Leaf Fig will thrive in bright, filtered light. </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Their favourite spot will be near a sunny window. If possible, try to rotate your Fiddle Leaf Fig every few months so that it doesn’t lean too much towards the light. You might need to move your Fiddle Leaf Fig a little closer to the window in the darker, winter months to help it get the light it needs. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Fiddle Leaf Figs hate sitting in water.</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Overwatering will cause your Fiddle Leaf Fig's roots to rot so make sure not to overwater them. It is best to wait until the top 2 inches of the soil is dry before watering. Check out our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">guide on preventing and fixing root rot</a> if you think you may have overwatered your Fiddle Leaf Fig. When watering, it is best to use room temperature water. We recommend giving your Fiddle Leaf Fig a little more water as it turns to spring to encourage new growth. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Fiddle Leaf Figs prefer warm, humid environments.</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;"> As Fiddles are native to the rainforest, make sure to grow your plant in a regular indoor temperature of 18-24°C. Low temperatures may cause it to develop brown leaves. Fiddle Leaf Figs tend to be sensitive to drafts so make sure to keep them away from open windows or doors. You can easily raise the humidity for your Fiddle Leaf Fig by following our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>You can only propagate Fiddle Leaf Figs from a stem cutting.</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Unfortunately, you can’t propagate Fiddles from a leaf cutting, all roots formed from a leaf cutting are cosmetic and won’t actually grow into a new tree. To propagate your Fiddle Leaf Fig, cut off about 10-15cm from the stem (make sure they are healthy leaves) and place in water. After 4-5 weeks, your cutting should be developing roots and once the roots are a few inches long, the cutting is ready to be potted. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Over-fertilisation can kill your Fiddle Leaf Fig.</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The best way to fertilise your Fiddle Leaf Fig Tree is to replace the top of the soil with a fresh nutrient-rich layer once a year. Then add a water-soluble fertiliser. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fiddle Leaf Figs require a nutrient rich soil.</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure to add some plant food every once in a while to help the luscious green leaves thrive. Make sure you don't overdo it though as this can cause your Fiddle to grow too much at once, meaning underdeveloped leaves will form. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Pruning your Fiddle Leaf Fig can help healthy growth.</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Cutting a few leaves off your Fiddle Leaf Fig tree will encourage healthy growth. Make sure you cut off damaged leaves and branches that are overcrowded as these plants need some space to grow healthily. Make the cuts an inch or two away from the trunk so that you don’t damage the trunk. Pruning your Fiddle Leaf Fig tree properly will keep it strong and healthy. We have a whole guide on how to correctly prune your Fiddle Leaf Fig <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prune-your-fiddle-leaf-fig-tree/">here</a>. </span>
<h3></h3>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>If the roots are showing, it is time to repot.</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Every now and again take a look to see if any roots are showing out of the bottom of the pot. If so, it is time to repot your Fiddle Leaf Fig Tree. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you want to keep your Fiddle at its current size, you can trim off some of the root ball but make sure you DO NOT trim more than 15-20% of its roots as this will cause too much damage to the root system. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fiddle Leaf Fig Trees can be harmful to pets.</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s important to know that Fiddle Leaf Figs can cause stomach irritation if your pets ingest it so just be a little careful if you have furry friends that like to chew on your plants as they can be a little toxic. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

Fiddle Leaf Fig trees can sometimes develop pests such as mealy bugs, spider mites and whiteflies. If you find your Fiddle has pest on the leaves, wipe it down with a damp cloth or <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-give-your-houseplants-a-shower/">give your Fiddle Leaf Fig a shower</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Your Fiddle Leaf Fig will thrive in bright, filtered light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Their favourite spot will be near a sunny window. If possible, try to rotate your Fiddle Leaf Fig every few months so that it doesn’t lean too much towards the light. You might need to move your Fiddle Leaf Fig a little closer to the window in the darker, winter months to help it get the light it needs. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Fiddle Leaf Figs hate sitting in water]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Overwatering will cause your Fiddle Leaf Fig's roots to rot so make sure to keep an eye on this. It is best to wait until the top 2 inches of the soil is dry before watering. Check out our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">guide on preventing and fixing root rot</a> if you think you may have overwatered your Fiddle Leaf Fig. When watering, it is best to use room temperature water. We also recommend giving your Fiddle Leaf Fig a little more water in spring to encourage new growth. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Fiddle Leaf Figs prefer warm, humid environments]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">As Fiddles are native to the rainforest, make sure to grow your plant in a regular indoor temperature of 18-24°C. Low temperatures may cause it to develop brown leaves. Fiddle Leaf Figs tend to be sensitive to drafts so make sure to keep them away from open windows or doors. You can easily raise the humidity for your Fiddle Leaf Fig by following our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[You can only propagate Fiddle Leaf Figs from a stem cutting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Unfortunately, you can’t propagate Fiddles from a leaf cutting, all roots formed from a leaf cutting are cosmetic and won’t actually grow into a new tree. To propagate your Fiddle Leaf Fig, cut off about 10-15cm from the stem (make sure they are healthy leaves) and place in water. After 4-5 weeks, your cutting should be developing roots and once the roots are a few inches long, the cutting is ready to be potted. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Over-fertilisation can kill your Fiddle Leaf Fig]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">The best way to fertilise your Fiddle Leaf Fig Tree is to replace the top of the soil with a fresh nutrient-rich layer once a year. Then add a water-soluble fertiliser. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Fiddle Leaf Figs require a nutrient rich soil]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure to add some plant food every once in a while to help the luscious green leaves thrive. Make sure you don't overdo it though as this can cause your Fiddle to grow too much at once, meaning underdeveloped leaves will form. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pruning your Fiddle Leaf Fig can help healthy growth]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Cutting a few leaves off your Fiddle Leaf Fig tree will encourage healthy growth. Make sure you cut off damaged leaves and branches that are overcrowded as these plants need some space to grow healthily. Make the cuts an inch or two away from the trunk so that you don’t damage the trunk. Pruning your Fiddle Leaf Fig tree properly will keep it strong and healthy. We have a whole guide on how to correctly prune your Fiddle Leaf Fig <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prune-your-fiddle-leaf-fig-tree/">here</a>. </span>
<h3></h3>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If the roots are showing, it is time to repot]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Every now and again take a look to see if any roots are showing out of the bottom of the pot. If so, it is time to repot your Fiddle Leaf Fig Tree. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you want to keep your Fiddle at its current size, you can trim off some of the root ball but make sure you DO NOT trim more than 15-20% of its roots as this will cause too much damage to the root system. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s important to know that Fiddle Leaf Figs can cause stomach irritation if your pets ingest it so just be a little careful if you have furry friends that like to chew on your plants as they can be a little toxic. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

If you find your Fiddle has pest on the leaves, wipe it down with a damp cloth or <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-give-your-houseplants-a-shower/">give your Fiddle Leaf Fig a shower</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;\nNative to the rainforests of central Africa, Fiddle Leaf Fig Trees are really stealing all of the attention right now. Their giant dark green glossy veined leaves give you that instant tropical feeling, right in your own home. They actually get their name from their violin-shaped leaves, similar to a Fiddle. \n\nFiddle Leaf Fig Trees like a nice warm, humid environment with plenty of sunshine and a good amount of water to support a strong root system. \n\nIf you’re looking for your plant to become the focal point of the room, then the Fiddle is the plant for you as they can grow up to 3 metres tall in the right environment. It’s important to note though that Fiddle Leaf Figs are toxic to pets and humans so not the best chance if there is a risk of leaves being ingested…\n\nYou should be able to find a Fiddle Leaf at most independent plant shops globally, but they can have quite a big price tag if you’re looking for a more mature one. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Native to the rainforests of central Africa, Fiddle Leaf Fig Trees are really stealing all of the attention right now. Their giant dark green glossy veined leaves give you that instant tropical feeling, right in your own home. They actually get their name from their violin-shaped leaves, similar to a Fiddle. Fiddle Leaf Fig Trees like a nice warm, humid environment with plenty of sunshine and a good amount of water to support a strong root system.

If you’re looking for your plant to become the focal point of the room, then the Fiddle is the plant for you as they can grow up to 3 metres tall in the right environment. It’s important to note though that Fiddle Leaf Figs are toxic to pets and humans so not the best chance if there is a risk of leaves being ingested…

You should be able to find a Fiddle Leaf at most independent plant shops globally, but they can have quite a big price tag if you’re looking for a more mature one.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Although Aloe Vera plants are seemingly very low maintenance, they can sometimes be a little fussy about their environment and care so it's important to look out for the warning signs. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Aloe Vera love bright, indirect sunlight</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Make sure your home has enough natural light to keep these ones happy. Whilst they can sustain some direct light, after a while too much sunlight will dry our your Aloe Vera's leaves. It is all about finding the right spot your for Aloe and it'll thrive!</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Be careful not to overwater your Aloe Vera</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Aloe Veras are quite sensitive plants when it comes to watering. The less the better really. They really dislike sitting in water so make sure they dry out fully between waterings. If you think you may have overwatered your Alow Vera, replace the soil immediately and adjust your watering schedule. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Use a well-draining potting mix</h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">A good potting mix for your Aloe Vera should contain perlite, lava rock or coarse sand to help water drainage. This will protect the roots from rotting which is the most common issue with Aloe Veras as it can happen quite quickly if you accidentally overwater them a few times. </span>

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Aloe Vera can be toxic if ingested </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Although the gel can be used on skin to reduce pain, you should never ingest any part of an Aloe Vera as it can cause nausea and can even be toxic in large quantities. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">It's easy to propagate your Aloe Vera</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Aloe Vera grow little pups from the main root system that pop up next to the mother plant. Simply cut the pup off with a couple of cm stem and repot them in succulent soil.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They don't need to be fertilised</h3>
Fertilising your Aloe Vera won't harm it but it isn't really necessary. They should be fertilised no more than once a year and we recommend using a water-soluble fertiliser if you do choose that you want to.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Warmer temperatures are best for your Aloe Vera</h3>
Although they aren't as fussy as some other houseplants, warmer temperatures do encourage more growth in your Aloe Vera. Make sure they aren't placed near an air vent or drafty window as the cooler temperatures will affect your Aloe Vera's health.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Aloe Vera grow little pups from the main root system that pop up next to the mother plant. Simply cut the pup off with a couple of cm stem and repot them in succulent soil.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Although Aloe Vera plants are commonly loved for their gel, they are much more than just their health and beauty benefits, as they make for a super minimalist and forgiving houseplant! Like most other succulents, Aloe Vera plants don’t need much tending to as they thrive in dry coarse potting mix. But it is important that they get a good amount of bright light or will become quite straggly. \n\nAs they mature a little, you’ll see lots of little Aloe pups popping up which can be very easily removed from the mother plant and propagated! Aloe plants are super affordable and you can pick them up basically anywhere that sells plants, even supermarkets will often sell them in the summer months. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Although Aloe Vera plants are commonly loved for their gel, they are much more than just their health and beauty benefits, as they make for a super minimalist and forgiving houseplant! Like most other succulents, Aloe Vera plants don’t need much tending to as they thrive in dry coarse potting mix. But it is important that they get a good amount of bright light or will become quite straggly.

As they mature a little, you’ll see lots of little Aloe pups popping up which can be very easily removed from the mother plant and propagated! Aloe plants are super affordable and you can pick them up basically anywhere that sells plants, even supermarkets will often sell them in the summer months.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_intro_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Spider Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Spider Plants are one of the easiest plants to care for, t<span style="font-weight: 400;">hey happily grow in most conditions and reward you with spider babies (spiderettes) that are easy to propagate. Below you'll find all the information needed to properly care for a Spider Plant.</span></p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_intro_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_light_rating]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_light_rating]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bright indirect light is perfect for Spider Plants.</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Spider Plants thrive in bright spots but will also adapt to lower light areas, but growth might not be as quick. Make sure you don’t leave your Spider Plant in direct light or this will burn the leaves. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Water moderately but don’t let them become too waterlogged. </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Overwatering can very quickly lead to root rot. Spider plants are pretty hardy so overwatering every now and again won't kill your plant but just be aware of how much you are giving them. Also, make sure </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">to stagger watering your Spider Plant as they prefer to dry out in between waterings. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Spider plants prefer cooler temperatures </span></h3>
Although <span style="font-weight: 400;">Spider Plant's won't always like to be sat in a really hot home,</span> they are quite easy-going so will survive in most climates year-round. Just try to avoid putting them near draughty doors or windows.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Common Issues for Spider Plants</h2>
Whilst <span style="font-weight: 400;">Spider Plant</span> are relatively easy to take care of and adapt to most environments, they are prone to some issues. However, if you notice these early and take the right steps, your <span style="font-weight: 400;">Spider Plant</span> will more than likely return to a healthy and thriving state.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>S<span style="font-weight: 400;">pider plants are very easy to propagate!</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;"> Once your Spider Plant matures, they will grow offshoots that will grow into spiderettes that you can separate from the mother plant. Propagation of Spider Plants can also be done via division of the mother plant. Check out our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-propagate-spider-plants/">guide to Spider Plant Propagation</a> which includes all the details you need. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4>Leaf tips burning</h4>
This is often caused by over or underwatering. Spider plants hate sitting in lots of water but need enough to not dry out for long periods of time.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Spider Plants thrive in bright spots but will also adapt to lower light areas. If you are growing a Spider Plant in low light, be aware that growth will be slower and it may not grow spider babies as quickly.  Another thing to take into consideration when finding the best spot for your Spider Plant is making sure it does not receibe any direct light as</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> this will burn the leaves.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Overwatering can very quickly lead to root rot. Spider Plants are pretty hardy so overwatering every now and again won't kill your plant but just be aware of how much you are giving them. Also, make sure </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">to stagger watering your Spider Plant as they prefer to dry out in between waterings. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Spider Plants are the perfect plant for a houseplant beginner as they are super easy to care for, grow pretty quickly, and produce an abundance of spider babies which can be propagated in seconds. \n\nThe best thing about Spider Plants is that you would really have to try to kill them as they adapt to and survive in most environments and don’t mind being a little neglected. They even show you when they need more water by going quite light green. But after a little bit of water, they spring back to full health in minutes. \n\nAs your plant matures, you’ll start to see it sprouting little spiderettes which you can choose to remove from the plant to create new Spider Plants. They really are the gift that keeps on giving. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Spider Plants are the perfect plant for a houseplant beginner as they are super easy to care for, grow pretty quickly, and produce an abundance of spider babies which can be propagated in seconds.

The best thing about Spider Plants is that you would really have to try to kill them as they adapt to and survive in most environments and don’t mind being a little neglected. They even show you when they need more water by going quite light green. But after a little bit of water, they spring back to full health in minutes.

As your plant matures, you’ll start to see it sprouting little spiderettes which you can choose to remove from the plant to create new Spider Plants. They really are the gift that keeps on giving.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Common Issues for Snake Plants</h2>
Snake plants are very resilient and low maintenance. They adapt to most environments and will reward you for pretty much leaving them alone.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake Plants prefer bright, indirect light</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">They will also tolerate more direct sunlight or shadier corners. Imperfect light conditions will mean your Snake Plant will grow slower than in brighter environments but it will not kill it. </span>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake Plants need very infrequent watering </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Although they may not look like it, snake plants are actually a succulent so it can be very easy to accidentally over-water them. They like to dry out in between waterings and during winter, they only need to be watered around once a month. </span>

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake Plants prefer warmer environments</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Being native to warmer countries, Snake Plants thrive in warmer conditions. In colder months, make sure your snake plant is not near drafty windows or doors. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
