							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Use a well draining soil</h3>
<p class="p1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake Plants</span> need dry conditions so make sure that you use well-draining soil.<span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake plants are one of the best plants at air purification. They filter out toxins at night which makes them great for the bedroom too.</span></p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Snake Plants can be propagated by division or leaf cutting</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Try to divide and repot in the spring so that it can adjust to its new environment during the warmer months. To propagate by division, cut a section of both leaves and roots and transfer into a separate pot. To propagate by leaf cutting, slice 5-7cm of a leaf and place it either in water or a well-draining potting mix. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Snake plants are mildly toxic.</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake Plants</span> can be harmful to cats and dogs if ingested and cause diarrhoea or vomiting. They have also quite tough and sharp leaves so make sure to keep out of reach of pets and young children.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_icon_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e31c7d22c60a]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4>Brown spots on the leaf</h4>
This may be a little difficult to diagnose the exact problem. It can be caused by too much or too little water or can also be due to fungus or bacteria on the leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4>The leaves are losing their bright green colour.</h4>
This may be a sign of overwatering. It can be the most common issue with snake plants as even slight overwatering can cause root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h4>The plant is quite unstable</h4>
Make sure you are always watering from the bottom as this will encourage the roots to grow down, keeping the plant stable and upright.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown spots on a Snake Plant can be caused by too much or too little water or can also be due to fungus or bacteria on the leaves. It can sometimes be difficult to diagnose the problem right away but start by inspecting the moisture in the soil to rule out any watering issues.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Snake Plants need very infrequent watering]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Although they may not look like it, snake plants are actually a succulent so it can be very easy to accidentally over-water them. They like to dry out in between waterings and during winter, they only need to be watered around once a month. </span>

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

They filter out toxins at night which makes them great for the bedroom too.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Snake Plants can be propagated by division or leaf cutting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Try to divide and repot in the spring so that it can adjust to its new environment during the warmer months. To propagate a Snake Plant by division, cut a section of both leaves and roots and transfer into a separate pot. To propagate your Snake Plant by leaf cutting, slice 5-7cm of a leaf and place it either in water or a well-draining potting mix. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Snake Plants</span> can be harmful to cats and dogs if ingested and cause diarrhoea or vomiting. They also have quite tough and sharp leaves so make sure to keep out of reach of pets and young children.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;The bold and striking leaves of the Snake Plant make it stand out wherever you put it! Not only are they slow-growing, but they transcend upwards so are great for small spaces or that corner you never know what to do with.  They have some of the sturdiest leaves or any houseplant, and their sharp leaf tips have given the plant the nickname of mother-in-laws-tongue! \n\nWhen it comes to care, Snake Plant are super easy to look after, they can adapt to a range of light levels (are great low light plants), prefer dry soil and don’t need much attention in the way of misting or repotting etc. So if you want a low maintenance, sturdy houseplant, then the Snake Plant is your perfect match! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">The bold and striking leaves of the Snake Plant make it stand out wherever you put it! Not only are they slow-growing, but they transcend upwards so are great for small spaces or that corner you never know what to do with. They have some of the sturdiest leaves or any houseplant, and their sharp leaf tips have given the plant the nickname of mother-in-laws-tongue!

When it comes to care, Snake Plant are super easy to look after, they can adapt to a range of light levels (are great low light plants), prefer dry soil and don’t need much attention in the way of misting or repotting etc. So if you want a low maintenance, sturdy houseplant, then the Snake Plant is your perfect match!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Caring for a Boston Fern isn’t tricky, but it is important you know their specific requirements. Their luscious green leaves are worth the effort. Below you will find all the information you need to look after your Boston Fern.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Boston Ferns like bright, indirect light. </span></h3>
Boston Ferns can deal with very bright spots but be careful not to expose your fern to too much direct sunlight as their leaves are quite delicate.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Boston Ferns thrive in damp soil. </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Dry soil is one of the main reasons why Boston ferns do not survive. It is very important to give your boston fern a little more humidity in the cold months as if you have the heating on, they can get very dry very quickly. To increase the humidity try misting your fern every few days. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Boston Ferns prefer cooler temperatures</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Boston ferns prefer a slightly cooler environment and will struggle with temperatures above 24C. Try to keep fresh air flowing through the room to prevent heat from building up. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Hold off the fertiliser</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Boston ferns don’t really need to be fertilised often. A few times a year or so will do as overfertilisation can harm your plant. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Boston Ferns love humidity so it's important that you mist their leaves every so often. This also removes any dust from the plant.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Boston Ferns love moisture</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">You can increase the humidity around your boston fern  by 70% by placing it on top of a tray of pebbles and water. Make sure to keep the water level below the plant so your fern isn't sitting in stagnant water. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;If you want to bring some jungle indoors, then the lush Boston Fern is the go-to! However, looking after them isn’t always easy as they can be a little fussy when grown indoors. There are two main things that your Boston Fern needs; bright sunshine and high humidity. This means you need to be prepared to mist your Fern daily to avoid crispy leaves. \n\nThe one downside we find to owning Boston Ferns is that they do shed a lot of leaves so you’ll find yourself tidying up after it quite a lot. But with the right care, they’ll reward you with luscious green wilderness. \n\nAnother great thing about Boston Ferns is they are pretty cheap and you shouldn’t run into too much trouble finding them in plant shops around the world.\n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">If you want to bring some jungle indoors, then the lush Boston Fern is the go-to! However, looking after them isn’t always easy as they can be a little fussy when grown indoors. There are two main things that your Boston Fern needs; bright sunshine and high humidity. This means you need to be prepared to mist your Fern daily to avoid crispy leaves.

The one downside we find to owning Boston Ferns is that they do shed a lot of leaves so you’ll find yourself tidying up after it quite a lot. But with the right care, they’ll reward you with luscious green wilderness.

Another great thing about Boston Ferns is they are pretty cheap and you shouldn’t run into too much trouble finding them in plant shops around the world.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">A strong contender for the easiest plant to care for, Rubber Plants are perfect for all plant parents. Here you'll find all of our top tips on how to care for a Rubber Plant, as well as how to diagnose problems to help your plant to thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Rubber Plants</h2>
Although Rubber Plants are pretty hardy, they will suffer under certain conditions so it's important to know if there is anything wrong with your plant. The most common issues that you might find with your Rubber Plant is that the leaves begin to turn yellow or crispy and may even fall off.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_soil_rating]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_soil_rating]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5f8684bd0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Rubber Plants love bright, indirect light </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Although they can adjust to lower light levels, Rubber Plants prefer indirect sunlight. Make sure to keep them away from the direct sun however, as this can be really damaging for their leaves as it can very quickly cause leaf burn. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Water thoroughly, but infrequently </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Rubber plants need to be watered more in the warmer months to help with new growth. You should make sure the soil is moist, but never waterlogged to avoid any root rot. If you think you may have overwatered your Rubber Plant, check out our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">root rot guide</a> to see how to fix and prevent it in the future.  </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Make sure to wipe their leaves</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Rubber Plants can suffer from dry crispy leaves if there isn't much humidity in your home. Make sure to either mist their leaves or wipe them down with a damp cloth every so often. This will also keep your Rubber Plant's leaves looking shiny and healthy. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Rubber Plants can be mildly toxic</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Some people are allergic to the sap of Rubber Plants so make sure to wash your hands if you come into contact with any sap. Ingesting some of a leaf may also cause stomach irritation. Rubber Plants can also be mildly toxic to your pets so make sure your furry friends don't ingest any of the leaves. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagating your Rubber Plant is easy</h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">It's quite simple to propagate your Rubber Plant as you can do it straight from a leaf cutting. Start by snipping off a healthy branch cutting and letting it root in water. Alternatively you can pot your Rubber Plant cutting it straight into soil. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The leaves are turning yellow </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">This can be a combination of overwatering and not enough sunlight. Check how moist the soil is and replace if necessary. If your plant is in a shady spot, try to move it closer to a window so it gets more sunlight. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Rubber Plants aren't fussy about temperature</h3>
Rubber Plants tend to do well in a range of temperatures so there is no need to worry about moving them around as the seasons change. The only thing to watch out for is that they are not next to any air vents or drafty windows and doors as this may cause temperature shock.]]></wp:meta_value>

We recommend pruning your Rubber Plant once a year as you can help control how you want it to grow. Pruning also helps encourage new healthy growth. It is best to prune your Rubber Plant in Spring and avoid pruning it in the dormant months of Autumn and Winter.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Rubber Plants love bright, indirect light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Although they can adjust to lower light levels, Rubber Plants prefer indirect sunlight. Make sure to keep them away from the direct sun however, as this can be really damaging for their leaves as it can very quickly cause leaf burn. Using a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter</a> is a great way to know how much light your plant is getting throughout the day. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Water thoroughly, but infrequently]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Rubber plants need to be watered more in the warmer months to help with new growth. You should make sure the soil is moist, but never waterlogged to avoid any root rot. Using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> can really help figure out if your plant needs more water. If you may have overwatered your Rubber Plant, check out our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-prevent-diagnose-and-fix-root-rot/">root rot guide</a> to see how to fix and prevent it in the future.  </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Rubber Plants can suffer from dry crispy or curling leaves if there isn't much humidity in your home. A super easy way to increase the humidity is by using a <a href="/a/humidifier">humidifier</a> to keep a nice consistent level.</span>

<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot=""> Make sure to either mist their leaves or wipe them down with a damp cloth every so often. This will also keep your Rubber Plant's leaves looking shiny and healthy. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pruning your Rubber Plant can help growth]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend pruning your Rubber Plant once a year with clean, <a href="/a/pruning-scissors">sharp shears</a>, as you can help control how you want it to grow. Pruning also helps encourage new healthy growth.

It is best to prune your Rubber Plant in Spring and avoid pruning it in the dormant months of Autumn and Winter.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;The name Rubber Plant comes from the latex in the leaves, which was once used to actually make rubber! They are a great plant to bring a little bit of that rainforest feel right into your home. And whilst they can reach about 30 metres in their native environment, when potted in your home they’ll be much smaller don’t worry!\n\nCaring for your Rubber Plant doesn’t have to be difficult. Good light levels and not too much water are the basics to remember. As they are native to Southern Asia, they love humidity and will really struggle with dry air so regularly misting will keep your plant happy and healthy. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">The name Rubber Plant comes from the latex in the leaves, which was once used to actually make rubber! They are a great plant to bring a little bit of that rainforest feel right into your home. And whilst they can reach about 30 metres in their native environment, when potted in your home they’ll be much smaller don’t worry!</span>

Caring for your Rubber Plant doesn’t have to be difficult. Good light levels and not too much water are the basics to remember. As they are native to Southern Asia, they love humidity and will really struggle with dry air so regularly misting will keep your plant happy and healthy.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic String of Hearts Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">The String of Hearts is one of our favourites as it can be relatively easy to care for, fits beautifully into any space and propagates easily! Here you will find our full String of Hearts care guide with all the information you need for your plant to thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_pull_quote]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fc584bd3]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;"><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Common Issues for String of Hearts</span></h2>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Although the String of Hearts are relatively easy plants to care for, it's still important to look out for any warning signs that might suggest it is struggling in its current conditions. The most common issues are yellowing leaves and dry, crispy stems. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>String of Hearts love sunlight</h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Your String of Hearts loves bright areas of your home. They can deal with a few hours of direct sunlight each day but prefer to be in a spot with indirect light so their leaves don't burn. Your String of Hearts </span>may struggle a little in the darker winter months so you might want to move them a little closer to the window during winter.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">They don't like sitting in water</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The String of Hearts is a type of succulent meaning that they don't do so well in damp soil. It is very important that you let them dry out between waterings otherwise this will very quickly lead to root rot. </span>

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">String of Hearts prefer average humidity</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">String of Hearts plants thrive best in 40-50% humidity which is what most households should be naturally. This means you don't need to worry about misting or increasing humidity levels for your String of Hearts which makes them a pretty easy plant to take care of. You can read our guide to humidity for houseplants <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">here</a> if you want to find out more. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">String of Hearts plants are easy to propagate. </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The String of Hearts may just be one of the easiest plants to propagate. Cut off a piece of the vine just above the node (where two heart leaves are) and place in water or soil. Roots should grow within a few weeks! We have written a whole guide on how to propagate your String of Hearts <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-propagate-your-string-of-hearts-plant/">here</a>. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The vines are very leggy</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Large gaps between the leaves tends to suggest the plant isn't getting enough light so try and move it to a sunnier spot.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The leaves are very light in colour</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot=""> This is another symptom of not enough light. Try to move it to a sunnier spot in order for it to regain more colour to its leaves. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>String of Hearts don't need regular fertilisation</h3>
To encourage new growth on your String of Hearts, you may want to give it some fertiliser. However, make sure you only feed it once a month during the growth periods of Spring and Summer, and not at all during winter. We also recommend fertilising your String of Hearts at half-strength.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only ever repot during the growth period</h3>
String of Hearts plants don't need constant repotting as their roots are delicate and won't become root bound very often. If you do want to repot your String of Hearts, try to only do it during the growth months of Spring and Summer as this will minimise shock .]]></wp:meta_value>

They can deal with a few hours of direct sunlight each day but prefer to be in a spot with indirect light so their leaves don't burn. Your String of Hearts </span>may struggle a little in the darker winter months so you might want to move them a little closer to the window during winter.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Don't worry about pruning your String of Hearts</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">String of Hearts plants don't need to be pruned like other houseplants. As long as you cut off the odd dead stem, and propagate cuttings if it gets too long for your space, there isn't really any need for pruning your String of Hearts. Just another reason why String of Hearts are so easy to care for!</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Native to South Africa, the String of Hearts should be top on your list for trailing houseplants. You don’t get much more unique than their speckled heart-shaped leaves. The other thing we love about the String of Hearts is that it’s such a fast grower over the spring and summer months, you’ll blink and there will be two new leaves popping out somewhere. \n\nThe String of Hearts is a semi-succulent plant meaning they don’t need much water, otherwise, it’ll cause their delicate shallow leaves to rot pretty quickly. Oh, and because they have such shallow roots, you won’t need to repot for a very very long time. \n\nIt makes the perfect plant for hanging down shelving, and because its pet friendly, you don’t need to worry about it ever becoming too long! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Native to South Africa, the String of Hearts should be top on your list for trailing houseplants. You don’t get much more unique than their speckled heart-shaped leaves. The other thing we love about the String of Hearts is that it’s such a fast grower over the spring and summer months, you’ll blink and there will be two new leaves popping out somewhere.

The String of Hearts is a semi-succulent plant meaning they don’t need much water, otherwise, it’ll cause their delicate shallow leaves to rot pretty quickly. Oh, and because they have such shallow roots, you won’t need to repot for a very very long time.

It makes the perfect plant for hanging down shelving, and because its pet friendly, you don’t need to worry about it ever becoming too long!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Kentia Palm Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Kentia Palms are pretty hardy plants that can stand environments which many other houseplants wouldn’t be able to, making them quite easy to care for. They can grow up to 40 feet but indoor Kentia Palms won’t often grow more than 3-4 metres.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

They are pretty adaptable plants and won't die suddenly if not given the right care. However, there are some problems that may occur over time so make sure to check up on your palm every so often.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">They thrive in bright, indirect light</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Kentia Palms will also adapt to low light environments but this might stilt growth. During darker winter months try to move your plant nearer the windows to maximise on the light.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Make sure to water them regularly </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Kentia palms are pretty tolerant when it comes to watering but they don’t like it too dry or overly soggy. Every so often mist your Kentia palm and it will love you.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Room temperature suits them best</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">This makes kentia palms super easy to grow at home. Just be cautious of putting them close to draughty windows or doors and water slightly more if you have the heating on a lot over winter. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">They are safe for children and pets </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Unlike many other houseplants, kentia palms are completely safe for children and pets!</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Remember to dust their leaves</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Kentia palms are a little fussy about having dust on their leaves so make sure to give it a once over with a damp cloth every now and again.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>A<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">void repotting your palm</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Kentia palms have pretty delicate roots so don't like to be repotted often. It is better to leave your palm in the pot even if it is a little root-bound, than to disrupt the root system by repotting. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Propagation can be very difficult</span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Kentia palms can only be propagated by germinating the seed which is pretty difficult to do indoors. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The leaf tips are turning brown </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">This is most likely due to underwatering which is drying out the leaves. Check the moisture in the soil and water your palm more regularly. Remember they don't like to dry out completely inbetween waterings.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Some leaves are turning yellow </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">This is most often caused by root rot meaning you are overwatering your palm. Replace the soil if it is waterlogged and water less frequently. Learn more about why your kentia palm is turning yellow here.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3><span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">The plant is unstable </span></h3>
<span data-token-index="0" data-reactroot="">Overwatering can affect the root system which will mean the plant is unable to stand upright. The best option is to stop watering as much for a while. If the problem persists, try taking the plant out of the pot and replacing the soil. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are leaf tips on my Kentia Palm turning brown?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that your Kentia Palm's leaf tips are turning crispy brown, this is most likely due to underwatering which is drying out the leaves. Check the moisture in the soil and water your palm more regularly. Remember Kentia Palms don't like to dry out completely inbetween waterings.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are some of the leaves on my Kentia Palm turning yellow?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellowing leaves on Kentia Palms is most often caused by root rot meaning you are overwatering your palm. Replace the soil if it is waterlogged and water less frequently. Find out more in our post about <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-is-my-kentia-palm-turning-yellow/">yellow Kentia Palm leaves</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[My Kentia Palm is unstable]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Kentia Palms are pretty hardy plants that can stand environments which many other houseplants wouldn’t be able to, making them quite easy to care for. They can grow up to 40 feet outdoors but will rarely get over 13 feet when kept indoors.\n\nThey can be quite fussy about watering however and prefer to get little and often as this stops their soil from drying out completely or being soggy for longer periods of time. They also aren’t great with having dusty leaves, so we recommend wiping them down with a damp cloth every now and then to keep them clean. \n\nThe good news is that they are completely safe and non-toxic, so perfect for homes with pets or kids! &quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Kentia Palms are pretty hardy plants that can stand environments that many other houseplants wouldn’t be able to, making them quite easy to care for. They can grow up to 40 feet outdoors but will rarely get over 13 feet when kept indoors.

They can be quite fussy about watering however and prefer to get little and often as this stops their soil from drying out completely or being soggy for longer periods of time. They also aren’t great with having dusty leaves, so we recommend wiping them down with a damp cloth every now and then to keep them clean.

The good news is that they are completely safe and non-toxic, so perfect for homes with pets or kids! </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Dragon Trees are very easy plants to care for. They bounce back quickly from improper care and will repay you with fast growth if looked after well. In our Dragon Tree care guide, you will find all the tips and info you need to help your plant thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Dragon Trees</h2>
Although Dragon Plants are fairly easy to care for, they may start to show signs of suffering if their care or environment is not ideal. The most common issues for Dragon Trees are brown leaves and leaf tips.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dragon Plants like bright indirect light</h3>
Make sure you don't place your Dragon Tree in direct light as this will burn and damage the leaves, which is irreversible. Don't worry if your Dragon Tree is in a slightly shadier spot, it just means it might grow a bit slower.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Be careful not to overwater</h3>
Dragon Trees won't die on you if you give them too much water every so often, but constant overwatering will lead to root rot and other issues. Make sure to check the soil's moisture before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dragon Trees aren't temperature sensitive</h3>
Don't worry too much about getting the right temperature for your Dragon Tree. If it is comfortable for you to live in, it will be fine for your Dragon Tree. Just make sure to keep it away from air vents and radiators.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Unlike some other houseplants, Dragon Trees aren't fussy about their potting soil. Just use a nice high-quality soil and your plant will be fine.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Mist your Dragon Tree's leaves</h3>
Although you don't need to worry too much about humidity levels for your Dragon Tree, we recommend misting the leaves every couple of weeks to increase plant health.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dragon Trees like fresh air</h3>
Over winter, your Dragon Tree can suffer with all the warm stuffy heating air. Try to open the windows and air out your home to increase the circulation of fresh air.]]></wp:meta_value>

The best way to tell whether or not your Dragon Tree needs repotting is to see if there are any roots popping out at the bottom of the pot. We recommend repotting your Dragon Tree every two years into a pot a few cm bigger in diameter than the previous one.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;The Dragon Tree was actually our first ever houseplant and ignited our initial love for caring for indoor plants many years ago. Native to Madagascar, it’s a timeless plant that brings elegance and style to every room. They are also super easy to care for and are great at purifying the air which makes them the perfect entry-level houseplant. \n\nYou’ll have a hard time trying to kill a Dragon Tree as they are pretty drought-tolerant and forgiving when it comes to light, temperature levels and humidity so it’ll adapt well to every spot in your home. \n\nAlthough they can reach up to 6 metres in their natural outdoor habitat, they’ll only ever get to about 1.5/2 metres when grown indoors (and even this will take years and years) so you don’t need to worry about it getting too big to handle. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">The Dragon Tree was actually our first ever houseplant and ignited our initial love for caring for indoor plants many years ago. Native to Madagascar, it’s a timeless plant that brings elegance and style to every room. They are also super easy to care for and are great at purifying the air which makes them the perfect entry-level houseplant.

You’ll have a hard time trying to kill a Dragon Tree as they are pretty drought-tolerant and forgiving when it comes to light, temperature levels and humidity so it’ll adapt well to every spot in your home.

Although they can reach up to 6 metres in their natural outdoor habitat, they’ll only ever get to about 1.5/2 metres when grown indoors (and even this will take years and years) so you don’t need to worry about it getting too big to handle.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for String of Pearls</h3>
It can sometimes be tricky to grow your String of Pearls indoors, so it is important that you keep an eye out for any warning signs that might indicate your plant is unhappy. Signs of stress include shrivelling leaves, thinning stems and a loss of leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>String of Pearls love sunshine</h3>
They can't get enough of the sunshine so find a bright spot in your home for your String of Pearls. Do keep it away from hours of direct sunlight though as it can cause them to burn.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Be sparing on the water</h3>
String of Pearls plants are succulents, meaning they don't require much water. They prefer their soil to be dry and overwatering can very quickly lead to root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>String of Pearls need space</h3>
These hanging succulents will need space to grow so make sure there is enough room for it to sprawl downwards.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't worry about fertilising</h3>
String of Pearls don't need to be fertilised often, if at all. Overfertilisation can actually cause real harm to your plant quite quickly so we recommend leaving it out completely.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagating your String of Pearls is easy</h3>
All you need to do is snip off some of the pearls and place half of the cutting in water. Change out the water every few days and you should start to see some new roots growing after a few weeks. You can also propagate your String of Pearls by burying the pearls in soil and watering regularly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>String of Pearls are toxic to your pets</h3>
Keep your furry friends and children away from your String of Pearls plant as ingesting them can cause skin irritation and stomach ache.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If your String of Pearls plant is losing leaves, it can be a sign of the temperature being too low or it being in a drafty spot in your home. Try to move your String of Pearls to a warmer spot to see if the pearls stop dropping.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice yellow leaves on your String of Pearls, this is probably a sign of overwatering. Too much moisture in the soil leads to root rot. Replace the soil immediately if you think you may have overwatered your String of Pearls.]]></wp:meta_value>

As with watering, too much misting of your String of Pearls plant can quite quickly lead to root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[String of Pearls plants are succulents, meaning they don't require much water. They prefer their soil to be dry and overwatering can very quickly lead to root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagating your String of Pearls is easy]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[All you need to do to propagate a String of Pearls is snip off some of the pearls and place half of the cutting in water. Change out the water every few days and you should start to see some new roots growing after a few weeks. You can also propagate your String of Pearls by burying the pearls in soil and watering regularly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3953]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;\nIt’s not difficult to fall instantly in love with the String of Pearls plant as their incredible small spherical leaves cascade dramatically out of every pot and hanging basket. The String of Pearls is a succulent plant meaning they love a lot of sunshine but don’t need much too water as they are quite sensitive to root rot. \n\nIt’s important that you continuously propagate your String of Pearls plant as the vines don’t survive that long. Without any propagation, your plant might only last about 5-6 years but luckily you can just take stem cuttings to regenerate growth. \n\nThe thing we love most about the String of Pearls is how quickly it grows during spring and summer. It really makes up for the lack of growth during the darker colder months that’s for sure! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">It’s not difficult to fall instantly in love with the String of Pearls plant as their incredible small spherical leaves cascade dramatically out of every pot and hanging basket. The String of Pearls is a succulent plant meaning they love a lot of sunshine but don’t need much too water as they are quite sensitive to root rot.

It’s important that you continuously propagate your String of Pearls plant as the vines don’t survive that long. Without any propagation, your plant might only last about 5-6 years but luckily you can just take stem cuttings to regenerate growth.

The thing we love most about the String of Pearls is how quickly it grows during spring and summer. It really makes up for the lack of growth during the darker colder months that’s for sure!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">ZZ Plants are hardy and perfect for anyone who might find it difficult to give their houseplants constant care and attention. Here you will find all the information you need to properly care for your ZZ Plant.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for ZZ Plants</h2>
Although ZZ Plants are some of the least sensitive houseplants you can buy, it doesn't mean they won't occasionally display signs of unhappiness and stress. The most common issues for ZZ Plants are curling leaves, brown spots  or tips on the leaves or yellowing of the plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>ZZ Plants cope in a range of light conditions</h3>
Although they prefer bright, indirect light, ZZ Plants will cope in low light areas of your home too. Just be careful not to put your ZZ Plant in direct light or this can burn and damage the leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Water your ZZ Plant every 1-2 weeks</h3>
ZZ Plants really don't like soggy soil so it is best to be quite cautious when it comes to watering. Make sure that the top of the soil is dry before giving it any more water.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Don't worry about needing to up the humidity for your ZZ Plant, they aren't that fussy!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>ZZ Plants are mildly toxic to pets</h3>
Try and keep your ZZ Plant out of the way of pets (and small humans too) as they can be mildly toxic if ingested, causing vomiting and stomach irritation.]]></wp:meta_value>

We recommend misting the leaves, or wiping them down with a damp cloth every so often so prevent the build up of dust.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If the tips of your ZZ Plant's leaves are turning brown and crispy, it will most often be caused by underwatering. Give your ZZ Plant a good soak through and adjust your watering schedule moving forward.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellow leaves on a ZZ Plant are either caused by too much direct sunlight or a pest infestation. Check the light levels in the are your ZZ Plant lives, as well as thoroughly checking over the leaves to spot any further signs of pests. If you do spot any pests on your ZZ Plant, treat it with <a href="/a/neem-oil">neem oil</a> and move away from all other plants.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Curling leaves on a ZZ Plant is often caused by too much direct sunlight. ZZ Plants prefer indirect or low light levels so try moving your plant to a shadier area of the room and monitoring the changes in light using a <a href="/a/light-monitor">sunlight meter.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although they prefer bright indirect light, ZZ Plants will cope in low light areas of your home too. Just be careful not to put your ZZ Plant in direct light or this can burn and damage the leaves. Use a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter</a> to determine if your ZZ Plant is getting enough light.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[ZZ Plants really don't like soggy soil so it is best to be quite cautious when it comes to watering. Make sure that the top of the soil is dry before giving it any more water. We recommend watering your ZZ Plant no more than twice monthly and using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to check when your plant needs water.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate your ZZ Plant by division or leaf cutting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The best way to propagate a ZZ Plant is by division of the mother plant. Carefully remove the plant from the pot and divide up the root system into several new smaller plants. Alternatively you can also propagate by leaf cutting but this will take a lot longer.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Also known as the Zanzibar Gem, the ZZ Plant is a great low-maintenance minimalist houseplant. Loved for their dark green glossy oval leaves, we recommend this one for those without a fantastic track record of keeping plants alive, but also for anyone looking for something smart and stylish to spruce up their home. They are very adaptable and will deal well with some bright but indirect light, as well as shady dark corners of your home. \n\nThe ZZ Plant is quite slow-growing so you won’t see new stems popping out all of the time. It’s important to note that they grow bulb-like roots called rhizomes so will need quite a large pot to really thrive and grow. This also means they are drought tolerant as they store water in their rhizomes. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Also known as the Zanzibar Gem, the ZZ Plant is a great low-maintenance minimalist houseplant. Loved for their dark green glossy oval leaves, we recommend this one for those without a fantastic track record of keeping plants alive, but also for anyone looking for something smart and stylish to spruce up their home. They are very adaptable and will deal well with some bright but indirect light, as well as shady dark corners of your home.

The ZZ Plant is quite slow-growing so you won’t see new stems popping out all of the time. It’s important to note that they grow bulb-like roots called rhizomes so will need quite a large pot to really thrive and grow. This also means they are drought tolerant as they store water in their rhizomes.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Schefflera Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Schefflera Plants, also known as Umbrella Plants, are easy to care for and striking in every room. Below you will find all the information you need to care for your Schefflera including basic care tips as well as how to diagnose and treat common problems.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Schefflera</h2>
Although Schefflera are hardy plants that can deal with a variety of environments, they can sometimes show signs of stress and unhappiness so it is important that you know what to look for. The most common problems for Schefflera plants are brown and yellow leaves as well drooping stems and leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Schefflera like bright, indirect light</h3>
Although they can deal with a range of light conditions, we recommend putting your Schefflera in a bright spot that doesn't receive too much direct sunlight.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They need rotating every month</h3>
This is because your Schefflera will begin to lean towards the light and rotating it every few weeks will help keep it stable and looking even.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Check the soil before watering</h3>
Schefflera don't need to be watered a huge amount and will not mind at all if you forget every so often. They don't like their roots to be sitting in water so just make sure your check your Schefflera's soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Boosting the humidity is not a necessity</h3>
Your Schefflera will do just fine with the natural humidity levels in your home. If you do want to boost the humidity, we recommend misting the leaves every other week or using a pebble tray.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Schefflera prefer warmer temperatures.</h3>
During the winter months, your Schefflera may struggle if the temperature in your home drops too low. We recommend making sure that your Schefflera isn't sat next to an AC vent or drafty doors/windows as this may cause your plant to go into shock and lose a few of its leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Schefflera are toxic to pets and humans</h3>
The sap inside your Schefflera's leaves is mildly toxic to humans and pets. Try to wear gloves if repotting or handling your Schefflera and keep it out of the way of your furry friends or small humans.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertilising your Schefflera is totally optional</h3>
You can have a happy and healthy Schefflera without fertilising it. However, if you do want to boost growth, you can do this by giving it soluble fertiliser a couple of times over the Spring and Summer months.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Schefflera losing leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dropping leaves on your Schefflera may be due to shock. If you have recently moved or repotted your Schefflera don't be alarmed if a few leaves drop off.

Also pay attention to the light levels as insufficient sunlight be also cause your Schefflera to lose some of its lower leaves as it focuses its energy on producing new growth.

You can find out more in our journal post about <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-is-my-schefflera-losing-leaves/">why your Schefflera is losing leaves</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

We have written a guide on <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-is-my-schefflera-drooping/">drooping Schefflera leaves</a> with more information.]]></wp:meta_value>

You may be either over or underwatering your Schefflera so check the soil moisture and adjust your watering schedule accordingly.]]></wp:meta_value>

We recommend making sure that your Schefflera isn't sat next to an AC vent or drafty doors/windows as this may cause your plant to go into shock and lose a few of its leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[You can propagate a Schefflera using stem cuttings ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The simplest way to successfully propagate a Schefflera plant is to use stem cuttings. Carefully cut off part an offshoot of the stem, or the top part of the plant with clean sharp scissors. Make sure it has part of the stem rather than just a leaf as roots will establish themselves quicker. Place in clean water to begin with until roots have formed. Then root into potting soil and continue usual Schefflera care.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_6108021a5827d]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3960]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Also known as the Umbrella Plant because of their dome-shaped leaves, the Schefflera is not only easy to care for but it’s pretty unique too! A mature Schefflera can sometimes have up to 16 little leaves off one stalk, whilst smaller plants may only have 4 or 5. \n\nWhen it comes to caring for your Schefflera, they are quite hardy and adapt well to different environments. You don’t need to worry about humidity levels etc so it’s pretty simple. One thing to note is that it’s a good idea to rotate your plant every few weeks. Schefflera plants have a tendency to lean towards the light so can become quite unbalance if not turned regularly. \n\nUnfortunately, Scheffleras are toxic to pets and humans so you need to keep this one away from small children or any furry friends that might be tempted to take a bite. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Also known as the Umbrella Plant because of their dome-shaped leaves, the Schefflera is not only easy to care for but it’s pretty unique too! A mature Schefflera can sometimes have up to 16 little leaves off one stalk, whilst smaller plants may only have 4 or 5.

When it comes to caring for your Schefflera, they are quite hardy and adapt well to different environments. You don’t need to worry about humidity levels etc so it’s pretty simple. One thing to note is that it’s a good idea to rotate your plant every few weeks. Schefflera plants have a tendency to lean towards the light so can become quite unbalance if not turned regularly.

Unfortunately, Scheffleras are toxic to pets and humans so you need to keep this one away from small children or any furry friends that might be tempted to take a bite.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbd77b950]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Devil's Ivy</h2>
It is important that you know what to look out for when it comes to common problems in your Devil's Ivy plant. The sooner you diagnose and fix the problem, the more chance you will have that your plant survives.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Devil's Ivy love the sunshine</h3>
Luckily for you, Devil's Ivy will thrive in all kinds of environments, from shady corners to bright windowsills. Be a little careful when it comes to direct light as this can burn the leaves, especially in the hot summer months.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Water about once a week</h3>
Your Devil's Ivy won't be super fussy when it comes to watering. The occasional over or underwatering won't kill it so just make sure that you check the moisture of the soil before watering and give it some time to dry out in between.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They prefer slightly higher humidity</h3>
Although this isn't a must-have, Devil's Ivy do prefer rooms with slightly higher humidity, such as the bathroom or kitchen. You can also increase the humidity yourself my misting the leaves or using a pebble tray for example.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Devil's Ivy is mildly toxic</h3>
Make sure you keep your Devil's Ivy away from pets and small humans as it can be slightly toxic if ingested, causing stomach and mouth irritation.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They like warmer environments</h3>
Try to avoid placing your Devil's Ivy near drafty doors or windows as the cold air from outside will cause your plant to go into shock.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Devil's Ivy couldn't be easier to propagate</h3>
You can propagate your Devil's Ivy by trimming off a leaf and node and placing in water. After a few weeks, roots should appear from the cutting, ready to be planted into soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't worry about repotting your Devil's Ivy</h3>
Devil's Ivy can survive for quite a long time in the same pot, so don't worry too much about repotting. Keep an eye on roots that may be popping out at the top or bottom of the pot so you know when it might be time to rehome your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Prune off any leggy vines</h3>
Throughout the year, your Devil's Ivy may produce offshoots with very few leaves which tend to look a little bare and leggy. We recommend pruning these back to give your plant a fuller look and help it concentrate on producing new healthy growth.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
