		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Variegation depends on the sunlight</h3>
The leaves on your Devil's Ivy will become more variegated with more sunshine. If your leaves are looking quite pale, it may be because it is not receiving enough sunlight.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellow leaves on a Devil's Ivy usually indicates watering issues. Check the moisture of the soil to see whether you are under or overwatering your Devil's Ivy.

It may also be due to natural ageing as over time some of the leaves on your Devil's Ivy may turn yellow and drop off but this is nothing to worry about.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Curling leaves on your Devil's Ivy/ Pothos plant is often caused by either watering or light issues. Check the moisture of the soil as well as how much light your plant is getting throughout the day and adjust the care/environment.]]></wp:meta_value>

The occasional over or underwatering won't kill it so just make sure that you check the moisture of the soil before watering and give it some time to dry out in between.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although this isn't a must-have, Devil's Ivy do prefer rooms with slightly higher humidity, such as the bathroom or kitchen. You can also increase the humidity yourself my misting the leaves or using a pebble tray for example. Find out more in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">humidity guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>

After a few weeks, roots should appear from the cutting, meaning it is ready to be planted into soil and you can resume your normal Devil's Ivy care routine.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;These are pretty unique houseplants because they actually prefer lower-light conditions over anything else! That’s where the name comes from, as they are well acquainted with the darkness. If you have a variegated variety, it will actually start to lose their pattern if placed in too much sunlight. So you don’t need to feel guilty about putting a Devil’s Ivy in a shady spot because it will actually love you for it. \n\nThey are also pretty hardy plants in terms of their other care requirements. They don’t need complicated watering schedules or specific pruning so are perfect for any new plant parents. You can't really go wrong with these at all!\n\nWhen it comes to styling the Devil’s Ivy plant, shelving is where they thrive as it gives it room to cascade dramatically out of the pot. They can be trained to grow upwards by a wall or moss pole so the option is yours. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">These are pretty unique houseplants because they actually prefer lower-light conditions over anything else! That’s where the name comes from, as they are well acquainted with the darkness. If you have a variegated variety, it will actually start to lose its pattern if placed in too much sunlight. So you don’t need to feel guilty about putting a Devil’s Ivy in a shady spot because it will actually love you for it.

They are also pretty hardy plants in terms of their other care requirements. They don’t need complicated watering schedules or specific pruning so are perfect for any new plant parents. You can't really go wrong with these at all!

When it comes to styling the Devil’s Ivy plant, shelving is where they thrive as it gives it room to cascade dramatically out of the pot. They can be trained to grow upwards by a wall or moss pole so the option is yours.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Prayer Plant Care</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Maranta plants get their nickname Prayer Plants from the unique way their leaves fold in the evenings which looks as if they are praying. Below you will find our complete Prayer Plant care guide with all the information you need to take care of your plant as well as deal with any issues you may run into. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They prefer bright, indirect light</h3>
Although Prayer Plants can survive, and thrive, in most light conditions, the ideal would be a spot with bright but indirect sunlight. Too much direct sunlight can burn the leaves and the colour will fade.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Prayer Plants like moist soil</h3>
But this doesn't mean they like soggy soil. We tend to go for a little and often approach to watering a Prayer Plant to ensure that the soil doesn't dry out totally but it prevents any overwatering from occurring.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Prayer Plants love humidity</h3>
If your home has quite dry air you might want to think about increasing the humidity in the room to help your Prayer Plant. You can invest in a humidifier, mist the leaves every few days, or use a pebble tray.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep them away from drafts</h3>
Prayer Plants don't deal so well next to drafty windows or doors as the cooler air from outside will cause shock. Try to keep your plant in the warmer areas of your home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Use a water-soluble fertiliser</h3>
During the growth months, you want to be feeding your Prayer Plant every few weeks using a water-soluble fertiliser. Just make sure not to give it at full-strength as this can cause harm to the roots and slowly kill your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Prayer Plant by division</h3>
Propagating your Prayer Plant can be quite simple if your plant is fairly mature. Carefully divide the mother plant, ensuring a good amount of roots remain on both parts and place into water or plant straight into well-draining potting soil.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only ever repot your Prayer Plant in Spring</h3>
You shouldn't need to repot your Prayer Plant very often, every couple of years or so will do. Make sure that when you do repot, that you choose a pot only a few cm bigger than the last or this will cause shock to the main root system and the plant may become unstable.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are my Prayer Plant's leaves curling?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Curling leaves on a Prayer Plant are most commonly caused by a lack of water or humidity. Make sure to take your plant out of its pot or use a moisture meter to check the moisture in the soil and adjust your watering accordingly. If the curling leaves are caused by a lack of moisture, they will soon recover and uncurl after watering again. If the soil is waterlogged and soggy replace it immediately to prevent further damage. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You can also increase the humidity for your Prayer Plant to stop the leaves from drying up and curling inwards. Prayer Plant leaves may also be curling due to temperatures being too low. Make sure your plant isn’t next to any drafty windows or doors as the cool air from outside may be shocking your plant, causing the leaves to curl.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Prayer Plant have brown leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Brown leaves on a Prayer Plant are often caused by a lack of humidity or issues with sunlight. Prayer Plants are native to rainforests so are super sensitive to dry air. Misting or using a humidifier should prevent the problem from getting worse. Unfortunately, once the leaves have gone brown there is no going back from there. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re still unsure about how to spot or fix the problem of brown leaves on your Prayer Plant, you can read more about it </span><a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/why-is-my-prayer-plant-turning-brown/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there yellow spots on my Prayer Plant's leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you notice yellow spots forming on your Prayer Plant’s leaves it is probably caused by bad water quality. Prayer Plants are quite sensitive to high levels of chemicals found in hard tap water. Leave out the water for around 24 hours so that the chlorine and fluoride evaporates. Alternatively, you can also use rainwater or distilled water to avoid this.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are the leaves on my Prayer Plant fading and losing their colour?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you notice that your Prayer Plant’s leaves are discolouring, it will be caused by sunlight issues, either too much or too little. If the old leaves are fading they are being exposed to too much intense sunlight. However, if it’s the new leaves that are turning quite solid green and losing their variegation then it usually means your Prayer Plant needs more sunlight. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Prayer Plant have brown tips on its leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Brown tips on a Prayer Plant is most commonly caused by dry air. If your room lacks humidity, it will cause the leaves to dry out, starting at the tips and edges. Increase the humidity by misting your plant every few days, using a pebble tray or investing in a humidifier to keep a nice stable humidity level for your Prayer Plant. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Prayer Plants prefer bright, indirect light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Although Prayer Plants can survive, and often thrive, in most light conditions, the ideal spot would be somewhere with bright but indirect sunlight. If your Prayer Plant gets too much bright indirect sunlight then the leaves can fade in colour and burn which shows up as brown or yellow burnt patches on the leaves. Unfortunately, this is irreversible so it’s important you make sure your Prayer Plant is away from direct sunlight in summer where the light is not only out for much longer each day, but the rays are stronger and more intense. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your Prayer Plant is getting too little light, then the new leaves on your plant will start to lose their variegation and become a more solid green colour. If this happens, move your plant to a slightly sunnier spot in your home.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Prayer Plants need moist but not soggy potting mix ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Watering your Prayer Plant is probably the most tricky part of caring for the plant as they need just the right balance to prevent their soil from drying out but not becoming soggy or waterlogged. We recommend buying a moisture meter to keep track of when your Prayer Plant needs a top-up. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We tend to go for a little and often approach when watering our Prayer Plants to ensure that the soil doesn’t dry out totally but it prevents any overwatering from occurring as root rot is the number 1 killer of Prayer Plants. It’s important that you use a tray or planter to capture any excess water which you should pour away 30 minutes after watering. This gives your plant enough time to soak up how much it needs. Make sure you use room temperature water as hot or cold water can shock or burn your plant which over time can cause real issues. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Top tip: when watering, water directly into the soil close to the base of the plant. Avoid getting the leaves wet when watering as they can begin to rot. Don’t worry about getting the leaves wet when misting as it won’t dampen the leaves enough to cause the leaves to rot but will hydrate the plant a little. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Use a well-draining potting mix for your Prayer Plant]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Prayer Plants do best in a well-draining potting mix which includes perlite as this helps with not only drainage but aeration of the soil. Prayer Plants are very sensitive to overwatering so it’s important that your potting mix doesn’t stay too soggy.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">To aid with drainage, you must have drainage holes at the bottom of the pot so excess water can run out. We also recommend putting a few small rocks at the bottom of the pot as these will prevent the drainage holes from being blocked by clumps of soil.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Prayer Plants need high humidity levels ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">As they are native to tropical rainforests, Prayer Plants like greenhouse conditions which include high humidity levels. If your home has quite dry air you need to increase the humidity in the room otherwise the leaves on your Prayer Plant will quickly dry out. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are a few different methods you can use to increase the humidity for your Prayer Plant. Misting the leaves every few days using a spray bottle is super easy but does come with the slight risk of leaf rot if you mist your Prayer Plant’s leaves too much in colder months. You can also make your own pebble tray which allows water to evaporate around your plant. However, the most effective and reliable way to increase the humidity for your Prayer Plant is by using a humidifier. They create a stable humidity level in your home and some can even be set on a timer so you don’t need to worry about forgetting to turn them on. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Keep your Prayer Plant away from drafts]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Prayer Plants don’t adapt so well to extreme temperatures so keep your plant away from drafty windows, AC vents or hotspots caused by radiators or cookers. Normal room temperature is the ideal environment for your Prayer Plant. If the temperatures are too low, your Prayer Plant will begin to lose leaves and if it gets too hot for your plant you won’t see many new leaves but instead, you’ll notice long spindly stems.  </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Use a water-soluble fertiliser]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Prayer Plants are quite slow growers so the best way to enhance growth is by fertilising your plant. You only want to fertilise during the growth months as Prayer Plants go into a dormant period.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We recommend feeding your Prayer Plant once every few weeks during spring and summer using a water-soluble fertiliser. We tend to use less than the recommended amount as what it says on the bottle won’t be accurate for every single plant! Too much fertiliser can burn through your plant’s roots which can cause brown leaves and plant death.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagating your Prayer Plant is super simple ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Propagating your Prayer Plant is really easy and can be done through two main methods; division and stem cuttings. The method that you choose depends on how mature your plant is as well as your personal choice. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When using the division method, carefully separate your mother Prayer Plant, ensuring a good amount of roots remain on both parts and plant straight into well-draining potting soil. How much you divide your plant depends on how mature your plant is and how many natural divisions there are in your plant. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You can also propagate your Prayer Plant through stem cuttings by taking a cutting below a leaf node and growing it in water. After several weeks you should start to see new roots growing from your cutting. Once these roots have matured a little you can plant them into well-draining soil and care for it as you would your mother plant. We recommend only taking stem cuttings in spring as it will take several months for roots to grow and doing the process in the warm sunny months gives your cuttings the best chance at success. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Watch out for pests on your Prayer Plant]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Unfortunately, Prayer Plants are prone to pests such as spider mites and mealybugs. It’s important to keep a constant eye on your plant’s leaves to spot any early signs of pest as this will give you the best chance of spotting the issue early. Check the undersides of the leaves as that’s where the pests like to hang out. We also recommend giving any new plants the once over after buying them as this will help prevent bringing unwanted insects into your home.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The most common signs that your Prayer Plant is infested with pests are: white powder on the leaves, webbing across the leaves, brown dots on the plant or small holes in the leaves. Use a magnifying glass to spot any issues or even visible pests. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you spot a pest infestation on your Prayer Plant, treat it with a natural insecticide. We have always found need oil to be really successful. Move your infected plant away from any other houseplants so that the pests cannot jump across the leaves and harm your other houseplants. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Only ever repot your Prayer Plant in Spring]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Maranta Prayer Plants have very shallow roots as they grow outwards rather than upwards so you shouldn’t need to repot your plant very often. Once every couple of years or so will do. Repotting can cause your Prayer Plant to be a little shocked as moving home can be pretty stressful (plants are more similar to humans than you might think!). </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When you do repot, choose a pot only a few cm bigger than the last or it can make the plant unstable and increase the risk of waterlogged soil. Due to their shallow roots, you should pick a pot that is wider than deep as this will help aid their spreading growth. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">One great thing about Prayer Plants is that they are completely safe for dogs and cats. So you don’t need to worry about your pet coming into contact or digesting part of your Prayer Plant. However, it’s good to discourage your pets from eating any of the leaves on your Prayer Plant as some houseplants are extremely toxic! </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_10_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Prayer Plants need good ventilation and airflow ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_10_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_10_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Growing your Prayer Plants indoors means they don’t get any exposure to the outdoor elements. This definitely does have positives as there’s no risk of high winds breaking your plant and there are fewer pests to kill your plant. However, it does mean that your Prayer Plant may not get adequate airflow which leaves them much more susceptible to disease or other issues. Avoid placing your plant near any vents to achieve airflow but fans and open windows will give good ventilation and help your Prayer plant thrive. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_10_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_11_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_11_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_11_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Prune your Prayer Plant in spring]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_11_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_11_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Throughout the colder darker months, your Prayer Plant will go into a dormant period where growth slows and becomes leggier. Pruning your plant in spring can encourage bushier growth and keep your plant looking healthier too! Using a clean pair of scissors (to avoid the risk of passing bacteria or pests onto your plant) and make a few cuts above the node on the stem. This will encourage new growth to form right under the cut. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you spot a yellowing leaf on your Prayer Plant, you may be wondering if you should cut it off or wait for it to naturally fall off. Both options are fine but we tend to remove yellow leaves so your Prayer Plant doesn’t waste any unneeded energy trying to revive it. Once the leaf has turned yellow there is no going back so it’s best to remove it and it will help your plant look better too. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_11_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Prayer Plant have yellow leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the leaves on your Prayer Plant are turning a solid yellow colour then this indicates watering issues. It can be caused by both under and overwatering your Prayer Plant. They don’t like sitting in soggy soil but can develop yellow leaves quickly if the potting mix completely dries out. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Watering your Prayer Plant is a fine balance that is affected by a lot of factors such as the size of your plant as well as the environment its in. Schedules don’t really work so well for Prayer Plants so using a moisture meter is the best way to monitor how much you should water your plant. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have been underwatering your Prayer Plant, don’t overcompensate by giving your plant loads of water in one go. This will shock your plant and can damage the root system. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f67396379d03]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_6_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[What’s causing the black leaves and stems on my Prayer Plant?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_6_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_6_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your Maranta Prayer Plant has a blackened base, this is a sign that overwatering has cause the root system to rot. This will affect your plant from the roots upwards so will impact the lower section of the plant first.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Take your Prayer Plant out of its pot and replace the soil immediately if still soggy. Don’t let it naturally dry out as this will risk more damage. If there are no roots or lower part of the plant that is salvageable, we recommend propagating the stems to save your Prayer Plant. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_6_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_6_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_6_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f67396379d03]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_7_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Prayer Plant losing leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_7_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_7_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you notice that your Prayer Plant is losing leaves at a quicker rate than it is growing new ones then this may be caused by low temperatures. If the leaves feel quite dry before they fall off then it may also be caused by dry air and a lack of humidity. Move your Prayer Plant to a slightly warmer spot in your home and mist the leaves every few days. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">However, if your Prayer Plant is losing a few leaves in autumn then it may be simply due to your plant going into the dormant period. It’s normal for Prayer Plants to stop all growth during autumn and winter and lose a lot of their leaves. It’s nothing to worry about and you simply need to give them a little bit more light and warm temperatures and they’ll regrow once spring is near! </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_7_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_7_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_7_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f67396379d03]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3 class="h2">About the Prayer Plant</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Native to the tropical rainforests of Brazil, the Prayer Plant family is loved for their variegated leaves with intricate vein patterns. You can easily spot a Prayer Plant by its leaf undersides as shades of deep red are revealed when the plant’s leaves curl up at night, bringing a splash of colour to your home. This natural folding of the leaves is called nyctinasty. Not only do Prayer Plants curl their leaves when night falls, but they generally move around a lot during the day too. Prayer Plants naturally follow the source of sunlight and if you were to watch a timelapse of your plant, you’d be shocked at how much they move and dance around. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Prayer Plants are quite slow growers, which spread out rather than grow tall. You may only find that your Prayer Plant reaches only about 30cm in height, but they will become quite bushy as they mature outwards. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Don’t expect your Prayer Plant to produce an abundance of flowers in spring and summer as they only very rarely bloom when grown indoors. You may be lucky and see the occasional small white flower but this won’t be a regular occurrence, unfortunately. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are several varieties of Prayer Plants that all look ever so slightly different. The most common is the tri-coloured Prayer Plant (M. leuconeura erythrophylla), also called the Herringbone plant which has red-veined leaves. You will also often see the Rabbit’s Foot Prayer Plant (M. leuconeura kerchoveana) which has more solid green leaves with darker green splashes. The third common variety is the Silver Band Prayer Plant (M. leuconeura massangeana) which has a dark green leaf background with a row of silver patches and white veins. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_6108021a5827d]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3928]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Native to the tropical rainforests of Brazil, the Prayer Plant is loved for its variegated leaves with intricate vein patterns. You can easily spot a Prayer Plant by its leaf undersides as shades of deep red are revealed when the plant’s leaves curl up at night, bringing a splash of colour to your home. \n\nThere are several varieties of Prayer Plants that all look ever so slightly different. The most common is the tri-colour which has red-veined leaves but you’ll sometimes see varieties with silver patches or dark green splashes. \n\nPrayer Plants are a little fussy though with light conditions, soil moisture and humidity levels though so we don’t recommend this as a starter plant, unfortunately. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Native to the tropical rainforests of Brazil, the Prayer Plant is loved for its variegated leaves with intricate vein patterns. You can easily spot a Prayer Plant by its leaf undersides as shades of deep red are revealed when the plant’s leaves curl up at night, bringing a splash of colour to your home.

There are several varieties of Prayer Plants that all look ever so slightly different. The most common is the tri-colour which has red-veined leaves but you’ll sometimes see varieties with silver patches or dark green splashes. Prayer Plants are a little fussy though with light conditions, soil moisture and humidity levels though so we don’t recommend this as a starter plant, unfortunately.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Native to the tropical rainforests of Central and South America, the Arrowhead is a fairly easy plant to take care of. Below you will find our complete Arrowhead care guide to help you look after your plant and spot any issues that may occur.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Arrowhead Plants</h2>
Although Arrowhead plant care can be quite easy, there are several common issues that happen if your plant isn't fully happy with its care or environment. It is important to spot the warning signs so you know how to help nurture your plant back to full health.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Arrowheads like bright, indirect light</h3>
Although Arrowhead Plants can survive in lower light areas of your home, it will thrive the most in bright, indirect sunlight. Make sure to keep it away from too much direct sunlight as over time this will burn its leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Let your Arrowhead dry out between waterings</h3>
Arrowhead plants don't like super dry soil, but they don't like their roots to be soggy either. So water it well but then let your plant dry out before watering again.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Arrowheads prefer warmer temperatures</h3>
Your Arrowhead plant will be happier in the warmer areas of your home. Make sure to keep it away from any drafty windows or doors as the cold air coming in from the outside will shock your plant and harm its growth potential.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise in Spring or Summer</h3>
The best time to fertilize your Arrowhead plant is in the growth months. Never fertilize in the winter as the growth will be minimal anyway.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the humidity high for your Arrowhead</h3>
Your Arrowhead plant will reward you if you increase the humidity levels, especially in the colder months where the heating will dry out the air in your home. You can find out how to increase the humidity in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Arrowhead plants are mildly toxic to pets and humans</h3>
Keep your Arrowhead plant away from small humans and pets who might likely eat some of the leaves. Ingestion can cause mild stomach and mouth irritation. Their sap can also cause mild skin irritation so we recommend wearing gloves when handling your Arrowhead.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>It couldn't be easier to propagate your Arrowhead.</h3>
Arrowhead plants can be quite quick growers and are really easy to propagate. Simply take a cutting that includes a node and place it in water. After a few weeks, roots should begin to show and your cutting will be ready to pot into soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellow leaves on your Arrowhead plant may be caused by overwatering. Whilst that is the most common issue, it is also worth looking into the light levels around your Arrowhead as too much direct light can cause yellow leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that your Arrowhead is drooping or looking limb, it is most often caused by underwatering or a lack of humidity. Increase the frequency of watering and mist the leaves every few days and the leaves should perk up.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pale leaves, similarly to yellow leaves, is an indication of too much direct sunlight. Try moving your plant to a shadier spot and removing any bleached leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are the tips on my Arrowhead turning brown? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dry, brown leaf tips on your Arrowhead plant is a signal of dry air. Luckily this is easy to fix by misting the leaves every few days to increase the humidity.]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Native to the tropical rainforests of Central and South America, the Arrowhead great plant to have in your collection. When fully grown, they can reach nearly 2 meters tall with large leaves that can have a variety of colours and variagations. \n\nAs you can imagine, the Arrowhead likes warm and humid environments. Letting the soil dry out between waterings is a great way to mimic their natural habitats and making sure they have bright, but indirect light, will stop the leaves from burning. \n\nWith them being a little more picky over humidity and placement, we wouldn’t always recommend them for a starter houseplant. They’re also mildly toxic to pets, which doesn’t make them the most friendly for households with cats or dogs.&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Native to the tropical rainforests of Central and South America, the Arrowhead great plant to have in your collection. When fully grown, they can reach nearly 2 meters tall with large leaves that can have a variety of colours and variegations.

As you can imagine, the Arrowhead likes warm and humid environments. Letting the soil dry out between waterings is a great way to mimic their natural habitats and making sure they have bright, but indirect light will stop the leaves from burning.

With them being a little pickier over humidity and placement, we wouldn’t always recommend them for a starter houseplant. They’re also mildly toxic to pets, which doesn’t make them the most friendly for households with cats or dogs.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Peace Lilies can handle many lighting conditions</h3>
Although they're native to brighter areas, the Peace lily can handle a wide variety of lighting conditions. They'll be happy in any spot, dim or bright. It's worth noting however that they'll only flower in brighter areas.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Watering your Peace Lily is easy</h3>
As they're not particular picky, you can water your Peace Lily relatively sparingly. It won't react badly if you miss a watering every so often. You can also just pop them in the shower once a week to clean the leaves off at the same time.]]></wp:meta_value>

Being native to the rainforest, they're very keen on high humidity. To make it easy you can simply mist the plant a couple of times a week, or even place it on a pebble bath. We have a great post all about raising the humidity for your plants available here.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate your Peace Lily through division of the mother plant ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Unfortunately, Peace Lilies cannot be propagated from a leaf or stem cutting. Instead, the best way to propagate a Peace Lily is through diving the mother plant into several smaller plants. Make sure each section has a good chunk of the root system and be careful when separating the roots as you don't want to cause too much damage.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;\nThere’s a reason that Peace Lilies are so popular, and it’s not just because of their incredible white flowers. They are super low maintenance plants that can adapt and thrive in most homes. They can tolerate all light levels which is super rare for houseplants. \n\nOur favourite thing about the Peace Lily is that it really helps us plant parents out by drooping its leaves when it really needs water. This can help you spot underwatering before it’s really a problem. Within minutes of watering, the leaves will perk up - it’s pretty cool! \n\nAnd if we haven’t sold you on the Peace Lily yet, then you should probably know that they are also one of the best plants at purifying the air and removing chemicals from your home! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">There’s a reason that Peace Lilies are so popular, and it’s not just because of their incredible white flowers. They are super low maintenance plants that can adapt and thrive in most homes. They can tolerate all light levels which is super rare for houseplants.

Our favourite thing about the Peace Lily is that it really helps us plant parents out by drooping its leaves when it really needs water. This can help you spot underwatering before it’s really a problem. Within minutes of watering, the leaves will perk up - it’s pretty cool! And if we haven’t sold you on the Peace Lily yet, then you should probably know that they are also one of the best plants at purifying the air and removing chemicals from your home!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic African Mask Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">With their unique and striking leaf patterns, African Mask Plants are not the easiest houseplant to care for. But don't let that put you off, as they are worth the extra hassle. Here you will find all the information you need to care for your African Mask Plant.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[A humid environment is the number one thing to look out for when caring for an African Mask Plant]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_pull_quote]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fc584bd3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for African Mask Plants</h2>
African Mask Plants can be a little bit tricky to take care of, so it is important that you know how to spot issues and problems.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>African Mask Plants will struggle in low-light</h3>
The ideal place for your African Mask Plant is a spot that gets nice natural bright but indirect light. They will struggle in darker areas of your home, as well as in direct sunlight so it is important you find the right balance.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't let the soil dry out</h3>
We recommend watering your African Mask Plant quite often, but not with a large volume of water. They don't want their soil to dry out, but they also don't want their roots to become waterlogged.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Humidity is vital for African Mask Plants</h3>
Dry air is the number 1 reason why houseplant lovers find it difficult to grow and care for an African Mask Plant. They require a humid environment as they are native to the tropics. There are several ways you can increase humidity levels for your African Mask Plant which we explain further in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">detailed guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Warm temperatures are vital</h3>
Similarly to the high humidity levels, African Mask Plants also prefer warmer temperatures. They will tolerate colder months over winter but you will see them struggle to produce any new growth at this time. Make sure to keep them away from drafty windows or air conditioning vents where they might experience cooler temperatures.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise African Mask Plants in growth months</h3>
It is very important that you only feed your African Mask Plant during Spring and Summer. We recommend fertilising them once a month during this time.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Avoid repotting in winter</h3>
Similarly to fertilisation, it's not a great idea to repot your African Mask Plant during colder months. The best time to repot would be in Spring as the growth period approaches so that the plant can get used to its new environment and shock will be easily overcome.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dust their leaves every so often</h3>
As with any houseplant with large flat leaves, African Mask Plants are prone to a build up of dust. Make sure to wipe the leaves down every few weeks.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>African Mask Plants are highly toxic to pets</h3>
The plant contains a chemical that if ingested by your pet, can cause stomach issues and vomiting. We recommend you keep your African Mask Plant away from your furry friends as well as children.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate African Mask Plants using division</h3>
As your African Mask Plant matures, you might want to think about propagating if the plant becomes too big for the space. Carefully take the roots out of the pot and separate the root systems with your fingers. Only use shears if absolutely necessary. You can then pot the new plant directly into the soil and continue usual care.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my African Mask Plant got yellow leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellowing leaves on an African Mask Plant is often caused by watering issues. This can be either over or underwatering so it is important to regularly check the moisture in the soil and adjust your watering schedule accordingly. You can pick up a moisture meter from Amazon <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">here</a> which will help you keep track of the moisture in the soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my African Mask Plant dying? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice your African Mask Plant looks as though it is dying, you need to act quickly to reverse this. It may be a mixture of issues that are causing this but we always recommend checking soil moisture first, as well as increasing humidity and checking it has enough sunlight.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my African Mask Plant drooping? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Drooping leaves is an indication that your African Mask Plant is suffering from water stress. This can be either over or underwatering so check the mositure levels in the soil using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> and adjust your watering schedule accordingly. If your soil is waterlogged we recommend replacing it entirely with <a href="/a/houseplant-soil">fresh high-quality potting mix.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my African Mask Plant got brown leaf tips? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown leaf tips is sometimes a difficult one to treat because it has several causes. It may be due to dry air, overfertilisation or overwatering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[African Mask Plants will struggle in low-light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The ideal place for your African Mask Plant is a spot that gets nice natural bright but indirect light. They will struggle in darker areas of your home, as well as in direct sunlight so it is important you find the right balance. If you aren't sure if your African Mask Plant is getting enough light, we recommend using a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light monitor. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Don't let the soil dry out]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend watering your African Mask Plant quite often, but not with a large volume of water. They don't want their soil to dry out, but they also don't want their roots to become waterlogged. We often use a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to help us know exactly when our plant needs water.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Humidity is vital for African Mask Plants]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dry air is the number 1 reason why houseplant lovers find it difficult to grow and care for an African Mask Plant. They require a humid environment as they are native to the tropics. There are several ways you can increase humidity levels for your African Mask Plant which we explain further in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">humidity guide</a>. The easiest way to increase humidity levels is by using a <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Warm temperatures are vital for African Mask Plants]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Similarly to the high humidity levels, African Mask Plants also prefer warmer temperatures. They will tolerate colder months over winter but you will see them struggle to produce any new growth at this time. Make sure to keep them away from drafty windows or air conditioning vents where they might experience cooler temperatures. A <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometer</a> is a great way to know for sure if your African Mask Plant is in the right spot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Only fertilise African Mask Plants in growth months]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is very important that you only feed your African Mask Plant during Spring and Summer. We recommend fertilising them once a month during this time during a <a href="/a/fertiliser-bottle">liquid fertiliser</a> at less than recommended strength.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Avoid repotting an African Mask Plant in winter]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Similarly to fertilisation, it's not a great idea to repot your African Mask Plant during colder months. The best time to repot would be in Spring as the growth period approaches so that the plant can get used to its new environment and shock will be easily overcome.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dust their leaves every so often]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As with any houseplant with large flat leaves, African Mask Plants are prone to a build up of dust. Make sure to wipe the leaves down every few weeks.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[African Mask Plants are highly toxic to pets]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Unfortunately, African Mask Plants are toxic to pets as the leaves contain a chemical that if ingested by your pet, can cause stomach issues and vomiting. We recommend you keep your African Mask Plant away from your furry friends as well as children.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate African Mask Plants using division]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As your African Mask Plant matures, you might want to think about propagating if the plant becomes too big for the space. Carefully take the roots out of the pot and separate the root systems with your fingers. Only use shears if absolutely necessary. You can then pot the new plant directly into the soil and continue usual care.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3821]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;If there is one plant that has risen up the popularity ranks recently, it’s the African Mask Plant! You can now buy these at basically every plant shop, market and superstore globally as they are definitely the most popular of the Alocasia family. And we totally understand why they have become so popular, their intense glossy shield like leaves are adorned with strong white veines which really make them something special. \n\nThey aren’t a great plant for beginners however, as they do require decent light levels, as well as warm tempertuares and a consistent high humidity level. Misting this plant is really crucial or it’ll start to develop some issues. \n\nIf in the right environment, your African Mask Plant can grow well above 1 metre but this will take many years as they don’t produce that many new leaves each year. This is why it’s crucial you take good care of the leaves your plant does have by regularly dusting and inspecting for issues. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">If there is one plant that has risen up the popularity ranks recently, it’s the African Mask Plant! You can now buy these at basically every plant shop, market and superstore globally as they are definitely the most popular of the Alocasia family. And we totally understand why they have become so popular, their intense glossy shield-like leaves are adorned with strong white veins which really make them something special.</span>

They aren’t a great plant for beginners, however, as they do require decent light levels, as well as warm temperatures and a consistent high humidity level. Misting this plant is really crucial or it’ll start to develop some issues.

If in the right environment, your African Mask Plant can grow well above 1 metre but this will take many years as they don’t produce that many new leaves each year. This is why it’s crucial you take good care of the leaves your plant does have by regularly dusting and inspecting for issues.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Problems for Dumb Cane Plants</h2>
Although Dumb Canes are relatively easy houseplants to take care of, they do come with their own set of problems. It is important that you spot the warning signs early so you can reverse any issues quickly. The most common problems with Dumb Cane plants are brown and curling leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
