		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Light requirement changes with the seasons</h3>
Dumb Cane plants like bright light during the winter months so that they can make the most out of the shorter days. However, over summer we suggest moving your plant a little further into the room so that the sunlight is indirect.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't let your Dumb Cane dry out</h3>
Dumb Cane plants like their soil to be slightly moist and won't be happy if kept dry for too long. Cut back your watering in winter though otherwise you risk overwatering.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dumb Cane like warm environments</h3>
This isn't a dealbreaker and Dumb Cane can certainly survive in slightly colder homes. But as a rule, they like to be in a slightly warmer environment so make sure they aren't sat next to any drafty windows or AC vents.]]></wp:meta_value>

Dumb Cane like to have good draining in their pot to allow for the water to flow through. A well-draining potting soil reduces the risk of root rot too so is quite an important one to remember.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Curling leaves on Dumb Cane Plants can have several different causes. It may be due to underwatering, over-fertilisation or temperature changes so check out its environment and adjust care accordingly. 		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Use a well-draining potting mix]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dumb Cane like to have good draining in their pot to allow for the water to flow through. A well-draining potting soil reduces the risk of root rot too so is quite an important one to remember.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend you do this with most houseplants as they need less that the amount stated on the bottle so if you do want to fertilise your Dumb Cane, make sure you use a diluted soluble fertiliser.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dumb Cane is toxic to pets and humans</h3>
One thing that is really important to note is that the sap of Dumb Cane plants is highly toxic. If ingested, it can cause temporary speech issues so make sure to keep it away from children and pets and wash your hands immediately after handling your Dumb Cane (or wear gloves!)

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;With incredible large speckles leaves, the Dumb Cane really does know how to impress! It has got a little bit of a bad reputation, however, as it’s very toxic to both humans and pets and can cause temporary loss of speech if consumed in large quantities (hence the name). However, this is quite rare and whilst important to keep in mind, shouldn’t put you off this plant entirely. \n\nDumb Cane plants are pretty forgiving and bounce back pretty quickly, so you don’t need to worry about occasionally over or underwatering. Just provide them with plenty of indirect sunshine and the occasional misting and they’ll reward you with some of the most beautiful foliage. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">With incredible large speckles leaves, the Dumb Cane really does know how to impress! It has got a little bit of a bad reputation, however, as it’s very toxic to both humans and pets and can cause temporary loss of speech if consumed in large quantities (hence the name). However, this is quite rare and whilst important to keep in mind, shouldn’t put you off this plant entirely.

Dumb Cane plants are pretty forgiving and bounce back pretty quickly, so you don’t need to worry about occasionally over or underwatering. Just provide them with plenty of indirect sunshine and the occasional misting and they’ll reward you with some of the most beautiful foliage.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Known for its evergreen trailing vines, English Ivy is a relatively easy houseplant to take care of. Below you will find our complete English Ivy care guide with all the information you need to help your ivy thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for English Ivy</h2>
English Ivy is quite an easy houseplant to take care of but that doesn't mean it won't come with a range of issues. The most common problems are caused by overwatering so it is important to check the moisture of the soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Avoid direct sunlight in summer</h3>
English Ivy like sunshine but also do well in medium to low light levels. In summer avoid putting your Ivy too close to the window as the intense direct light will harm the leaves. In winter it can deal with a little more direct light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>English Ivy like their soil to be moist</h3>
We recommend watering your English Ivy a little more regularly than some of your other houseplants as they don't like their soil to dry out. However, hold back on the volume of water as their roots will rot if the soil is waterlogged.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Occasionally mist if its really hot</h3>
Humidity levels are not a major thing to look out for when growing an English Ivy indoors. If you live in a hot climate, it might be good to mist your plant every other week or so during summer to add a little humidity.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't worry about fertilising</h3>
English Ivy don't require feeding and will thrive on their own. However, if you do want to feed it we recommend only doing it in spring with a soluble fertiliser at half the recommended strength.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Repot with new soil regularly</h3>
English Ivy really benefit from having their soil replaced every year or so. You don't necessarily need to repot into a bigger pot each time (only when you feel it is very root bound) but they can be spruced up by just refreshing their soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Pruning keeps an English Ivy bushy and healthy</h3>
Knowing when and how to prune an English Ivy is really important. We recommend trimming it back quite a lot every 3 years to stimulate new growth. In between, prune off the leggy vines quite far up and it will make your plant bushier and more compact.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your English Ivy using stem cuttings</h3>
You can very easily propagate your English Ivy by cutting off some of the vines and placing them in water. You want to make sure the vines are about 10cm+ so they have the best chance at growing roots. Switch out the water every few days to keep it fresh and repot into soil once roots have started to grow on the vine.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3888]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Although they are most commonly known as outdoor plants, you can very successfully grow an English Ivy indoors as long as you give it enough light. We are obsessed with the white variegated English Ivy but if not given enough sunshine, the new leaves will lose all of that variegation. \n\nIncluded in the NASA Clean Air Study, the English Ivy is great at removing toxins from the air so we recommend having this around your home. They are also believed to sometimes be able to improve allergy symptoms so as well as looking lush, they have great benefits for us too. \n\nThey are also super fast-growing plants so you want to place them on a high shelf making sure they have enough space to cascade downwards. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Although they are most commonly known as outdoor plants, you can very successfully grow an English Ivy indoors as long as you give it enough light. We are obsessed with the white variegated English Ivy but if not given enough sunshine, the new leaves will lose all of that variegation.

Included in the NASA Clean Air Study, the English Ivy is great at removing toxins from the air so we recommend having this around your home. They are also believed to sometimes be able to improve allergy symptoms so as well as looking lush, they have great benefits for us too. They are also super fast-growing plants so you want to place them on a high shelf making sure they have enough space to cascade downwards.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Problems for Nerve Plants</h2>
Nerve Plants are not the easiest houseplant to take care of, so you may well come into some problems over time. The most common issue is a lack of humidity in homes which causes dry crispy leaves and stems.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Direct light will quickly kill your Nerve Plant</h3>
One of the most important thing to know when caring for a Nerve Plant is to keep it away from any direct sunshine as it will cause leaf burn very quickly. Nerve Plants prefer a bright spot with indirect sunshine and can also grow well under fluorescent light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Try and keep the soil moist</h3>
Nerve Plants will struggle if their soil is too dry for prolonged periods of time so try and make sure you keep the soil moist. We recommend watering your Nerve Plant little but often to avoid any overwatering and root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Use a peat-moss base for the soil</h3>
Nerve Plants will grow well in a potting soil that allows some drainage, whilst also retaining some of that moisture. This will help with maintaining the right level of water in the soil so that the roots are not sat in stagnant water, but the plant never dries out either.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Nerve Plants will grow in a range of temperatures</h3>
You can relax a little when it comes to finding the right temperature for your Nerve Plant as they aren't as fussy as some other houseplants. We would still recommend you steer clear of really cold temperatures or drafty windows as they are native to the tropical rainforests.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>High humidity is vital for Nerve Plants</h3>
If we were to give you only one piece of advice for caring for a Nerve Plant, we would always say keep the humidity high. Nerve Plants are native to tropical rainforests so you want to mist your plant often and keep the humidity as high as you can for it to have the best chance at survival. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your houseplants in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">humidity guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertilise your Nerve Plant during the growth season</h3>
It is important to remember to only feed your Nerve Plant during the spring and summer months. We recommend using a fertiliser specifically for tropical plants and dilute it at half strength.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Nerve Plant using leaf cuttings</h3>
When taking a cutting to propagate your Nerve Plant, make sure it includes a node or two as this is where the new roots will pop out from. Propagate in Spring so that your new Nerve Plant cuttings have the best chance at maturing.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has Nerve Plant got yellow leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that your Nerve Plant is developing yellow leaves, this is most commonly caused by overwatering. Check the moisture in the soil and adjust your watering schedule accordingly. Make sure that you have good drainage holes so that the soil does not become waterlogged.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Crispy, dry leaves on your Nerve Plant will most probably be caused by a lack of humidity. As Nerve Plant are native to tropical rainforests, they may suffer in dry homes. You can find out more about increasing the humidity for your Nerve Plant <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">here</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Nerve Plant dropping leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If your Nerve Plant is dropping leaves, it may be due to cold temperatures. If your plant is next to drafty windows, doors or AC vents, the cold air may be stressing your plant out meaning it loses some of its leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Direct light will quickly kill your Nerve Plant]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One of the most important thing to know when taking care of a Nerve Plant is to keep it away from any direct sunshine as it will cause leaf burn very quickly. Nerve Plants prefer a bright spot with indirect sunshine and can also grow well under fluorescent light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Try and keep the soil moist]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Proper watering is super important for your Nerve Plant care routine as they will struggle if their soil is too dry for prolonged periods of time so try and make sure you keep the soil moist. We recommend watering your Nerve Plant little but often to avoid any overwatering and root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Nerve Plants will grow well in a potting soil that allows some drainage, whilst also retaining some of that moisture. This will help with maintaining the right level of water in the soil so that the roots are not sat in stagnant water, but the plant never dries out either.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[You can relax a little when it comes to finding the right temperature for your Nerve Plant as they aren't as fussy as some other houseplants. We would still recommend you steer clear of really cold temperatures or drafty windows as they are native to the tropical rainforests.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If we were to give you only one piece of advice for caring for a Nerve Plant, we would always say keep the humidity high. Nerve Plants are native to tropical rainforests so you want to mist your plant often and keep the humidity as high as you can for it to have the best chance at survival. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your houseplants in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">humidity guide.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;With delicate leaves, Nerve Plants are low-growing spreader plants that aren't always the easiest to care for. The most popular and common variety is silver and green veined, though you’ll also often spot varieties with white, pink or red veins and leaves too! \n\nThey have quite specific care requirements though so we don’t tend to recommend them to beginner plant parents as they are quite fussy about balancing the level of light, water, humidity and temperature. If there is one tip we can give you it would be to mist your plant at every opportunity you have to prevent them from drying out. But if you can get the care routine nailed down, then they are totally worth the extra hassle! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">With delicate leaves, Nerve Plants are low-growing spreader plants that aren't always the easiest to care for. The most popular and common variety is silver and green-veined, though you’ll also often spot varieties with white, pink or red veins and leaves too!

They have quite specific care requirements though so we don’t tend to recommend them to beginner plant parents as they are quite fussy about balancing the level of light, water, humidity and temperature. If there is one tip we can give you it would be to mist your plant at every opportunity you have to prevent them from drying out. But if you can get the care routine nailed down, then they are totally worth the extra hassle!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Wandering Jew Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Wandering Jew Plants are one of our favourite houseplants to take care of as they seem to grow bigger and wilder every day. Below you will find all the information you need to properly care for your Wandering Jew Plant.</p>
&nbsp;
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9"></p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Problems for Wandering Jew Plants</h2>
Wandering Jew Plants are fairly easy plants to take care of, and we hope that with our care guide you have been able to look after your plant well. However, it can always occur that your plant starts to show signs of stress and unhappiness so it is important to know what the warning signs look like.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Bright, indirect light is ideal</h3>
Wandering Jew Plants will struggle to thrive in darker areas of your home so make sure to find it a nice bright spot. However, if your plant receives direct sunlight it can fade the leaves which is irreversible. So you want to find a nice light balance.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Be careful not to overwater it</h3>
Wandering Jew Plants don't like their soil to be too dry, or waterlogged so again you want to find a balance between the two. We recommend watering your plant little and often so that the soil retains some moisture but not enough to cause issues such as root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Adjust your watering throughout the year</h3>
You want to make sure that you are watering your Wandering Jew Plant less in the colder, winter months as growth will slow and the demand for water will be less. Watering in winter can often lead to root rot so check the moisture in the soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Temperature isn't an issue for Wandering Jew Plants</h3>
A great thing about Wandering Jew Plants is that they aren't too fussy about the temperature and will grow well in your home regardless. They do tend to prefer slightly cooler temperatures but are happy with warm environments too.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't fertilise your Wandering Jew Plant</h3>
They just don't need it and will thrive completely on their own. If you do decide that you want to fertilise your Wandering Jew Plant, just make sure it is at half strength as overfertilisation will cause the leaves to lose their colour and pattern.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Repot only when root-bound</h3>
It is not super necessary to constantly be repotting your Wandering Jew Plant, as they won't suffer too much if they are a little pot-bound. But when you do decide to repot, make sure the new pot isn't more than a few centimetres larger in diameter than the last one otherwise this may your plant to become stressed.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagating a Wandering Jew Plant is easy!</h3>
It really couldn't be simpler to propagate a Wandering Jew Plant. All you need to do is take a stem cutting and pop it in some water. Change out the water every few days to keep it fresh and after a few weeks you should see roots start to appear. At this point your cutting is ready to be pot into soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Dead parts of the plant are also sometimes caused by natural ageing, which unfortunately is going to happen no matter your care. We recommend taking cuttings of the healthy parts and pruning away the dead leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If the new growth on your Wandering Jew Plant is becoming quite leggy and doesn't have many leaves on it, it may be caused by either a lack of humidity and moisture in the soil, or by a lack of sunlight. It is quite common for this to happen over winter.

We recommend cutting off the leggy growth and adjusting the environment or your care routine and this should encourage new healthy growth to develop.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Also known as the Inch Plant, we haven’t yet come across a faster-growing or easier to propagate houseplant. Native to the tropics of Mexico and South America, these plants offer something different with their purple and silvery leaves that transcend out of the pot. \n\nGrowing these indoors helps keep their growth more contained whilst still giving that wilderness feel which we love. Caring for these plants is also super easy as all they need is ample light and moderate water. They are quite forgiving though so won’t give up straight away if something’s a little off.\n\nThese plants are great for hanging planters or when placed on shelving so you can really make the most of those incredible vines. They can be mildly toxic though so you’ll want to keep them away from pets. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Also known as the Inch Plant, we haven’t yet come across a faster-growing or easier to propagate houseplant. Native to the tropics of Mexico and South America, these plants offer something different with their purple and silvery leaves that transcend out of the pot.

Growing these indoors helps keep their growth more contained whilst still giving that wilderness feel which we love. Caring for these plants is also super easy as all they need is ample light and moderate water. They are quite forgiving though so won’t give up straight away if something’s a little off.

These plants are great for hanging planters or when placed on shelving so you can really make the most of those incredible vines. They can be mildly toxic though so you’ll want to keep them away from pets.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Bird of Paradise Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">The Bird of Paradise is a fantastic, tall and glossy houseplant that gives a real tropical feel to your space. On top of all of this, they're also pretty simple to care for and can take a good variety of conditions without issues.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Common Issues for Bird of Paradise</h2>
Although Bird of Paradise care can be quite easy, there are several common issues that happen if your plant isn’t fully happy with its care or environment. It is important to spot the warning signs so you know how to help nurture your plant back to full health.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Bird of Paradise Love Humidity</h3>
Being native to the coasts of South Africa, these plants will thrive in more humid environments. To make it easy you can simply mist the plant a couple of times a week, or even place it on a pebble bath. We have a great post all about raising the humidity for your plants available here.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Ideal Light Conditions</h3>
Your Bird of Paradise will need a good amount of bright sunlight. Keeping one in a spot with more indirect light won't necessarily harm the plant, but it will most likely prevent it from blooming.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Temperature Levels</h3>
Any normal home temperature will be fine for your Bird of Paradise, however they will grow the most when it's slightly warmer. It's worth noting that their development will likely grind to a halt over the colder months.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Feeding Your Bird of Paradise</h3>
During the warmer months you're going to see much more growth. As such it's a good idea to feed with a simple liquid plant fertiliser once every four weeks during spring and summer.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Watering Correctly</h3>
Bird of Paradise prefer a little and often way of watering, this keeps the soil moist but never wet and soggy. They can be prone to root rot so it's important that you get the drainage right, make sure your pot isn't holding in any excess moisture.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Bird of Paradise are poisonous to pets</h3>
Watch out if you have have a cat or dog around! Pets that ingest the leaves can develop digestive issues and struggle with breathing, so give this one a miss if you have a pet in the house.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Bird of Paradise have splits in its leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[This is very common with Bird of Paradise and actually doesn't mean anything is wrong at all. They develop these splits in the wild to make them more resistant to the wind.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why won't my Bird of Paradise flower?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It's very rare to get the Bird of Paradise to flower or bloom indoors. If you have a brighter spot in your home that you could move the plant into, this would give it the best shot at blooming.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

As with any houseplant with large flat leaves, Bird of Paradise are prone to a build up of dust. Make sure to wipe the leaves down every few weeks or pop them in the shower for their next watering]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Bird of Paradise prefer a little and often way of watering, this keeps the soil moist but never wet and soggy. They can be prone to root rot so it's important that you get the drainage right, make sure your pot isn't holding in any excess moisture.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;If you’re dreaming of a tropical getaway, then a Bird of Paradise is the next best thing. Native to South Africa, they are loved for their incredible orange and blue leaves that resemble birds (which explains the name). It’s really important that you keep your pets away from the flowers and leaves as they can be very toxic if ingested so we don’t really recommend this one to pet parents, unfortunately. \n\nIt’s also important that you have a lot of space when buying a Bird of Paradise plant as they do grow up to about 2 metres in size. But if you have the space for it, then they are the perfect plant for those looking for something a little more exotic. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">If you’re dreaming of a tropical getaway, then a Bird of Paradise is the next best thing. Native to South Africa, they are loved for their incredible orange and blue leaves that resemble birds (which explains the name). It’s really important that you keep your pets away from the flowers and leaves as they can be very toxic if ingested so we don’t really recommend this one to pet parents, unfortunately.

It’s also important that you have a lot of space when buying a Bird of Paradise plant as they do grow up to about 2 metres in size. But if you have the space for it, then they are the perfect plant for those looking for something a little more exotic.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Elephant Ear Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Known for their larger than life, heart-shaped leaves, Elephant Ear Plants are the new popular houseplant, and they're super easy to care for! Our Elephant Ear Plant care guide has all the information you need to help your plant thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Elephant Ear Plants</h2>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Elephant Ears need bright sunshine</h3>
But make sure you keep it away from direct sunlight as this can cause leaf burn which unfortunately is irreversible. You might want to consider moving your plant a little closer to the window during winter to make use of all the sunlight.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the soil moist</h3>
One really important thing to remember when caring for an Elephant Ear Plant is to keep the soil moist. You want to make sure that the soil doesn't stay too dry in between waterings so keep a close eye on it and regularly check the moisture levels.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They prefer warmer temperatures</h3>
Although they will still grow and survive in slightly colder homes, a warmer environment will really help them thrive. Don't be alarmed if there is no growth in the winter period, they are just adjusting to the temperature change.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Elephant Ear Plants love humid environments</h3>
As Elephant Ear Plants are native to the tropics, it is important for you to try and replicate some of that environment in your home. An easy way to do this is by increasing the humidity. You can find out more about this in our detailed <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide to humidity</a>.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only use fertiliser in Spring</h3>
This goes for most other houseplants too as this is when the growth period occurs. We also recommend using a water-soluble fertiliser so that it is not as harsh on the root system.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Elephant Ear Plants are toxic to pets</h3>
If ingested by your dog or cat, it can cause mouth and stomach irritation so try and keep your furry friends away from the plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Rotate the plant to keep it balanced</h3>
You may find that over time your Elephant Ear Plant leans in towards the source of light. In order to keep the new growth equal and the plant balance, rotate your Elephant Ear Plant every month or so.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>You can't propagate a Elephant Ear Plant with stem cuttings</h3>
Unfortunately, propagating your Elephant Ear Plant isn't the easiest. You can propagate your plant by dividing and repotting the runners into new individual plants.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dusting the leaves is important</h3>
Due to the size of Elephant Ear leaves, they are prone to a large build-up of dust which can affect the plant's health which is why we recommend wiping them down with a damp cloth every few weeks.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there yellow leaves on my Elephant Ear Plant?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellow leaves on an Elephant Ear Plant can often be caused by watering issues. Check the moisture of the soil to see whether your plant is receiving too much or too little water. Also make sure there are sufficient drainage holes in the pot to avoid root rot. This <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter from Amazon</a> is a great way to keep track of the moisture levels in the soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If the leaves on your Elephant Ear Plant are drooping, this will likely be caused by underwatering. Start by giving your plant a shower and letting the excess water run off. Then  slowly increase the frequency and volume of water and the leaves should return to normal soon.]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is totally normal for your Elephant Ear Plant to occasionally lose a leaf, this is just part of the natural ageing process. However, if the rate of lead loss increases, check the moisture levels in the soil to check if your plant needs more or less water.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there dark brown spots on my Elephant Ear Plant's leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown patches or spots on the leaves is often a sign of overwatering. We recommend replacing the soil immediately with a <a href="/a/houseplant-soil">high-quality potting mix</a> and removing any roots that have rotted. Then adjust your watering schedule so the plant has time to dry out slightly between waterings.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Prune the odd leaf as your plant ages</h3>
Over time, as your plant matures, we recommend pruning the older leaves that might be beginning to droop a little. Make sure you use clean, sharp shears to remove the leaf.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_10_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>You don't need to repot your Elephant Ear Plant often</h3>
Don't worry about needing to find a new pot for your Elephant Ear Plant all the time. You only really need to repot them when you start to see roots coming out at the bottom or top of your plant. When it is time to repot your Elephant Ear Plant, make sure you do it in spring or summer to coincide with the growing season.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_10_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Elephant Ear plants need bright sunshine]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[But make sure you keep your Elephant Ear plant away from direct sunlight as this can cause leaf burn which unfortunately is irreversible. You might want to consider moving your plant a little closer to the window during winter to make use of all the sunlight. If you aren't sure if your plant is getting enough light, you can use a <a href="/a/light-monitor">sunlight monitor</a> to test different spots in your home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Keep the soil moist]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One really important thing to remember when taking care of an Elephant Ear Plant is to keep the soil moist. You want to make sure that the soil doesn't stay too dry in between waterings so keep a close eye on it and regularly check the moisture levels using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They prefer warmer temperatures]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although they will still grow and survive in slightly colder homes, a warmer environment will really help your Elephant Ear plant thrive. Don't be alarmed if there is no growth in the winter period, they are just adjusting to the temperature change.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Elephant Ear Plants love humid environments]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As Elephant Ear Plants are native to the tropics, one important part of your care routine is to try and replicate some of that natural environment in your home. An easy way to do this is by increasing the humidity. We recommend this <a href="/a/humidifier">affordable humidifier available from Amazon</a>. You can find out more about this in our detailed <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">guide to humidity</a>.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Only fertilise your Elephant Ear plant in Spring]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[This goes for most other houseplants too as this is when the growth period occurs. We also recommend using a water-soluble fertiliser like <a href="/a/fertiliser-bottle">this one from Miracle Gro</a> so that it is not as harsh on the root system.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

You only really need to repot them when you start to see roots coming out at the bottom or top of your plant. When it is time to repot your Elephant Ear Plant, make sure you do it in spring or summer to coincide with the growing season.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Known and loved for their larger than life, heart-shaped leaves, Elephant Ear Plants are the new popular houseplant on the block! Whilst they are most commonly grown outdoors, this doesn’t mean they can’t adapt nicely to your home. With enough light, a little boost to the humidity and good moisture in the soil, your Elephant Ear Plant could soon be boasting leaves that are nearly a meter in length!\n\nIt will require a little bit of work though to keep your Elephant Ear Plant thriving, from daily misting, to regularly dusting the leaves as the sheer size of them make them a dust magnet, it’s important to tend to an Elephant Ear Plant to keep it happy and healthy. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Known and loved for their larger than life, heart-shaped leaves, Elephant Ear Plants are the new popular houseplant on the block! Whilst they are most commonly grown outdoors, this doesn’t mean they can’t adapt nicely to your home. With enough light, a little boost to the humidity and good moisture in the soil, your Elephant Ear Plant could soon be boasting leaves that are nearly a meter in length!

It will require a little bit of work though to keep your Elephant Ear Plant thriving, from daily misting, to regularly dusting the leaves as the sheer size of them make them a dust magnet, it’s important to tend to an Elephant Ear Plant to keep it happy and healthy.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<div class="container narrower aos-init aos-animate" data-aos="fade-up" data-aos-duration="1500">
<h2>Basic Cast Iron Plant Care</h2>
The Cast Iron Plant is a fantastic, glossy houseplant that gives a real tropical feel to your space. On top of all of this, they’re also pretty simple to care for and can take a good variety of conditions without issues.

</div>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They're super easy to keep</h3>
The great thing about Cast Iron Plants is that it's one of the easiest plants to keep. They can deal with a huge range of environments with no issues.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Cast Iron Plant lighting needs</h3>
The Aspidistra is one of the least fussy houseplants when it comes to lighting conditions. They're more than happy with a shady spot, just keep them out of bright direct light.]]></wp:meta_value>

To make sure that the leaves stay lush and healthy, make sure to keep the humidity a little higher. To make it easy just spray the leaves down with a misting bottle every few days.]]></wp:meta_value>

As with lighting requirements, the Aspidistra is really not fussy. Make sure that your pot isn't holding in excess moisture to avoid root rot, but don't worry about missing the odd watering.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Cast Iron Plant have yellow leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The most common cause of yellow leaves on Cast Iron Plants is overwatering. Check the moisture levels in the soil to confirm the issue and replace if waterlogged. Going forward you will want to cut back on how much you are watering your Cast Iron Plant to prevent the issue happening again.

Another potential cause is too much direct sunlight scorching the leaves. In this cause simply move your plant to a less sunny spot and remove the worst affected leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f67396379d03]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Cast Iron Plant have brown leaf tips?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Bronw leaf tups are caused by a few factors so go through eliminating each one to find the cause. Firstly it can be caused by underwatering which dries out the leaves. Secondly, it can be caused by a lack of humidity so try misting your plant or investing in a humidifier.

If those two issues are not solving the problem then it may be that your Cast Iron Plant is reacting to the high levels of fluoride in the tap water so use rainwater or distilled water in future.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f67396379d03]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there spots on my Cast Iron Plant's leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Spots and speckles on your Cast Iron Plant are often caused by spider mites. These are little pests that suck on your plant's leaves and will eventually kill your plant if not dealt with. Start by isolating your plant to stop the infestation spreading to other plants and then treat with an insecticide.

It can happen that you are not able to curb the spider mite infestation at which point it is sometimes best to say goodbye to your plant so you don't risk infecting any of your other beloved houseplants. It can be tough (we have been there) but it has to be done sometimes.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;The Cast Iron Plant is a fantastic, glossy houseplant that gives a real tropical feel to your space. On top of all of this, they’re also pretty simple to care for and can take a good variety of conditions without issues. This hardiness is where they got their name from, because they are just that tough.\n\nCast Iron Plants are perfect for areas that don’t have quite as much light, and will happily continue to grow in a shady spot. If you provide a little extra humidity, using something like a spray bottle of humidifier, you can expect your Cast Iron Plant to really thrive. \n\nWe definitely recommend these are a starter or beginner houseplant due to their ease of maintenance, but don’t be disheartened by the fact that they do grow quite slowly.&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">The Cast Iron Plant is a fantastic, glossy houseplant that gives a real tropical feel to your space. On top of all of this, they’re also pretty simple to care for and can take a good variety of conditions without issues. This hardiness is where they got their name from, because they are just that tough.

Cast Iron Plants are perfect for areas that don’t have quite as much light, and will happily continue to grow in a shady spot. If you provide a little extra humidity, using something like a spray bottle or humidifier, you can expect your Cast Iron Plant to really thrive.

We definitely recommend these as a starter or beginner houseplant due to their ease of maintenance, but don’t be disheartened by the fact that they do grow quite slowly.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_intro_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Zebra Cactus Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Named after their white striped leaves, Zebra cacti are very easy for care for. They pretty much thrive from being forgotten about. Here you will find all the information you need to properly care for a Zebra Cactus.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for a Zebra Cactus</h2>
Although it is thought that Zebra Cactus plants are very easy to take care of, this doesn't mean they won't come with their own heap of problems. It is important to know the warning signs so you can act quickly if something doesn't seem right.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They like bright, indirect light</h3>
Your Zebra Cactus loves the sunlight as they are from the succulent family. However, it is important that you do not place your Zebra Cactus in direct sun as this will scorch the leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Adjust your watering according to the season</h3>
Your Zebra Cactus won't need watering very much over the winter months, every two months will suffice. In the warmer, summer months make sure your Zebra Cactus has fully dried out in between watering otherwise this will quickly lead to root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Never let the crown get wet</h3>
It is important that when you water a Zebra Cactus, you don't let the rosetta / crown get wet as this will encourage the plant to rot, especially in slightly cooler temperatures where the water will not soak through or evaporate.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't worry about humidity levels</h3>
Luckily, your Zebra Cactus isn't fussy about humidity levels. They do, however, like fresh air so make sure you ventilate the room by opening the windows regularly or using a fan.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise your Zebra Cactus in summer</h3>
Use cactus fertiliser to feed your plant once a month during the growth period of spring and summer. You don't need to fertilise in winter as the plant goes into a dormant period.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate a Zebra Cactus using its offshoots</h3>
It is very easy to propagate a Zebra Cactus as they start to produce little offshoots as the mother plant matures. Carefully slice off one of the plantlets, keeping some of the roots attached and place in water for a few weeks. Once the root system has matured slightly more, your plant is ready to be repot into soil.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pale white or yellow leaves on a Zebra Cactus indicate that it has been sat in too much direct sunlight and the leaves have burnt. Remove the affected areas of the plant and place it further inside the room, away from any direct sun.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Use cactus fertiliser to feed your plant once a month during the growth period of spring and summer. You don't need to fertilise in winter as the plant goes into a dormant period.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[When caring for a Zebra Cactus, it is important that you place them in a warm spot in your home. They will struggle with anything below 15 degrees celcius so make sure they aren't placed next to any drafty doors or windows.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is very easy to propagate a Zebra Cactus as they start to produce little offshoots as the mother plant matures. Carefully slice off one of the plantlets, keeping some of the roots attached and place in water for a few weeks. Once the root system has matured slightly more, your plant is ready to be repot into soil.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Named after their white striped leaves, Zebra Cacti are super easy to care for and pretty much thrive from being forgotten about. Native to South Africa, this small succulent needs a good amount of sunshine and warmth to thrive but humidity is something you really don’t need to worry about with these plants. As with a lot of other succulents, water your Zebra Cactus sparingly as they are quite sensitive to overwatering and leaf rot. \n\nWith the right care and environment, you should expect to see your Zebra Cactus bloom but don’t get too excited as the flowers can be quite underwhelming. But to make up for it, these plants are non-toxic so safe for children and pets that might be tempted to nibble on the leaves. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Named after their white striped leaves, Zebra Cacti are super easy to care for and pretty much thrive from being forgotten about. Native to South Africa, this small succulent needs a good amount of sunshine and warmth to thrive but humidity is something you really don’t need to worry about with these plants. As with a lot of other succulents, water your Zebra Cactus sparingly as they are quite sensitive to overwatering and leaf rot.

With the right care and environment, you should expect to see your Zebra Cactus bloom but don’t get too excited as the flowers can be quite underwhelming. But to make up for it, these plants are non-toxic so safe for children and pets that might be tempted to nibble on the leaves.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Fishbone Cactus Care</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Fishbone cacti are quite easy to take care of and reward you with fast growth. They are also super easy to propagate making them a great gift for friends and family. Below you will find all the information you need to care for your Fishbone Cactus.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for a Fishbone Cactus</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Here are some common issues that you might run into. It's important to diagnose any issues early to give your plant the best chance of bouncing back.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They love the sunshine</h3>
Although your Fishbone Cactus prefers bright, indirect light, they can cope well with periods of direct sunshine but try to keep that a little limited. If they get the right level of sunlight over the year, they will reward you by flowering so it is definitely worth keeping an eye on those sunlight levels.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They need a little more water than other cacti</h3>
Fishbone Cacti are native to more tropical climates, rather than the desert so it is best to water it slightly more than your other cacti types. Make sure their soil is able to dry out between waterings as Fishbone Cactus plants don't like to be sat in water too much.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They prefer warmer temperatures</h3>
Although your Fishbone Cactus will prefer slightly warmer temperatures, they won't die on you immediately if the temperatures drops a little so don't worry about it too much.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>High humidity is important for a Fishbone Cactus</h3>
They thrive in humid environments so are best placed in the bathroom or kitchen where humidity levels are natural higher due to showering and cooking. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your plants in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Feeding is not a necessity</h3>
We wouldn't worry too much about fertilising your Fishbone Cactus but if you do want to, we recommend using a water-soluble fertiliser at half strength so that it doesn't cause too much harm to the roots.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Look out for signs you need to repot</h3>
Every year or so, it may be time to repot your Fishbone Cactus as it can become unstable and stressed if root bound for too long. Make sure to handle the plant carefully when repotting to avoid any damage to the root system or leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagating your Fishbone Cactus is easy!</h3>
If you want to propagate a Fishbone Cactus, you can do this by taking a leaf cutting. Try to take a cutting of about 10cm to give it the best chance at producing roots. Leave the cutting in a dry place for a few weeks for it to harden at the base before potting directly into soil.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
