		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my Fishbone Cactus turned very dry? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you notice the leaves on your Fishbone Cactus are starting to become quite dry and cripsy, it is probably due to underwatering. Although this plant is a cactus type, it actually requires more water than others. Your first instinct may be to drown your plant to overcompensate for the lack of water but this can actually shock your plant and cause more damage. Instead, slowly reintroduce watering for your Fishbone Cactus over a week or two and it should rectify the issue. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">In future, we recommend using a moisture meter to make sure that you don’t leave it too long between waterings. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Cut away the burnt leaves and place your plant in a shadier spot. Fishbone Cacti adapt well to medium light levels due to their flat leaves. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

Wipe the leaves clean with a damp cloth and treat with an insecticide. Fishbone Cacti plants are quite resistant to pests unless their care or environment isn’t ideal so make sure that you are following the care guide above to prevent another infestation. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They love the sunshine]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Fishbone Cacti adapt well to a mix of light levels and can easily thrive in bright, indirect sunshine as well as medium light too. Their flat leaves mean they have adapted to soak in as much sunlight as possible so are a great choice for most plant parents. They can deal with some direct sunshine but burn easily so be cautious. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If they get the right level of sunlight over the year, your Fishbone Cactus will reward you by flowering so it is definitely worth keeping an eye on those light levels.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They need a little more water than other cacti]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Fishbone Cacti are native to more tropical climates, rather than the desert so it is best to water it slightly more than your other cacti types. Make sure their soil is able to dry out between waterings as Fishbone Cactus plants don’t like to be sat in water too much. Adjust your watering schedule throughout the year so that the potting mix isn’t too soggy during autumn and winter. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Fishbone Cacti prefer warmer temperatures]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Although your Fishbone Cactus will prefer slightly warmer temperatures, they won’t die on you immediately if the temperatures drops a little so don’t worry about it too much. Avoid placing too close to cold drafts as this will over time damage the health of your Fishbone Cactus. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

You can find out more in our humidity </span><a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">guide</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">We wouldn’t worry too much about fertilising your Fishbone Cactus but if you do want to, we recommend using a water-soluble fertiliser at half strength so that it doesn’t cause too much harm to the roots. Fertilising too much can cause stunted growth, yellow leaves and a whole load of other problems. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Look out for signs you need to repot your Fishbone Cactus]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Every year or so, it may be time to repot your Fishbone Cactus as it can become unstable and stressed if root bound for too long. Make sure to handle the plant carefully when repotting to avoid any damage to the root system or leaves. Check to see if the roots are popping out from the top of bottom of the pot as this is a telltale sign that you need to repot your Fishbone Cactus. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagating your Fishbone Cactus couldn’t be easier! ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you want to propagate your Fishbone Cactus, you can do this by taking a leaf cutting. Try to take a cutting of about 10cm to give it the best chance at producing roots. Leave the cutting in a dry place for a few weeks for it to harden at the base before potting directly into soil. You might choose to use rooting powder to encourage new roots to grow but it’s up to you! </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Another great thing about Fishbone Cacti is that they are completely non-toxic for dogs and cats so you don’t need to worry about it being near your beloved furry friends. Although they don’t have super sharp spikes like a lot of other cacti, Fishbone Cacti do have small spines that can cause irritation so wear gloves when handling. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_604387a5b7bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3 class="h2" style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">About the Fishbone Cactus</span></h3>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Also known as the Zig Zag plant, the Fishbone Cactus is a low-maintenance and easy to propagate houseplant. Their flat leaves mean that they can adapt well to spots in your home with medium light levels making them a perfect plant for every plant parent! Although they are called a cactus, Fishbone Cacti actually need more light than most other cacti so make sure you aren’t leaving it too long between waterings. </span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Fishbone Cacti are quite quick growers and you’ll soon enough see lots of new leaves popping out. Because of this, it also means that you’ll need to regularly repot your Fishbone Cactus into a new planter. Make sure to pick one only a few cm wider in diameter otherwise, this can cause your plant to become unstable. </span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Another great thing about the Fishbone Cactus is that it’s one of the easiest plants to propagate. Just take a leaf cutting and pop it in fresh potting soil and it’ll grow roots - yes it’s as easy as that! </span></p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">It can happen that you Fishbone Cactus grows a few flowers during spring and summer if the conditions are right. They need a little extra sun during summer and a touch of fertiliser to help it along the way. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[You need a well-draining potting mix ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">To help your Fishbone Cactus thrive, you need to make sure you are using a well-draining potting mix. This will help avoid problems caused by overwatering and waterlogged soil. Perlite is the main component that is needed for Fishbone Cacti. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Their flat zig-zag leaves make the Fishbone Cactus something really special. And they aren’t even super difficult to care for which is a bonus. It’s important to note that the Fishbone Cactus is actually native to the jungles of Mexico rather than a desert. This means the care is slightly different to what you’d expect when you hear the word Cactus. They need a little bit more water and can only deal with some direct sunshine each day. \n\nYou’ll be pleased to hear that they are also really easy to propagate and are non-toxic too! The only downside is that they can be a little bit difficult to find but we hope as they continue to grow in popularity that they’ll soon be in every plant shop across the world. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Their flat zig-zag leaves make the Fishbone Cactus something really special. And they aren’t even super difficult to care for which is a bonus. It’s important to note that the Fishbone Cactus is actually native to the jungles of Mexico rather than a desert. This means the care is slightly different to what you’d expect when you hear the word Cactus. They need a little bit more water and can only deal with some direct sunshine each day.

You’ll be pleased to hear that they are also really easy to propagate and are non-toxic too! The only downside is that they can be a little bit difficult to find but we hope as they continue to grow in popularity that they’ll soon be in every plant shop across the world.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

It is important to know the warning signs that your plant might not be super happy with its environment or care. The quicker you react to a potential problem, the more chance your plant has to quickly return to full health.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They can deal with a range of light conditions</h3>
Monkey Mask Plants can survive in anything other than direct sunlight as this will scorch their leaves over time. It is also good to know that plant growth will slow in low light conditions.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Monkey Mask Plants like frequent watering</h3>
But make sure that you allow enough time for the soil to dry out between waterings as this will over time cause root rot. We recommend watering once a week in the growth months and fortnightly over winter.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They aren't fussy about temperature</h3>
Luckily for us Monkey Mask owners, they are not too fussed about temperatures. As long as your home doesn't reach below 10ºC for extended periods of time, you should be fine.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>High humidity is vital for a Monkey Mask Plant</h3>
It is important that you regularly mist the leaves of your Monkey Mask Plant to increase the humidity levels. They also grow really well in bathrooms and kitchens due to the increased levels of steam from showering and cooking.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Monkey Mask Plants are toxic to humans and pets</h3>
Unfortunately, Monkey Mask Plant are mildly toxic if ingested or if they come into contact with your eyes so it is really important that you keep the plant away from pets and small humans that might try and eat parts of the leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise in the growth period</h3>
As with most other houseplants, you should only be feeding your Monkey Mask Plant in spring and summer as they will go through a more dormant growing period in the colder months. We recommend using a fertiliser at half strength so not to damage the root system.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dusting the leaves is super important</h3>
Monkey Mask Plants are prone to a build up of dust on their leaves, which not only stops the light getting to the plant, but also makes the leaves look a little dull. We recommend carefully wiping the leaves down with a damp cloth every month or two to keep the leaves looking and feeling fresh.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my Monkey Mask Plant developed yellow leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellow leaves on your Monkey Mask Plant indicate that the plant has either received too much light (most probably direct sunlight) or the soil is waterlogged due to overwatering. Use a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter</a> or a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to determine if the environment is right.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my Monkey Mask Plant developed brown leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown leaves on a Monkey Mask Plant often indicates a lack of humidity. The best way to raise the humidity is through misting, or using a <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier. </a>You can learn more about how to raise the humidity for your houseplants in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">humidity guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They can deal with a range of light conditions]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One thing that makes Monkey Mask Monstera care quite easy is that they can survive in anything a range of light conditions. You want to make sure to stay away from intense direct light as this will scorch their leaves over time. It is also good to know that plant growth will slow in low light conditions.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Monkey Mask Plants like frequent watering]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Make sure that you allow enough time for the soil to dry out between waterings as this will over time cause root rot. We recommend watering your Monkey Mask Monstera once a week in the growth months and fortnightly over winter. Use a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to determine when to water your Monkey Mask Monstera.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Monkey Mask Monsteras aren't fussy about temperature]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Luckily for us Monkey Mask owners, they are not too fussed about temperatures. As long as your home doesn't reach below 10ºC for extended periods of time, you should be fine. If you want to be extra sure, use a <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometer</a> to keep your plant away from drafts or extreme hotspots.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[High humidity is vital for a Monkey Mask Plant]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is important that you regularly mist the leaves of your Monkey Mask Plant to increase the humidity levels. You can either do this by using <a href="/a/spray-bottles">spray bottles,</a> or by investing in a<a href="/a/premium-humidifier"> humidifier</a>. They also grow really well in bathrooms and kitchens due to the increased levels of steam from showering and cooking.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Monkey Mask Plants are toxic to humans and pets]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Unfortunately, Monkey Mask Plant are mildly toxic if ingested or if they come into contact with your eyes so it is really important that you keep the plant away from pets and small humans that might try and eat parts of the leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Only fertilise in the growth period]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As with most other houseplants, you should only be feeding your Monkey Mask Plant in spring and summer as they will go through a more dormant growing period in the colder months. We recommend using a fertiliser at half strength so not to damage the root system. This <a href="/a/fertiliser-bottle">liquid feed</a> is our favourite and is suitable for most houseplants.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dusting the leaves is super important]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Monkey Mask Plants are prone to a build up of dust on their leaves, which not only stops the light getting to the plant, but also makes the leaves look a little dull. We recommend carefully wiping the leaves down with a damp cloth every month or two to keep the leaves looking and feeling fresh.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;A close relative to the infamous Swiss Cheese Plant, the Monkey Mask Monstera never disappoints. With holes in the middle of the leaves, rather than running to the edges, this plant definitely stands out in a crowd. It can get a little rough and rugged looking as the vines intertwine around each other, but that gives it quite a rustic charm and brings a little bit of the jungle right to your home.\n\nMonkey Mask Monstera plants can be grown with a moss pole if you’d prefer to prop it up, or it can be left to hang down out of the pot, making it adaptable to nearly any space in your home. When it comes to caring for your plant, avoid direct sunshine and super soggy, and make sure to mist the leaves regularly and your plant will be very happy! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">A close relative to the infamous Swiss Cheese Plant, the Monkey Mask Monstera never disappoints. With holes in the middle of the leaves, rather than running to the edges, this plant definitely stands out in a crowd. It can get a little rough and rugged looking as the vines intertwine around each other, but that gives it quite a rustic charm and brings a little bit of the jungle right to your home.

Monkey Mask Monstera plants can be grown with a moss pole if you’d prefer to prop it up, or it can be left to hang down out of the pot, making it adaptable to nearly any space in your home. When it comes to caring for your plant, avoid direct sunshine and super soggy, and make sure to mist the leaves regularly and your plant will be very happy!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Air Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Air Plants are some of the only plants that don't need any soil to grow and only need the occasional misting and water bath to keep them alive. Below you will find our complete Air Plant Care Guide with all the information you need to help it thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Air Plants</h2>
Because Air Plants are so unique in how you care for them compared to regular houseplants, they are bound to have some issues. It is important to spot any warning signs to know when your Air Plant might be unhappy.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Intense curling of your Air Plant's leaves may signify that it is dehydrated. The best thing to do is soak it in water for 30 minutes and keep on top of your misting routine. Be careful not to go the other way and overwater your Air Plant as this can kill it quite quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;There are hundreds of Air Plant varieties for you to fall in love with, all with relatively similar care requirements. If you haven’t already guessed from the name, Air Plants are pretty different to most other houseplant types as they don’t grow in soil. Instead, all they need is regular misting and the occasional bath to survive! \n\nNative to areas across Central and South America, Air Plants need warm temperatures and high humidity levels to really thrive which makes them great plants for terrariums. But don’t think this is the only way to grow Air Plants, because with a little bit of care and attention to their environment, you can grow them in most homes with no problems! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">There are hundreds of Air Plant varieties for you to fall in love with, all with relatively similar care requirements. If you haven’t already guessed from the name, Air Plants are pretty different to most other houseplant types as they don’t grow in soil. Instead, all they need is regular misting and the occasional bath to survive!</span>

Native to areas across Central and South America, Air Plants need warm temperatures and high humidity levels to really thrive which makes them great plants for terrariums. But don’t think this is the only way to grow Air Plants, because with a little bit of care and attention to their environment, you can grow them in most homes with no problems!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_intro_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Jade Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Jade Plants, also known as Money Plants or Lucky Plants, are popular succulents that are believed to bring luck. They are also quite easy to care for which is always a bonus. Below you will all the information you need to properly care for your Jade Plant.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Jade Plants need full sun</h3>
It is important that your Jade Plant gets at least a few hours of direct sunlight each day. If you are lucky enough to have a south-facing window in your home, we definitely recommend placing them near that to maximise the exposure each day.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Good drainage is vital</h3>
Jade Plants like it if the soil is moist but not damp and they hate sitting in water. This means you need to ensure your pot has good drainage holes and you have added perlite into the soil mix. During winter, you need to reduce the amount of water as this can easily lead to root rot in colder temperatures.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the leaves of your Jade Plant dry as you water</h3>
It is important that you do not splash the leaves whilst watering your Jade Plant as this can lead them to rot so make sure to water directly into the soil from a narrow spout.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Jade Plants prefer warmer temperatures</h3>
Although they will survive in slightly cooler homes, Jade Plants thrive best in environments at or above room temperature. Don't worry if your room sometimes drops below 10°C in winter as your Jade Plant will still be able to survive, but growth will be minimal.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Jade Plants</h2>
Although the requirements for taking care of a Jade Plant are quite clear, this doesn't necessarily mean it always works out in practice. There are quite a few common issues that occur so its important to know the warning signs and act quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[136]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Use a water soluble fertiliser</h3>
Throughout the warmer months of spring and summer you may want to fertilise your Jade Plant to encourage growth. We recommend using a weak water-soluble fertiliser once a month during the growth period, and none at all during autumn and winter.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Jade Plants are sensitive to tap water salts</h3>
We recommend you filter the water for your Jade Plant if you live in a hard water area. This is because they can be quite sensitive to salts that are in your tap water.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They don't mind being a little pot bound</h3>
Frequently repotting your Jade Plant is not a necessity, they won't suffer too much by being root bound so you might only need to repot every few years or so. When you do though, make sure you repot in spring so it can settle into its new home during the warmer months.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Jade Plants can flower if neglected</h3>
If you do want your Jade Plant to produce flowers, do not repot too often so that the plant becomes quite root bound and keep the soil quite dry. This will encourage the plant to produce little white flowers.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that your Jade Plant is losing quite a few leaves, this is often an indication that your plant is thirsty. Increase the watering a little (making sure there is sufficient drainage) but be careful not to overcompensate as too much water can cause root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Shrivelled, dry leaves on a Jade Plant are a sign that it is not receiving enough water. Increase the watering a little (making sure there is sufficient drainage) but be careful not to overcompensate as too much water can cause root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are my Jade Plant's leaves turning brown?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If there are light brown spots or patches on the leaves of your Jade Plant, it may be due to underwatering. If there are dark brown, squidgy leaves, it may be overwatering. Check the moisture in the soil and adjust your watering schedule accordingly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are the leaves on my Jade Plant squishy? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Squishy Jade Plant leaves are an indication that you have been overwatering, or there is not enough drainage in your pot. Make sure you have added perlite to the potting mix and hold off on the watering for a while.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is important that your Jade Plant gets at least a few hours of direct sunlight each day. If you are lucky enough to have a south-facing window in your home, we definitely recommend placing them near that to maximise the exposure each day.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Jade Plants like it if the soil is moist but not damp and they hate sitting in water. This means you need to ensure your pot has good drainage holes and you have added perlite into the soil mix. During winter, you need to reduce the amount of water as this can easily lead to root rot in colder temperatures.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although they will survive in slightly cooler homes, Jade Plants thrive best in environments at or above room temperature. Don't worry if your room sometimes drops below 10°C in winter as your Jade Plant will still be able to survive, but growth will be minimal.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Jade Plants thrive best at humidity levels of around 30%-50%. Never mist your Jade Plant as they need their leaves to be dry to avoid rot. You can find out more about humidity levels and percentages in our<a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/"> humidity guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>

When you do though, make sure you repot in spring so it can settle into its new home during the warmer months.]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Believed to bring luck, Jade Plants are one of the most popular succulent varieties. They are best known for their oval-shaped leaves and strong stems which become quite woody as they mature. \n\nWhen it comes to caring for your Jade Plants, the top two things to remember is to give it a spot that gets ample sunshine throughout the day as well as making sure the potting mix has fully dried out before watering again as they are susceptible to root rot if you’re not careful. \n\nJade Plants are quite slow growers though, so even if the environment and care routine are perfect, they may only grow a few inches per year. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Believed to bring luck, Jade Plants are one of the most popular succulent varieties. They are best known for their oval-shaped leaves and strong stems which become quite woody as they mature.

When it comes to caring for your Jade Plants, the top two things to remember is to give it a spot that gets ample sunshine throughout the day as well as making sure the potting mix has fully dried out before watering again as they are susceptible to root rot if you’re not careful. Jade Plants are quite slow growers though, so even if the environment and care routine are perfect, they may only grow a few inches per year.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Croton Plant Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">One thing that is really unique about Croton Plants is that they are genetically unstable. This means that all plants look slightly unique. Below you will find our complete Croton Plant care guide with all the information and tips you need to help your plant thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Croton Plants</h2>
Croton Plants are fairly easy plants to take care of and don't have a wide range of issues. However, it is still important to know the warning signs of when your plant may be unhappy so you can react quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Croton Plants love bright, indirect light</h3>
Although they can survive in medium light areas, Croton Plants love bright, indirect light more than anything. Be careful not to place them in direct sunshine as this can scorch and burn the leaves.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the soil evenly moist</h3>
We recommend watering once a week in the warmer growth months and reducing this to twice a month during autumn and winter. Croton Plants also like their leaves to be misted every once in a while.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Croton Plants need a warm environment</h3>
Croton Plants are a little sensitive to the cold and will prefer room temperature or above. Be extra careful not to place your plant near a drafty door or window as the cold air from outside can cause stress and shock.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise in the growing season</h3>
This rule goes for most houseplants, but you should only fertilize your Croton Plant in the warmer months of spring and summer as the plant will usually go into a dormant period over winter.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Leaf colours depend on sunlight levels</h3>
By increasing the intensity of sunlight, you can actually make your Croton Plant produce more vibrant leaves. If there are no real patterns or colours in the leaves, you might want to move it to a sunnier spot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Repot your Croton Plant in spring</h3>
It is best to repot your Croton Plant in spring, right before the growing period. Choose a pot a few centimetres larger in diameter and add a few small handfuls of good draining soil to the bottom before carefully lifting the plant in.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Mist your Croton Plant to avoid pests</h3>
If you live in a home with quite low humidity levels, you might want to think about misting your plant. This reduces the risk that your Croton Plant will get infested with spider mites.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Croton Plants are mildly toxic to pets</h3>
Although it won't cause long term damage for your pet, ingesting part of a Croton Plant will cause stomach issues and vomiting so try to keep your plant away from your furry friends.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Croton Plant using a stem cutting</h3>
Croton Plant can be easily propagated by cutting off part of the stem and placing it in water. After a few weeks, roots should develop and your cutting can be placed into soil. Occasionally your Croton Plant will produce offshoots which can be divided from the mother plant.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate your Croton Plant using a stem cutting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Croton Plants can be easily propagated by cutting off part of the stem and placing it in water. After a few weeks, roots should develop and your cutting can be placed into soil. Occasionally your Croton Plant will produce offshoots which can be divided from the mother plant. Because the Croton Plant family is quite genetically unstable, the offshoots may not always look the same as the mother plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;If you’re looking to bring a splash of colour into your home, then the Croton Plant is the perfect choice. Native to India and Indonesia, the unusual thing about Croton Plants is that they are genetically unstable which means every single plant will look slightly unique. Even when propagated, the new plants can look different to the mother plant. \n\nThere are so many types of Croton Plants showcasing red, yellow, pink, purple, orange and white leaves but luckily they all have the same care requirements. Like most other tropical plants, they need ample light, a moderate amount of water and a nice warm room to really thrive. It’s best to keep this one away from pets though as although it’s not the most toxic plant, it can cause some irritation when ingested. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">If you’re looking to bring a splash of colour into your home, then the Croton Plant is the perfect choice. Native to India and Indonesia, the unusual thing about Croton Plants is that they are genetically unstable which means every single plant will look slightly unique. Even when propagated, the new plants can look different to the mother plant.

There are so many types of Croton Plants showcasing red, yellow, pink, purple, orange and white leaves but luckily they all have the same care requirements. Like most other tropical plants, they need ample light, a moderate amount of water and a nice warm room to really thrive. It’s best to keep this one away from pets though as although it’s not the most toxic plant, it can cause some irritation when ingested.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for a Burro's Tail</h2>
A Burro's Tail plant can be a little more difficult than the average succulent so it is important to know the warning signs so you can act quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Burro's Tail love the sunshine</h3>
As with most succulent types, they love sunlight and can suffer in very low light areas of your home. Be careful not to expose your Burro's Tail to too much direct light as this can scorch the plant over time.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Water it maximum once a month</h3>
Your Burro's Tail thrives from having dry soil and too much moisture can very quickly lead to root and plant rot. We recommend watering deeply once a month, rather than light watering more often. Make sure to check the moisture in the soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Your Burro's Tail needs a warm environment</h3>
In order to produce plenty of healthy growth, your Burro's Tail will need a warm spot in your home. Don't worry too much if temperatures drop a little in winter as this is their dormant period anyway.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Normal humidity levels are fine</h3>
You don't need to worry about raising the humidity levels for your Burro's Tail. Also, try not to grow it in a bathroom or kitchen where the natural humidity is higher.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>You might never have to repot it</h3>
Your Burro's Tail plant really quite enjoys being root bound so you don't need to worry about repotting it. If you need to, be extra careful when handling it as the leaves can drop very easily.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Burro's Tail plants are safe for pets and children</h3>
You'll be pleased to know that Burro's Tail plants are not toxic when handled or ingested so you don't need to worry about pets or small children getting too close.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagating a Burro's Tail is simple!</h3>
Burro's Tail leaves can be quite prone to dropping. But this can actually make for an easy way to propagate. Leave the dropped leaves out of water and soil for a few days for them to harden at the bottom. Then insert into fresh, nutrient-rich soil and resume normal care.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Burro's Tail dropping leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The occasional leaf drop on a Burro's Tail is quite normal. However, if you notice it happening a lot, and the leaves look healthy and not soft or too dry, then it may be due to over-handling. For example, moving it around to different spots or brushing past it as you walk.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[How do I remove pests from my Burro's Tail?]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4085]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Also known as the Donkey’s Tail Plant, these striking succulents are loved for their delicate leaves that dramatically cascade out of the pot. Native to Mexico and Honduras, they are forgiving to the forgetful waterer as they store water in their leaves (this also makes them quite sensitive to overwatering so be mindful about that) and just need a nice warm sunny spot to be happy!\n\nTheir easy care routine does come at a cost, however, as the Burro’s Tail grows pretty slowly throughout the year. Their stems can often reach around 20-25 inches but it’s really important to handle the Burros Tail plant carefully as the stems break off with just the slightest touch. Luckily they enjoy being root-bound so you shouldn’t have to repot it very often and you can really easily propagate any stems or leaves that fall off. They are also non-toxic so great for homes with small children or furry friends. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Also known as the Donkey’s Tail Plant, these striking succulents are loved for their delicate leaves that dramatically cascade out of the pot. Native to Mexico and Honduras, they are forgiving to the forgetful waterer as they store water in their leaves (this also makes them quite sensitive to overwatering so be mindful about that) and just need a nice warm sunny spot to be happy!

Their easy care routine does come at a cost, however, as the Burro’s Tail grows pretty slowly throughout the year. Their stems can often reach around 20-25 inches but it’s really important to handle the Burros Tail plant carefully as the stems break off with just the slightest touch. Luckily they enjoy being root-bound so you shouldn’t have to repot it very often and you can really easily propagate any stems or leaves that fall off. They are also non-toxic so great for homes with small children or furry friends.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Cactus Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">There are probably more Cactus types that we could possibly count in the world, which makes them one of the most unique and popular houseplant types. We have put together a Cactus care guide that you can apply generally to most of your Cacti.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Cacti</h2>
Growing and caring for Cacti in your home can sometimes be difficult so it is important to know what to look out for that suggests your cactus isn't doing so well.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep your Cactus in a bright spot</h3>
As you can imagine, being native to deserts across the world, cacti love sunlight. They will really struggle in low light areas of your home so make sure these are kept close to windows to make the most of the sunshine each day.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Adjust your watering across seasons</h3>
In the hotter months of spring and summer, it is important that your cacti receive sufficient watering. We usually go for once a month but it does depend on the size and drainage of each specific cactus. In winter, hold back almost completely from watering as it will cause root rot very quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>You must use a fast-draining potting mix</h3>
Your Cactus will rot pretty quickly if the soil retains moisture for too long. We recommend using succulent/ cactus specific soil as this will contain agents such as perlite which increases drainage in the pot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Cacti prefer warmer environments</h3>
Although they can survive in slightly cooler homes, Cacti thrive in warmer environments. Nearer windows will tend to give them a little more warmth in summer but can be a little drafty in winter so be aware of this.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Dry air is best for your Cactus</h3>
This can be a little tricky especially if you have other humidity-loving houseplants in your home. Don't worry too much about changing the humidity levels in your home but prevent placing your Cactus in the kitchen or bathroom where steam from cooking or showering naturally increases the humidity.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Use Cactus-specific fertiliser</h3>
If you wish to feed your Cactus during the growing months, we recommend using Cactus-specific fertiliser as they tend to be a little more tailored than generic houseplant fertiliser.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep away from pets and children</h3>
Due to the sharp thorns found on a lot of Cactus types, as well as some that produce sap that can be irritable to your skin and stomach, we recommend as a rule to keep your pets and children away from the Cacti in your home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't worry about repotting</h3>
You usually won't have to repot your Cactus for a few years as they are quite slow growers and have shallow roots. If you do think it is time to repot, make sure you wear thick gloves to protect from their sharp pricks.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Cactus using segment cuttings</h3>
Propagating a Cactus is usually quite easy and can be done by snipping of a healthy stem/pad or individual head. Place the cutting in the sun for a few days for it to harden before placing it in fresh cactus potting mix. Water every week or so and after a month or two it should start to form roots.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there are brown edges / markings on my Cactus?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If the brown parts are dry rather than soft and mushy, this will have been caused by underwatering. Be careful when rectifying this problem as you can very easily go the other way and overwater.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my cactus droopy?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that your cactus is drooping down, this is probably caused by overwatering. We recommend carefully inspecting the moisture in the soil, replacing it if necessary and adjusting your watering schedule.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my cactus turned brown at the base?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If your Cactus is turning brown and mushy from the base up, you have been overwatering it. Carefully inspect the moisture levels in the soil and replace if necessary. Then adjust your watering schedule and check the soil before watering each time.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[In the hotter months of spring and summer, it is important that your Cacti receive sufficient watering. We usually go for once a month but it does depend on the size and drainage of each specific cactus. In winter, hold back almost completely from watering as it will cause root rot very quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although they can survive in slightly cooler homes, Cacti thrive in warmer environments. Nearer windows will tend to give them a little more warmth in summer but can be a little drafty in winter so be aware of this.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

Don't worry too much about changing the humidity levels in your home but prevent placing your Cactus in the kitchen or bathroom where steam from cooking or showering naturally increases the humidity.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Due to the sharp thorns found on a lot of Cactus types, as well as some that produce sap that can be irritable to your skin and stomach, we recommend as a rule to keep your pets and children away from the Cacti in your home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Don't worry about repotting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[You usually won't have to repot your Cactus for a few years as they are quite slow growers and have shallow roots. If you do think it is time to repot, make sure you wear thick gloves to protect from their sharp pricks.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagating a Cactus is usually quite easy and can be done by snipping of a healthy stem/pad or individual head. Place the cutting in the sun for a few days for it to harden before placing it in fresh cactus potting mix. Water every week or so and after a month or two it should start to form roots.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3998]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;There are probably more Cactus species than we could possibly count in the world, which makes them one of the most unique and popular houseplants to keep. On top of that, they are normally incredibly easy to maintain, make great gifts and can be good starter plant.\n\nBright lighting conditions, minimal watering and low humidity requirements make them one of the best windowsill plants you can have. Plus you only have to repot them every few years due to their slower than average growth. However, as I’m sure you can imagine, they’re not the best houseplants to have around pets or children as some species can have quite nasty spines.&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">There are probably more Cactus species than we could possibly count in the world, which makes them one of the most unique and popular houseplants to keep. On top of that, they are normally incredibly easy to maintain, make great gifts and can be good starter plant.

Bright lighting conditions, minimal watering and low humidity requirements make them one of the best windowsill plants you can have. Plus you only have to repot them every few years due to their slower than average growth. However, as I’m sure you can imagine, they’re not the best houseplants to have around pets or children as some species can have quite nasty spines.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Calathea Orbifolia</h2>
Calathea Orbifolia can be a litlte difficult to care for sometimes and have a range of issues that may occur if the environment or care is off. It's good to know the warning signs so you can act quickly and reverse the damage.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They don't need bright light to survive</h3>
Medium to low light levels are best for a Calathea Orbifolia. Make sure you don't place it in any direct sunlight as it will scorch and burn the leaves which is unfortunately permanent.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They like their soil to be moist</h3>
We recommend taking a little but often approach to watering your Calathea Orbifolia. They like moist, but not waterlogged soil so it is important to check the soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Slightly more humid rooms are best</h3>
We recommend growing your Calathea Orbifolia in a bathroom or kitchen if the light levels are right in there as the natural lift in humidity caused by steam from the shower/cooking is perfect.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the temperatures warm for your Calathea Orbifolia</h3>
Try to avoid putting your Calathea Orbifolia near a drafty window or AC vent as the cold temperatures can harm your plant's health.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise in the growth period</h3>
As with the majority of your other houseplants, only fertilize your Calathea Orbifolia in spring and summer. We recommend feeding once a month using a regular houseplant fertiliser.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
