		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They are perfectly safe for pets and humans</h3>
A great thing about Calathea Orbifolia is that they are not toxic for your cats, dogs and children which means you don't need to keep them out of reach or worry about them getting a little nibble.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Calathea Orbifolia using division</h3>
The most successful way of propagating a Calathea Orbifolia is by dividing the mother plant into smaller, separate plants. As they will each have part of the main root system attached, you can plant directly into soil and don't have to place in water first.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown tips on a Calathea Orbifolia can be a little difficult to diagnose because there are several causes. It may be due to underwatering, dry air or sensitivity to chemicals in the tap water. Check the moisture in the soil using a<a href="/a/moisture-monitor"> moisture meter</a> and leave the water to sit for a day so the fluoride can evaporate.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[A yellowish tinge on the edges of the leaves suggest a reaction to the fluoride and chlorine in your tap water. We recommend using rain water or alternatively leaving your tap water to sit for a day to the chemicals can evaporate.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Limp stems on a Calathea Orbifolia is a sign of overwatering. Check the moisture levels in the soil using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> and replace if waterlogged. Adjust your watering schedule going forward and the stems should start to recover.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are the leaves on my Calathea Orbifolia drooping?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As with drooping stems, drooping leaves are a sign of overwatering. Check the moisture levels in the soil using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> and replace it with fresh <a href="/a/houseplant-soil">high-quality potting mix</a> if waterlogged. Adjust your watering schedule going forward and the leaves should start to pick back up again.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Medium to low light levels are best for a Calathea Orbifolia. Make sure you don't place it in any direct sunlight as it will scorch and burn the leaves which is unfortunately permanent. You can use a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter</a> to help you measure the sunlight levels in your home to make sure you're placing your Calathea Orbifolia in the best place.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They like their soil to be moist]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend taking a little but often approach to watering your Calathea Orbifolia. They like moist, but not waterlogged soil so it is important to check the soil before watering. We often use our <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to help know when our Calathea plants need a water which helps to prevent over or underwatering. You can pick up a really <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">affordable moisture meter from Amazon here. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend growing your Calathea Orbifolia in a bathroom or kitchen if the light levels are right in there as the natural lift in humidity caused by steam from the shower/cooking is perfect. You can also use a <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier</a> to keep a nice constant level near your Calathea.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Using a <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometer,</a> we recommend checking the temperatures throughout the day/night as well as throughout the year to spot any extreme temperatures.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As with the majority of your other houseplants, only fertilize your Calathea Orbifolia in spring and summer. We recommend feeding once a month using a regular houseplant fertiliser. We tend to use<a href="/a/fertiliser-bottle"> this one from Miracle Gro.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[A great thing about Calathea Orbifolia is that they are not toxic for your cats, dogs and children which means you don't need to keep them out of reach or worry about them getting a little nibble.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The most successful way of propagating a Calathea Orbifolia is by dividing the mother plant into smaller, separate plants. As they will each have part of the main root system attached, you can plant directly into soil and don't have to place in water first.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;With their striking green and silver striped leaves, the Calathea Obifolia is the perfect plant for those looking for a little something different as they transport you straight to the tropics! There are a few things to look out for when caring for a Calathea Obifolia, firstly, avoid direct sunshine as this will burn their beautiful leaves. They also like some moisture in the soil but hate sitting in soggy soil, so finding the right balance is key. \n\nAnother thing we love about Calathea Obifolia plants is that they are safe for pets and humans, so you don’t need to worry about bringing them into your home.  \n\nThe once slightly rare Calathea variety, you should now be able to get your hands on one pretty easily in nurseries and larger plant shops around the world. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">With their striking green and silver striped leaves, the Calathea Obifolia is the perfect plant for those looking for a little something different as they transport you straight to the tropics! There are a few things to look out for when caring for a Calathea Obifolia, firstly, avoid direct sunshine as this will burn their beautiful leaves. They also like some moisture in the soil but hate sitting in soggy soil, so finding the right balance is key.

Another thing we love about Calathea Obifolia plants is that they are safe for pets and humans, so you don’t need to worry about bringing them into your home. Although it was once slightly rare, you should now be able to get your hands on one of these pretty easily in nurseries and larger plant shops around the world.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">We aren't surprised that Rattlesnake Plants are becoming popular in the houseplant world as they are very easy to care for. Below you'll find all the information you need to properly care for your Rattlesnake Plant.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Rattlesnake Plants</h2>
There are a few common problems that may occur over time when caring for your Rattlesnake Plants. It's important to know the warning signs so you can change the care or environment.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They are a great low-light plant</h3>
One thing we really love about Rattlesnake Plants is that they don't need a lot of light to be happy. They will thrive well in medium to low light areas of your home. Direct sunlight is a definite no-go as it will scorch the leaves pretty quickly!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Rattlesnake Plants like moist soil</h3>
But it is important to not let it get waterlogged. Water more frequently in the growth period of spring and summer. In winter, we recommend only watering your Rattlesnake Plant when the top of the soil is very dry to touch.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Rattlesnake Plants prefer warmer temperatures</h3>
Although they won't necessarily die if your home is a little cooler, Rattlesnake Plants definitely like warmer rooms. Try to keep them away from drafty windows and doors as the cold air from outside may cause shock.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Try to keep the humidity up</h3>
Rattlesnake Plants like a spot with slightly more humidity. We recommend misting your plant in warmer months or growing it in your kitchen or bathroom where humidity levels are naturally higher. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your plants in our<a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/"> guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise your Rattlesnake Plant in the growth period</h3>
As with the majority of other houseplants, Rattlesnake Plants do not need fertilisation in winter. You will get the best results if you use a general houseplant fertiliser every month or so during spring and summer.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Rattlesnake Plants are safe for pets and humans</h3>
Another reason why we love Rattlesnake Plants is that they are non-toxic for pets and children. So you don't need to worry about moving it out of the way.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate a Rattlesnake Plants using division</h3>
The best method to propagate your Rattlesnake Plants is through dividing the mother plant into several new plants. As long as each plant has a good bit of the main root system, your propagation should be successful. Be careful when handling the roots to minimise damage.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are my Rattlesnake Plant's leaves curling? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice the leaves on your Rattlesnake Plant are starting to curl, this is often due to either a lack of water or not enough humidity in the air. Slightly increase the frequency of your watering and occasionally mist your plant if you are not already as this may stop the leaves from curling. We also recommend using a <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier</a> to increase the humidity around your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there are brown leaf tips on my Rattlesnake Plant?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown leaf tips on a Rattlesnake Plant are most commonly due to underwatering or a lack of humidity. Slightly increase the frequency of your watering and occasionally mist your plant using a <a href="/a/spray-bottles">spray bottle</a> or use a<a href="/a/premium-humidifier"> humidifier</a> if you are not already.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Rattlesnake Plant wilting? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you find that your Rattlesnake plant has started to wilt, you may be overwatering. Check the moisture in the soil using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> and replace with a <a href="/a/houseplant-soil">high-quality potting mix</a> if waterlogged. Reduce your watering and keep an eye on the moisture levels in the soil. We also recommend adding drainage holes to the pot if there aren't any or switching to <a href="/a/terracotta-pots">terracotta pots. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They are a great low-light plant]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One thing we really love about Rattlesnake Plants is that they don't need a lot of light to be happy. They will thrive well in medium to low light areas of your home. Direct sunlight is a definite no-go as it will scorch the leaves pretty quickly! Use a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light meter</a> if you aren't sure where to place your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Rattlesnake Plants like moist soil]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is important to not let your Rattlesnake Plant's soil get waterlogged. Water more frequently in the growth period of spring and summer. In winter, we recommend only watering your Rattlesnake Plant when the top of the soil is very dry to touch. You can also use a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to check the soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Rattlesnake Plants prefer warmer temperatures]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although they won't necessarily die if your home is a little cooler, Rattlesnake Plants definitely like warmer rooms. Try to keep them away from drafty windows and doors as the cold air from outside may cause shock.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Try to keep the humidity up]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Rattlesnake Plants like a spot with slightly more humidity. We recommend misting your plant in warmer months using a <a href="/a/spray-bottles">spray bottle</a>, using a <a href="/a/humidifier">humidifier</a> or growing it in your kitchen or bathroom where humidity levels are naturally higher. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your plants in our<a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/"> guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Only fertilise your Rattlesnake Plant in the growth period]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As with the majority of other houseplants, Rattlesnake Plants do not need fertilisation in winter. You will get the best results if you use a general houseplant fertiliser every month or so during spring and summer. Our plants really love <a href="/a/fertiliser-bottle">this feed from Miracle Gro.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Rattlesnake Plants are safe for pets and humans]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Another reason why we love Rattlesnake Plants is that they are non-toxic for pets and children. So you don't need to worry about moving it out of the way.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate a Rattlesnake Plants using division]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The best method to propagate your Rattlesnake Plants is through dividing the mother plant into several new plants. As long as each plant has a good bit of the main root system, your propagation should be successful. Be careful when handling the roots to minimise damage.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3932]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Over the past few years, Rattlesnake Plants have gone from being quite rare to being one of the most popular Calathea plants around… and we totally understand why! Not only do they have über-cool markings on their long thin leaves, but they are quite an easy plant to take care of.\n\nNative to the Brazilian rainforests, Rattlesnake Plants can adapt to a range of light levels, making them a great choice for those looking for a low-light plant. They also don’t need that much water as their roots absolutely hate sitting in waterlogged soil. The one thing you do need to make sure you do when caring for a Rattlesnake Plant is to boost the humidity either by misting the leaves or by using a humidifier. \n\nRattlesnake Plants are non-toxic too, so that’s just another reason to love them! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Over the past few years, Rattlesnake Plants have gone from being quite rare to being one of the most popular Calathea plants around… and we totally understand why! Not only do they have über-cool markings on their long thin leaves, but they are quite an easy plant to take care of.

Native to the Brazilian rainforests, Rattlesnake Plants can adapt to a range of light levels, making them a great choice for those looking for a low-light plant. They also don’t need that much water as their roots absolutely hate sitting in waterlogged soil. The one thing you do need to make sure you do when caring for a Rattlesnake Plant is to boost the humidity either by misting the leaves or by using a humidifier. Rattlesnake Plants are non-toxic too, so that’s just another reason to love them!
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for a Bunny Ears Cactus</h2>
Like any cactus, Bunny Ears Cacti can be a little difficult to care for in your home as they are suited to a very different environment. Make sure to look out for any warning signs and act immediately if you think something is wrong.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Bunny Ears Cacti love sunshine</h3>
The best spot for a Bunny Ears Cactus is somewhere that gets bright, direct sunlight for several hours each day. South-facing windows are the best and they may struggle in a north-facing spot.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They don't require much water</h3>
As with most cacti, your Bunny Ears Cactus doesn't need much water at all. The roots are adapted to catch even the slightest bit of water meaning too much water can quickly lead to root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They thrive in warmer temperatures</h3>
Although having a home that is slightly cooler doesn't mean you could never have a Bunny Ears Cactus, remember that they do grow better, and produce flowers in warmer temperatures.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Quick drainage is key</h3>
Due to the danger of root rot, you want to ensure that the soil and the pot have good drainage. Make sure the pot has sufficient drainage holes (and that they aren't blocked) and add some perlite to the potting mix to increase the water flow.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertiliser can encourage growth and flowering</h3>
We recommend diluting the fertiliser to avoid damaging the roots and plant. Also do not fertilise your Bunny Ears Cactus during the dormant winter period or if you have recently repotted it.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Repot your Bunny Ears Cactus every other year</h3>
To avoid the plant becoming too rot-bound, we recommend repotting a Bunny Ears Cactus every year or two. Make sure to choose a pot only a few centimetres larger in diameter so that the plant doesn't become unstable in its new home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate a Bunny Ears Cactus using leaf cuttings</h3>
You can easily propagate your Bunny Ears Cactus by breaking off one of the pads and potting it a few centimetres into the soil. Water regularly for about 6 months to encourage roots to form.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Bunny Ears Cactus not growing?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Stunted growth in a Bunny Ears Cactus can be caused by watering issues, either too much or too little. The best thing to do is carefully remove the plant from its pot (whilst wearing thick gloves) and inspect the potting mix. If you notice that it’s either bone dry or really clumpy and soggy then it means that watering issues is causing it to struggle. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the soil is very dry, slowly reintroduce watering again but avoid overcompensating and drowning your plant as this will cause a whole range of other issues. If the potting mix is quite soggy, replace it immediately rather than waiting for it to dry out as this risks more damage being done to the root system. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">A lack of growth can also simply be down to seasonal changes so don’t worry if you don’t see any new pads during autumn and winter as this is the dormant period. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there brown patches on my Bunny Ears Cactus?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Browning on your Bunny Ears Cactus can be caused by overwatering, pest infestation or a drop in temperature. Check the potting mix first as this is an easy way to see if watering has damaged the root system at all. Then inspect the pads for any signs of pests and invest in a humidity and temperature measure to keep an eye on the environment. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there white patches/ brown scabs on my Bunny Ears Cactus?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">White patches on your Bunny Ears Cactus is a sign that your plant is, unfortunately, being infested by mealybugs. Bown scabs on the pads of your Bunny Ears Cactus are a sign of scale insects. Treat all pests with alcohol using a cotton bud and this should keep the problem at bay. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are the pads on my Bunny Ears Cactus shrivelling?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">This is a sign that you have been overwatering your Bunny Ears Cactus. We recommend removing the parts of the pads that are brown and changing the soil out immediately to avoid any further damage. Moving forward reduce the amount you are watering your Bunny Ears Cactus and cut back on watering almost entirely during winter as they are very susceptible to leaf and root rot whilst temperatures are low. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Bunny Ears Cacti love sunshine]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">The best spot for a Bunny Ears Cactus is somewhere that gets bright, direct sunlight for several hours each day. South-facing windows are the best and they may struggle in a north-facing spot. During the hottest summer days you may want to bring your cactus away from the window a little to stop it burning but otherwise, you shouldn’t have too many issues placing it in direct sunlight. </span>

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Bunny Ears Cacti don't require much water]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">As with most cacti, your Bunny Ears Cactus doesn’t need much water at all. The roots are adapted to catch even the slightest bit of water meaning too much water can quickly lead to root rot. Use a saucer or planter to capture excess water and remove any water after about 10 minutes. This will allow the plant to soak up the right amount of water but will help to prevent the roots from sitting in puddles of water. During the growth period of spring and summer, your Bunny Ears Cactus does like to have some moisture in the soil so water a little once a week. During autumn and winter, however, we recommend only watering your Bunny Ears Cactus once a month as this is the dormant period. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Bunny Ears Cacti thrive in warmer temperatures]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Although having a home that is slightly cooler doesn’t mean you could never have a Bunny Ears Cactus, remember that they do grow better, and produce flowers in warmer temperatures. This is especially important during spring and summer to encourage new healthy growth. During the autumn and winter months they appreciate slightly cooler temperatures so keep them away from radiators or heating vents as this can dry out the cactus and cause several issues. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Good drainage is key for your Bunny Ears Cactus]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Due to the danger of root rot, you want to ensure that the soil and the pot have good drainage. Use a well-draining potting mix that is especially designed for cacti. A pre-packaged cactus soil will usually work well but you can also create your own sand-based potting mix if you wish to. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure the pot has sufficient drainage holes so that excess water can run out of the pot and be poured away rather which will help reduce the risk of root rot. It’s a good idea to put some small pebbles at the bottom of the pot to prevent the drainage holes being blocked by clumps of potting mix. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Fertiliser can encourage growth and flowering in your Bunny Ears Cactus]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Using a cacti-specific fertiliser, feed your Bunny Ears Cactus a couple of times throughout the growth period. This will help to encourage new pads to grow as well as flowers and fruit to develop. It’s important that you use a water-soluble fertiliser made for cacti which are low in nitrogen rather than using a generic houseplant fertiliser. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When feeding your Bunny Ears Cactus, dilute the fertiliser more than recommended so it’s weaker than what it says on the bottle. Too much fertiliser can damage and burn the roots so it’s better to be on the safe side. You should also never fertilise your Bunny Ears Cactus in autumn or winter as this can actually kill your plant. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Repot your Bunny Ears Cactus every other year]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">To avoid your Bunny Ears Cactus becoming rot-bound, we recommend repotting your plant every year or two. Make sure to choose a pot only a few centimetres larger in diameter so that the plant doesn’t become unstable in its new home. Make sure to use thick gloves when repotting your Bunny Ears Cactus as the bristles can be quite painful and difficult to remove from skin. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate a Bunny Ears Cactus using leaf cuttings]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">You can easily propagate your Bunny Ears Cactus by breaking off one of the pads and potting it a few centimetres into the soil. We have found that using tweezers to break off the pads works really well and avoids you coming into contact with the sharp bristles on the plant. Pop your pads deep into potting mix and water regularly to encourage root growth. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Top tip: we have always found propagating Bunny Ears Cacti to be more successful when you use cuttings that have 2-3 pads on each. This helps the plant to mature faster and reduces the risk of disease. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Bunny Ears Cacti prefer dry air]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">As with most Cacti types, the Bunny Ear Cactus thrives in low humidity. This is because they are native to desert plains and their pads will begin to rot if in a humid environment. This makes the plants great for those who find their homes are too dry for other tropical houseplants to thrive in. You can also use a dehumidifier to prevent your Bunny Ears Cactus from rotting. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Keep your Bunny Ears Cactus away from pets]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Although the cactus itself is not toxic to pets, cacti should be kept well away from them due to their glochids which can cause irritation when touched or swallowed. This is why we always recommend placing these plants high up on shelves or somewhere where children and pets can’t get to. The bristles on the Bunny Ears Cactus are actually very lose and come away even with a bit of wind so it can be really easy for yourself or any pets to get them stuck in skin if touched. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[ads_disabled]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_ads_disabled]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_604387a5b7bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3 class="h2 mb-4">About the Bunny Ears Cactus</h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re looking for a low-maintenance houseplant that still gives the wow-factor, then look no further than the Bunny Ears Cactus. Great for beginners and seasons plant parents, the Bunny Ears Cactus is loved for its flat oval pads that spring up in pairs. There are a lot of names given to this plant, from Polka Dot Cactus to Angle Wings, but we love Bunny Ears Cactus the most as the fuzzy bristles on the pads give it that furry look. However, although they sound cute, Bunny Ears Cacti are definitely not as cuddly as you’d like them to be. Although they don’t grow spines, they go have fuzzy glochids that grow on the pads. These are painful to touch and can be really difficult to remove from skin so make sure you wear gloves at all times when handling the plant. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Native to the Mexican desert plains, the Bunny Ears Cactus will thrive if you replicate the native conditions. Try and find a spot in your home with low humidity levels and lots of natural sunshine. They will start to rot if placed in bathrooms or kitchens where there is naturally a higher humidity level so choose the placement carefully. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">These slow-growing houseplants can reach up to around half a metre, sometimes more when grown indoors but will grow to double that if given the right conditions outside. They will take a while to grow but are definitely worth the wait. You may sometimes see light yellow flowers grow from the tops of the most mature pads on your Bunny Ears Cactus and if you’re lucky there might even be some red or purple fruit starting to grow. Although you won’t die from eating the fruit, it usually won’t taste great so we don’t recommend giving it a try, unfortunately. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_extra_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_6108021a5827d]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[There’s no need to prune your Bunny Ears Cactus]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your Bunny Ears Cactus is healthy, you don’t need to worry about pruning it. With some other houseplants, it can be beneficial to encourage bushier growth but the same doesn’t really apply to the Bunny Ears Cactus. You only really need to prune off unhealthy pads when you notice them turning brown or drying out. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_9_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are the new pads on my Bunny Ears Cactus red?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">You may be a little concerned that the new pads growing on your Bunny Ears Cactus are red, whilst the rest of the plant is solid green. Good news, this is totally normal and nothing to worry about. The new leaves will turn green as they mature. It’s just a little quirk of the Bunny Ears Cactus!  </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_4_plant_common_issues_single_faq]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f67396379d03]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[What’s causing my Bunny Ears Cactus to fall over?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your Bunny Ears Cactus is becoming unstable and parts or all of the plant is falling over then this is a sign that the roots are weakening. This is most commonly caused by overwatering which has meant the roots are rotting and are unable to keep the plant stable. Whilst wearing gloves, remove your Bunny Ears Cactus from its pot and inspect the root system. Replace any soggy soil and trim away the rotten roots. Use a plant support to help your Bunny Ears Cactus stay upright and with some time the root system should start to regrow and support your plant. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_related_posts]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_60268bb69353e]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4056]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;If you’re looking for a low-maintenance houseplant that still gives the wow-factor, then look no further than the Bunny Ears Cactus. Loved for their flat pad-like leaves, and lack of long sharp spikes (they have fuzzy glochids instead which are still a little painful to touch), they are great for beginner plant parents! \n\nNative to the Mexican desert plains, the Bunny Ears Cactus will thrive if you replicate the native conditions. They don’t need much water and will thrive in bright direct sunshine. This makes them the perfect plant for those sunny windowsills that are too bright for a lot of other houseplants.\n\nThese slow-growing houseplants can reach up to around half a metre but will grow to double that if given the right conditions outside. They do take a while to grow but are definitely worth the wait. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">If you’re looking for a low-maintenance houseplant that still gives the wow-factor, then look no further than the Bunny Ears Cactus. Loved for their flat pad-like leaves, and lack of long sharp spikes (they have fuzzy glochids instead which are still a little painful to touch), they are great for beginner plant parents!</span>

Native to the Mexican desert plains, the Bunny Ears Cactus will thrive if you replicate the native conditions. They don’t need much water and will thrive in bright direct sunshine. This makes them the perfect plant for those sunny windowsills that are too bright for a lot of other houseplants.

These slow-growing houseplants can reach up to around half a metre but will grow to double that if given the right conditions outside. They do take a while to grow but are definitely worth the wait.]]></wp:meta_value>

Luckily there aren't too many common problems that occur when caring for a Worm Plant. However, it is good to know the warning signs so you can keep an eye out for when something might not be quite right.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They thrive in bright indirect light</h3>
Worm Plants, like many other succulent types, love sunshine but can be scorched by the sun if sat in a lot of direct light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Water your Worm Plant sparingly</h3>
Make sure that your Worm Plant doesn't sit in too much water as this can very quickly lead to root rot. Before watering, check that the top few centimetres of the soil is completely dry. In winter, watering once a month or so should suffice.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They aren't fussy about temperature</h3>
One great thing about Worm Plants is that they survive well in the natural temperature of your home, in both summer and winter. They aren't super sensitive to the cold so don't worry about your plant not making it through the colder seasons.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only use fertiliser in the growth period</h3>
It is important that if you do fertilise your Worm Plant, that you only do so in spring and summer. We recommend using a specific fertiliser designed for succulents.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They don't mind being root-bound</h3>
One thing you don't need to worry about when caring for a Worm Plant is repotting. They don't mind their roots being a little crowded so can happily grow in the same pot for a few years. When you do repot, handle the roots and plant gently to avoid damage.]]></wp:meta_value>

Be slightly careful about where you place your Worm Plants if you have a pet because they can be a little toxic if digested.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[When caring for a Worm Plant, one thing you don't need to worry about is trying to increase humidity levels. If anything, they thrive better in dry air so keep them away from bathrooms and kitchens where the natural humidity level is higher.]]></wp:meta_value>

They don't mind their roots being a little crowded so can happily grow in the same pot for a few years. When you do repot, handle the roots and plant gently to avoid damage.]]></wp:meta_value>

Worm Plants are actually one of the easiest succulents to propagate and you will have great success doing it. Place the cuttings in slightly moist soil in a bright spot. Avoid placing them in direct light as this will scorch the entire cutting.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Fan Palms</h2>
Although these are hardy plants that are perfect for first-time houseplant parents, this doesn't mean you won't encounter some problems along the way.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fan Palms love direct sunlight</h3>
Although they can also grow in shadier areas of your home, Fan Palms prefer bright light. They can tolerate direct light too unlike many houseplants so you really don't need to worry about too much sunlight.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They need regular watering</h3>
You need to let the soil dry out between waterings, but Fan Palms usually need to be watered once a week in summer and less frequently in colder months.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Don't worry about temperature or humidity</h3>
The reason Fan Palms are so easy to care for is that they will be okay with the natural temperature and humidity levels in your home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Regular fertilisation will encourage growth</h3>
You can fertilise your Fan Palm throughout the year, using a palm-specific fertiliser. Keep the fertiliser weaker than the recommended amount to prevent damaging the root system.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Repot every few years</h3>
Don't worry too much about repotting your Fan Palm as they are relatively slow growers. Every 2 or 3 years should be enough to prevent them from becoming too root-bound.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate a Fan Palm by division</h3>
You can propagate your Fan Palm by splitting up the mother plant into several palms. Make sure that each individual plant has a strong part of the root system attached and repot them into separate containers.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fan Palms are completely safe for pets and children</h3>
One great thing about Fan Palms is that they are non-toxic so you don't need to worry about your cats, dogs or children going near it.

&nbsp;]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are my Fan Palm's leaves drooping?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Drooping leaves and stems on a Fan Palm is an indication that it is not getting enough water. Check the moisture levels in the soil and adjust your watering schedule accordingly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there brown tips on my Fan Palm's leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dry brown tips on a Fan Palm's leaves is a very common issue. It may be caused by underwatering or very dry air. We recommend checking the moisture in the soil to see if it needs more water and misting the leaves every few days.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Perfect for novice plant parents, the Fan Palm is a great way to bring some of the tropics right to your home. It’s one of the few palms that can actually truly thrive in non-tropical conditions so you don’t need to worry too much about having the perfect environment for it. Bright sunshine and moderate watering will keep this one happy and healthy. \n\nOutdoors the Fan Palm can reach several meters tall, but when grown indoors in a pot, it’ll grow very slowly and won’t reach anything near that don’t worry! Although the plant is non-toxic, we still recommend keeping it away from your furry friends as the leaf tips are very sharp. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Perfect for novice plant parents, the Fan Palm is a great way to bring some of the tropics right to your home. It’s one of the few palms that can actually truly thrive in non-tropical conditions so you don’t need to worry too much about having the perfect environment for it. Bright sunshine and moderate watering will keep this one happy and healthy.

Outdoors the Fan Palm can reach several meters tall, but when grown indoors in a pot, it’ll grow very slowly and won’t reach anything near that don’t worry! Although the plant is non-toxic, we still recommend keeping it away from your furry friends as the leaf tips are very sharp.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Polka Dot Begonia</h2>
Even though the Polka Dot Begonia is quite an easy houseplant to care for, there are a few issues that can easily occur. It is important to act as soon as you suspect a problem to give your plant the best chance of survival.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They thrive in bright indirect light</h3>
Polka Dot Begonia love the sunshine but be careful to expose them to direct sunlight as this can really damage the leaves and permanently scorch them.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the soil moist, not soggy</h3>
You want to be watering your Polka Dot Begonia once a week during the growing months. Make sure the soil is dry before you water as too much moisture can cause root rot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They like slightly higher humidity levels</h3>
Polka Dot Begonia don't like the air to be really dry. However, we tend to avoid misting as too much moisture directly on their leaves can be damaging. Instead, you can use a pebble tray or place it in naturally humid rooms. Visit our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">houseplant humidity guide</a> to find out more.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Room temperature is fine</h3>
One great thing about Polka Dot Begonia plants is that they will happily thrive in the natural temperature in your home. Keep them away from drafty windows, especially in winter, as this can cause shock if it is exposed to a lot of cold air.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Polka Dot Begonia grow pretty fast!</h3>
If in the right environment and given the right care, these plants can grow up to 2m indoors. If you want your plant to continue growing, repot every year or so or when you notice the roots are coming 0ut of the pot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertilise in spring to encourage growth</h3>
We recommend feeding your Polka Dot Begonia every month in the warmer growth months. A general houseplant fertiliser should work just fine!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Polka Dot Begonia are toxic to pets and humans</h3>
You want to keep your Polka Dot Begonia away from pets and small children as they are toxic. Although it won't cause serious long-term damage, ingestion can cause stomach irritation.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Pruning can create a fuller-looking plant</h3>
If you want your Polka Dot Begonia to look a little bushier and less leggy, you can prune it back to encourage new growth. You can also prune it back in winter to help it restore energy.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_7_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Polka Dot Begonia from a stem cutting</h3>
It is pretty simple to propagate your Polka Dot Begonia as you can simply snip off a leaf (making sure there is a stem node attached). Place the cutting in water and after a few weeks, roots should begin to show meaning you can repot your cutting into fresh soil.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that the leaves and stems on your Polka Dot Begonia are drooping down, this is an indication that your plant needs more water. Check the moisture in the soil and adjust your watering schedule accordingly. The most reliable way to check the moisture levels in the soil is by using a<a href="/a/moisture-monitor"> moisture meter. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[This is called powdery mildew and can be a result of misting the leaves of your Polka Dot Begonia too much. You want to ensure that there is no moisture on your plant's leaves (especially overnight) as this is what is causing a build up of mildew.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Polka Dot Begonia have yellow leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Yellow leaves on a Polka Dot Begonia indicates your plant has received too much water. Replace the soil if it is waterlogged with<a href="/a/houseplant-soil"> fresh houseplant mix</a> and hold off watering as much as you were before.

You also want to make sure that there is good drainage in the pot, so check your pot has drainage holes as otherwise all that moisture is being retained. You can also add <a href="/a/perlite">perlite</a> to the potting mix to aid drainage and aeration.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown edges on a Polka Dot Begonia's leaves indicates too much sunlight. Make sure your Polka Dot plant is away from direct sunlight as this can very easily scorch and burn the leaves. Pick up a<a href="/a/light-monitor"> light meter</a> if you aren't sure exactly where to place your plant - we love them as they help you monitor the light levels across the day.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice quite a few leaves dropping from your Polka Dot Begonia this indicates too much water or temperature shock. Check the moisture in the soil and move your plant away from any drafty doors or windows. Using <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meters</a> and <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometers</a> can help you assess your care and environment to make sure it's right for your Polka Dot Begonia.]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown leaf tips on a Polka Dot Begonia are often caused by underwatering. Try increasing the frequency of watering a little but keep an eye on the soil moisture to avoid any root rot occurring.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_5_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
