		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They thrive in bright indirect light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Polka Dot Begonia plants love the sunshine but be careful not to expose them to direct sunlight as this can really damage the leaves and permanently scorch them. A great way to make sure your Polka Dot Begonia is getting the right amount of light is by picking up a light meter. They are super affordable and <a href="/a/light-monitor">available on Amazon here. </a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Keep the soil moist, not soggy]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[You want to be watering your Polka Dot Begonia once a week during the growing months. Make sure the soil is dry before you water as too much moisture can cause root rot. We always prefer to use a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to determine if our Polka Dot Begonia needs watering as root rot is something you really want to avoid.

Another way you can help avoid root rot is to use<a href="/a/terracotta-pots"> terracotta pots.</a> Plastic pots hold in every drop of moisture, where as terracotta or clay pots allow some of the water to evaporate through the sides. We love <a href="/a/terracotta-pots">these ones from Amazon.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Polka Dot Begonias like slightly higher humidity levels]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Polka Dot Begonia don't like the air to be really dry. However, we tend to avoid misting as too much moisture directly on their leaves can be damaging. Instead, you can use a pebble tray, <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier</a> or place it in naturally humid rooms. Visit our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">houseplant humidity guide</a> to find out more.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One great thing about Polka Dot Begonia plants is that they will happily thrive in the natural temperature in your home. Keep them away from drafty windows, especially in winter, as this can cause shock if it is exposed to a lot of cold air. Use a <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometer</a> to check that your plant isn't in a really cold or hot spot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If in the right environment and given the right care, Polka Dot Begonia plants can grow up to 2m indoors. If you want your plant to continue growing, repot every year or so or when you notice the roots are coming out of the pot.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate your Polka Dot Begonia from a stem cutting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_8_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is pretty simple to propagate your Polka Dot Begonia as you can simply snip off a leaf using your <a href="/a/pruning-scissors">shears</a> (making sure there is a stem node attached). Place the cutting in water and after a few weeks, roots should begin to show meaning you can repot your cutting into <a href="/a/houseplant-soil">fresh soil.</a>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;With their unique angel-shaped dotted leaves, the Polka Dot Begonia is a fairly easy plant to care for once you know what to do with them. Bright, indirect light and consistent watering (making sure not to let it dry out) will keep your Polka Dot Begonia happy. When all of their needs are met, they can grow quite quickly and will likely need repotting every year. \n\nIt’s worth noting that they do like slightly higher humidity levels, but this shouldn’t be maintained by misting as water collecting on the leaves can cause damage. Instead we’d recommend placing them somewhere naturally humid, or using a humidifier/pebble tray to supplement.&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">With their unique angel-shaped dotted leaves, the Polka Dot Begonia is a fairly easy plant to care for once you know what to do with them. Bright, indirect light and consistent watering (making sure not to let it dry out) will keep your Polka Dot Begonia happy. When all of their needs are met, they can grow quite quickly and will likely need repotting every year.

It’s worth noting that they do like slightly higher humidity levels, but this shouldn’t be maintained by misting as water collecting on the leaves can cause damage. Instead, we’d recommend placing them somewhere naturally humid or using a humidifier/pebble tray to supplement.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Maidenhair Ferns are best suited to experienced plant parents as they can be quite fussy about their care and environment. Below is our complete Maidenhair Fern care guide with all the information you need to raise a happy and healthy fern!</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Issues for Maidenhair Ferns</h2>
Even the most experienced plant owners sometimes struggle with Maidenhair Ferns so it is important that you familiarise yourself with the warning signs so you can diagnose the problem as quickly as possible.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Maidenhair Ferns need a shady spot</h3>
The number 1 thing to know when caring for a Maidenhair Fern is that they don't survive well in sunny areas. Avoid any direct light as this will immediately scorch the leaves.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They love moist soil</h3>
It is important that your Maidenhair Fern's soil stays moist, but not waterlogged. We recommend ensuring good drainage in the pot so that the excess water can flow out. Water little and often to avoid the soil drying too much.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>High humidity is a necessity</h3>
Maidenhair Ferns can be quite difficult to care for because they require constant attention to make sure the humidity levels are up. The easiest way to do this is by misting your Maidenhair Fern daily or by using a pebble tray underneath the fern.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Maidenhair Ferns need warmer temperatures</h3>
They will not survive so well in cooler rooms so make sure they are not near any drafty windows or doors. Anything below average room temperature will be too cold for your Maidenhair Fern.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertilising is optional</h3>
If you do choose to fertilise your Maidenhair Fern, make sure you use a weak soluble fertiliser. Also only feed during the growth months or spring and summer.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Maidenhair Ferns are safe for pets</h3>
Although we never recommend allowing your pet to nibble on your houseplants, Maidenhair Ferns are safe for pets so you don't need to worry too much about placing them out of reach.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Maidenhair Fern using division</h3>
If you want to propagate your Maidenhair Fern, we recommend diving the mother fern in two or three parts. Make sure that each fern has a good percentage of the overall root system to ensure survival and growth.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common problems for Tree Philodendron</h2>
Luckily Tree Philodendrons are fairly easy to take care of and watering issues are the only real point of concern. It is good to keep an eye on the leaves to see if there are any yellow or brown patches developing.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They require bright, indirect light</h3>
Tree Philodendrons thrive best in areas with bright light. However, keep it out of direct sunlight as this can easily damage the leaves. They are able to survive in medium light but will nor grow as quickly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They don't like to be sat in water</h3>
Whilst it is important that you keep the soil of your Tree Philodendron relatively moist, get rid of any excess water that runs through so your plant is not sat in too much water. Overwatering can cause root rot which leads to a whole heap of issues for your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They like humid environments</h3>
Tree Philodendron are native to tropical areas so thrive best in warm humid environments. Check out our detailed guide on <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">increasing humidity for your houseplants </a>for top tips on how to do this. The easiest way is by misting your plant every few days.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Be careful of over-fertilising</h3>
If you do choose to fertilise your Tree Philodendron, we recommend using a soluble fertiliser at half strength in spring and summer. Too much fertiliser can cause irreversible leaf burn.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Tree Philodendrons need warmer temperatures</h3>
As they are native to tropical areas, Tree Philodendrons grow best in slightly warmer temperatures. Keep them away from drafty doors and windows as the cold air will over time damage your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Tree Philodendron are toxic to pets</h3>
If you have a pet that is prone to nibbling on your beloved plants, then maybe this one isn't for you. Ingestion of the leaves can cause stomach irritation and contact with the sap can cause skin irritation on humans.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Tree Philodendron by stem cutting</h3>
As your Tree Philodendron begins to grow, you may want to propagate it so it becomes a more manageable size. The best way to do this is by taking a stem cutting with at least one node and growing it in water for a few weeks. Once roots have started to grow out of the node you can pot into fresh soil.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dry brown leaf tips or patches on the leaves is a sign of underwatering. Check how dry the soil is and increase how often you water. 		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Calathea Triostar Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Part of the Prayer Plant family, Calathea Triostar are known for their incredible colourful leaves with pink undersides. Below you will find our detailed Calathea Triostar Care Guide with all the information you need to help your plant thrive.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They love bright, indirect light</h3>
Calathea Triostar love sunshine but can get damaged easily if they are exposed to any direct light. We recommend finding a spot with amble indirect light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the soil slightly damp</h3>
But remember there is a big different between moist and waterlogged soil. If your Calathea Triostar sits in water for too long, the roots will begin to rot. Always check the top few inches of the soil before watering.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Calathea Triostar Issues</h2>
Calathea Triostar plants can be a little tricky to care for and may start to show signs of unhappiness such as yellow leaves or brown leaf tips. Below you will find our recommendations for treating these issues.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Calathea Triostars need a humid environment</h3>
One of the most important things about caring for a Calathea Triostar is keeping the humidity levels up. A great way to do this is misting the plant every few days (or more if you can) or using a pebble tray. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your plant in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Calathea Triostar hate cold temperatures</h3>
We recommend finding a nice warm spot for your Calathea Triostar as they prefer slightly warmer temperatures. Be careful not to place your plant near AC vents or any drafty windows or doors as the cold air can cause long-term shock.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertilise your Calathea Triostar in the growth period</h3>
We recommend feeding your Calathea Triostar once a month in spring and summer when it is producing new leaves. Always dilute the fertiliser to half the recommended strength]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Calathea Triostar plants are non-toxic</h3>
One great thing about the Calathea Triostar is that they are non-toxic for both pets and humans, so you don't need to worry about moving them out of reach.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Calathea Triostar through division</h3>
Spring is the best time to propagate your Calathea Triostar as the growth period gives it the best chance of success. You should propagate by diving the mother plant and placing in fresh soil. Make sure that each new plant has a good chunk of the root system.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Calathea Triostar have yellow leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice that your Calathea Triostar is starting to develop yellow leaves, it is usually caused by overwatering. Check the moisture in the soil and replace if necessary. In future, we recommend using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> to ensure you only water your Calathea when needed. You can also use <a href="/a/terracotta-pots">terracotta pots</a> rather than plastic ones which allow some of the water to escape out of the sides.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why has my Calathea Triostar developed pale leaves? ]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Pale leaves on a Calathea Triostar are a sign that there is too much moisture in the soil. Adjust your watering schedule and make sure there are drainage holes in the pot (and that they are not blocked by anything).]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there brown edges on my Calathea Triostar's leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Dry, cirpsy brown edges on the leaves of your Calathea Triostar is a signal that either it needs to be watered more often, or that the humidity levels are too low. The easiest way to increase the humidity level is by using a <a href="/a/premium-humidifier">humidifier</a>. You can find out more about how to increase the humidity for your houseplants in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why is my Calathea Triostar wrinkly and looking withered?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Wrinkly, withered leaves on a Calathea Triostar are a sign that the air in the room is too dry. Try to mist your plant regularly using a <a href="/a/spray-bottles">spray bottle</a> or move it to the kitchen or bathroom where humidity levels are naturally higher. We also recommend every plant parent use a <a href="/a/humidifier">humidifier</a> to keep a nice constant humidity level in your home.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They love bright, indirect light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Calathea Triostar love sunshine but can get damaged easily if they are exposed to any direct light. We recommend finding a spot with plenty of indirect light. You may want to adjust where you place your plant depending on the seasons and the sun strength. Using a <a href="/a/light-monitor">light monitor</a> is a great way to determine if your plant's getting enough light.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Keep the soil slightly damp]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Remember there is a big different between moist and waterlogged soil. If your Calathea Triostar sits in water for too long, the roots will begin to rot and the plant will quickly become limp and mushy. Always check the top few inches of the soil before watering. Using a <a href="/a/moisture-monitor">moisture meter</a> helps to figure out how much moisture is in the soil so you don't under or overwater.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Calathea Triostars need a humid environment]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One of the most important things about caring for a Calathea Triostar is keeping the humidity levels up. A great way to do this is misting the plant using a spray bottle every few days (or more if you can) or using a <a href="/a/humidifier">humidifier</a> to keep a consistent level. You can find out more about raising the humidity for your plant in our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">guide</a>.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Calathea Triostar hate cold temperatures]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend finding a nice warm spot for your Calathea Triostar as they prefer slightly warmer temperatures. Be careful not to place your plant near AC vents or any drafty windows or doors as the cold air can cause long-term shock. We always check the spot our plants are in using a <a href="/a/humidity-monitor">digital thermometer</a>. They will help avoid drafts or hotspots.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Fertilise your Calathea Triostar in the growth period]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We recommend feeding your Calathea Triostar once a month in spring and summer when it is producing new leaves. Our plants love the<a href="/a/fertiliser-bottle"> liquid fertiliser from Miracle Gro.</a> Always dilute the fertiliser to half the recommended strength.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Calathea Triostar plants are non-toxic]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One great thing about the Calathea Triostar is that they are non-toxic for both pets and humans, so you don't need to worry about moving them out of reach.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate your Calathea Triostar through division]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Spring is the best time to propagate your Calathea Triostar as the growth period gives it the best chance of success. You should propagate by diving the mother plant and placing in fresh soil. Make sure that each new plant has a good chunk of the root system.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Part of the Prayer Plant family, Calathea Triostar plants are loved for their incredible white, green and pink leaves. Their vibrant pink leaf undersides really make this plant stand out in a crowd. \n\nAs much as we love the Calathea Triostar, they are a little fussy so be prepared for a bit of a challenge to keep this one alive and happy. They hate direct sunlight as it can very quikcly burn and scorch the leaves. It’s also important that you keep a good level of moisture in the soil, not too much and not too little. \nThe best thing about Calathea Triostars is how quickly they do grow once you get the environment and care just right. Before you know it, there will be new leaves and stems popping up everywhere which makes it a great plant to propagate! \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Part of the Prayer Plant family, Calathea Triostar plants are loved for their incredible white, green and pink leaves. Their vibrant pink leaf undersides really make this plant stand out in a crowd.</span>

As much as we love the Calathea Triostar, they are a little fussy so be prepared for a bit of a challenge to keep this one alive and happy. They hate direct sunlight as it can very quickly burn and scorch the leaves. It’s also important that you keep a good level of moisture in the soil, not too much and not too little. The best thing about Calathea Triostars is how quickly they do grow once you get the environment and care just right. Before you know it, there will be new leaves and stems popping up everywhere which makes it a great plant to propagate!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Common Issues for Asparagus Ferns</h2>
Although Asparagus Fern care can be quite easy, there are several common issues that happen if your plant isn’t fully happy with its care or environment. It is important to spot the warning signs so you know how to help nurture your plant back to full health.]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Ideal Light Conditions</h3>
Asparagus Ferns are happy in most lighting conditions, which is great news. It's best if you keep them out of direct sunlight though as they can be prone to burning.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Watering Correctly</h3>
Asparagus Ferns prefer a little and often way of watering, this keeps the soil moist but never wet and soggy. They can be prone to root rot so it’s important that you get the drainage right.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Asparagus Ferns Love Humidity</h3>
Being from the forest, Asparagus Ferns are happiest when there's a little higher humidity. Be sure to give yours a mist every few days, or consider a pebble tray to keep things more consistent.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Asparagus Ferns are poisonous to pets</h3>
Watch out if you have have a cat or dog around! Pets that ingest the leaves can develop digestive issues and struggle with breathing, so give this one a miss if you have a pet in the house.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

Avoid placing them next to drafty windows and doors as the cool air from outside can be quite harmful over time.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The easiest way to propagate your Asparagus Fern is by dividing the plant. Make sure that you equally divide up the root system so that each plant has the best survival chance. We also recommend propagating your Asparagus Fern in spring ahead of the warmer growth months.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;The Asparagus Fern is such an elegant little houseplant – and although they look like they’ll be hard work to keep happy, they’re actually pretty simple to care for. Given the right conditions, they can grow extremely quickly and you’ll find new stems popping up every week.\n\nThey aren’t too fussy on light conditions or watering schedules, but humidity is a must for them. Make sure to give them a spray with a mist bottle every 3-5 days or place near a humidifier to keep them happy in the long term. The leaves and stems will yellow if they aren’t happy, if that happens to you then just give your Asparagus Fern another spray down and a little extra water. &quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">The Asparagus Fern is such an elegant little houseplant – and although they look like they’ll be hard work to keep happy, they’re actually pretty simple to care for. Given the right conditions, they can grow extremely quickly and you’ll find new stems popping up every week.

They aren’t too fussy on light conditions or watering schedules, but humidity is a must for them. Make sure to give them a spray with a mist bottle every 3-5 days or place near a humidifier to keep them happy in the long term. The leaves and stems will yellow if they aren’t happy, if that happens to you then just give your Asparagus Fern another spray down and a little extra water. </span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Mistletoe Cactus Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Although you might think they like dry, desert-like environments, Mistletoe Cacti are actually jungle cacti meaning they require warmth and high humidity to thrive. Below you will find all the information you need to properly care for your Mistletoe Cactus.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They love the sunshine</h3>
We recommend placing your Mistletoe Cactus in an area where it gets bright but filtered and direct light. A few hours of direct morning light wouldn't harm your plant but steer clear if exposing it]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Keep the soil moist but not soggy</h3>
There is a bit of a balance to be struck in terms of watering your Mistletoe Cactus. They don't like to fully dry out like other plants in the Cacti family but don't like to be swimming in water either.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Average room temperature is fine</h3>
Although they prefer warmer temps, one great thing about the Mistletoe Cactus is that it will survive well in the average room temperature. They don't like it if it gets too cold at night (below about 10-15 degrees C) so be wary of placing it in a cold room.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>High humidity is a must-have</h3>
One of the most important things to note when taking care of a Mistletoe Cactus is that it loves high humidity levels. They thrive in bathrooms and kitchens where the humidity is naturally higher. Alternatively, check out our guide to <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">increasing the humidity for your houseplants</a> for more tips.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertiliser isn't always a necessity</h3>
It is up to you whether or not you want to feed your Mistletoe Cactus. They will thrive without it but it can sometimes help to feed in Springtime to accelerate growth. Use a cactus specific fertiliser as this suits its needs better than regular feed.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They are completely safe for pets</h3>
Another great thing about the Mistletoe Cactus is that it is completely safe for dogs, cats and children so you don't need to worry about putting it out of reach.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Problems for a Mistletoe Cactus</h2>
Although they can be quite a low-maintenance plant if in the right environment and given the right care, there are some common issues that may pop up which indicate your plant is unhappy. Most of the issues are caused by overwatering so we recommend regularly checking the soil's moisture.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Mistletoe Cactus with stem cuttings</h3>
It really couldn't be easier to propagate your Mistletoe Cactus as all you need to do is take a cutting of the plant, let the end callous out of water and soil for a few days before placing in a cactus soil mix. Before you know it you will have a fresh new plant!]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Wilting Mistletoe Cactus stems are often a sign you are overwatering and the roots are starting to rot. Remove the damaged stems and replace the soil.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice black and mushy stems on your Mistletoe Cactus, you have probably overwatered your plant. We recommend replacing the soil if it is still soggy and trimming off the black mushy stems.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If your Mistletoe Cactus is losing stems, this is a sign of overwatering. Although they like to have moist soil, Mistletoe Cactus don't like to be sitting in too much water. Replace the soil and cut back on your watering.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why are there white masses on my Mistletoe Cactus?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_3_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice white cotton-like masses on your Mistletoe Cactus it unfortunately means it is infected with mealybugs. This can be treated using a neem or insecticide product. Keep your infected Mistletoe Cactus away from other plants to prevent the infestation from spreading.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Red stems on a Mistletoe Cactus are an indicator that the plant is receiving too much direct sunlight. Remove the damaged stems and place in a slightly shadier spot. Ideally somewhere with still bright, but indirect light.]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Although they prefer warmer temperatures, one great thing about the Mistletoe Cactus is that it will survive well in the average room temperature. They don't like it if it gets too cold at night (below about 10-15 degrees C) so be wary of placing it in a cold room.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[High humidity is vital when caring for a Mistletoe Cactus]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[One of the most important things to note when taking care of a Mistletoe Cactus is that it loves high humidity levels. They thrive in bathrooms and kitchens where the humidity is naturally higher. Alternatively, check out our guide to <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">increasing the humidity for your houseplants</a> for more tips.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[It is up to you whether or not you want to feed your Mistletoe Cactus. They will thrive without it but it can sometimes help to feed in Springtime to accelerate growth. Use a cactus specific fertiliser as this suits its needs better than regular feed.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Satin Pothos Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">Known for their unique silver speckles leaves, the Satin Pothos is the perfect plant for every houseplant parent at they are easy to care for! Below you will find all the information you need to properly care for your Satin Pothos.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Problems for Satin Pothos</h2>
Even this easy-to-care-for trailing plant may cause you some headaches if given improper care or the wrong environment. It is important to diagnose the problem early to give your plant the best chance of bouncing back.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5ffa84bd5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Satin Pothos like bright, indirect light</h3>
Make sure you keep your Satin Pothos out of direct sunlight as this can scorch the leaves. They will grow in low light areas of your home, but their leaves will become less variegated, so it is about finding the balance.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They like to be moist, not soggy</h3>
An important thing to note about Satin Pothos plants is that they do like moisture in the soil, but don't like it to be sat in it! Make sure the top few inches of the soil are dry before watering again. They are also tolerant of some underwatering, so don't be too alarmed if you forget about it once in a while.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Medium humidity levels are best</h3>
If you find you have quite a dry home, you may want to increase the humidity around your Satin Pothos a little to help prevent dry leaf tips. Check out our guide to humidity <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">here</a> for more information. Kitchens or bathrooms with enough light are great as they naturally have slightly higher humidity levels.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Avoid placing your Satin Pothos in cold rooms</h3>
Satin Pothos plants do best in rooms with slightly warmer temperatures, but average room temperature will also be fine. The most important thing is to avoid placing your Satin Pothos next to drafty windows or doors as the cold air will cause damage to your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Only fertilise your Satin Pothos in summer</h3>
As with many other houseplants, we recommend only fertilising in the growth period of spring and summer. A general houseplant fertiliser at half strength once a month should be plenty!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Satin Pothos are slightly toxic to pets and humans</h3>
We would recommend putting your Satin Pothos slightly higher on the shelves as they are mildly toxic to dogs, cats and humans. If ingested it can cause mild mouth and stomach irritation.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Satin Pothos by taking a stem cutting</h3>
When propagating your Satin Pothos plant, it is important that you take a stem cutting that has a node or two in it as this is where the new roots will form. We recommend placing your cutting in water for several weeks until a small root system has grown. Then plant your cutting in soil and resume general Satin Pothos care.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Satin Pothos have yellow leaves?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If your Satin Pothos has developed yellowing leaves, this can be a sign of two things. Either you have been overwatering it and the soil has become waterlogged, or it requires more sunlight. The best way to know is by checking the moisture levels in the soil.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If your Satin Pothos looks quite sad and the leaves are drooping down, it may be because it is being consistently underwatered. Check how dry the potting soil is and increase the frequency of your watering if needed.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Satin Pothos have brown leaf tips?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Brown leaf tips are a sign that your Satin Pothos is in a room with quite dry air. Check out our guide to <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">increasing humidity for your houseplants</a> for more information on how to change this.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_2_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Satin Pothos like bright, indirect light]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Make sure you keep your Satin Pothos out of direct sunlight as this can scorch the leaves. They will grow in low light areas of your home, but their leaves will become less variegated, so it is about finding the balance.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[They like to be moist, not soggy]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[An important thing to note when caring for a Satin Pothos is that they do like moisture in the soil, but don't like it to be sat in it! Make sure the top few inches of the soil are dry before watering again. They are also tolerant of some underwatering, so don't be too alarmed if you forget about it once in a while.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Medium humidity levels are best for your Satin Pothos]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you find you have quite a dry home, you may want to increase the humidity around your Satin Pothos a little to help prevent dry leaf tips. Check out our <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/humidity-guide/">guide to humidity</a> for more information. Kitchens or bathrooms with enough light are great as they naturally have slightly higher humidity levels.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Avoid placing your Satin Pothos in cold rooms]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Satin Pothos plants do best in rooms with slightly warmer temperatures, but average room temperature will also be fine. The most important thing is to avoid placing your Satin Pothos next to drafty windows or doors as the cold air will cause damage to your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Only fertilise your Satin Pothos in summer]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[As with many other houseplants, we recommend only fertilising in the growth period of spring and summer. A general houseplant fertiliser at half strength once a month should be plenty!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Satin Pothos are slightly toxic to pets and humans]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[We would recommend putting your Satin Pothos slightly higher on the shelves as they are mildly toxic to dogs, cats and humans. If ingested it can cause mild mouth and stomach irritation.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254ea6bf13]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Propagate your Satin Pothos by taking a stem cutting]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5f5254d96bf12]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[When propagating your Satin Pothos plant, it is important that you take a stem cutting that has a node or two in it as this is where the new roots will form. We recommend placing your cutting in water for several weeks until a small root system has grown. Then plant your cutting in soil and resume general Satin Pothos care.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4006]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_image]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_611bdbc97b94f]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;Known for their unique silver speckled leaves, the Satin Pothos is the perfect houseplant for every plant parent as they are super simple to care for. They can grow quite quickly in the right conditions and are very easy to propagate, so cuttings and young plants can make great gifts. \n\nBright, indirect light and a consistent watering schedule will keep them happy and thriving. Avoiding colder rooms or areas with dryer air will really help in making sure your Satin Pothos will stay healthy all year round. \n\nOriginating from southeast Asia these plants will also appreciate a little extra humidity, so spraying them with a mist bottle every now and then will keep them closer to their natural environment.&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">Known for their unique silver speckled leaves, the Satin Pothos is the perfect houseplant for every plant parent as they are super simple to care for. They can grow quite quickly in the right conditions and are very easy to propagate, so cuttings and young plants can make great gifts.

Bright, indirect light and a consistent watering schedule will keep them happy and thriving. Avoiding colder rooms or areas with dryer air will really help in making sure your Satin Pothos will stay healthy all year round.

Originating from southeast Asia these plants will also appreciate a little extra humidity, so spraying them with a mist bottle every now and then will keep them closer to their natural environment.</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common Problems for Yucca</h2>
Even though they are quite low maintenance, there are a few issues that your Yucca might suffer from. It's important to know the warning signs so you can deal with the issue as soon as it arises. This will give your plant the best shot at returning to full health.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Yucca can grow in all light conditions</h3>
One of the best things about a Yucca plant is that it can cope in bright sunlight and dark corners. Be aware though that if growth will be slower in a darker spot.]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Good drainage is key</h3>
The one thing a Yucca really doesn't like is being waterlogged. Make sure that your pot has good drainage holes and you remove any excess water that flows out. Water much less in winter, about once every 3-4 weeks.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Yucca don't mind temperature extremes</h3>
As they are native to the desert, Yucca are used to dealing with extreme daytime heat and cool nights. So don't worry too much about finding the ideal room temperature.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

If you do want to feed your Yucca we highly recommend you only do this in the growth months. Use a soluble liquid fertiliser at half the recommended strength.]]></wp:meta_value>

The easiest way to propagate your Yucca is by replanting offshoots. You can keep the offshoots in water for a few weeks for roots to develop or directly pot them in soil. We recommend doing this in spring to give it the best chance of success.]]></wp:meta_value>

							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_nugget_content]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<span data-sheets-value="{&quot;1&quot;:2,&quot;2&quot;:&quot;A staple of many homes, the Yucca is one of the most popular houseplants and you’ll often see them around offices, shops and restaurants too! They’re super easy to care for so are perfect for all plant parents. They were very popular in the ’70s so are a great way to get a little bit of vintage style in your home. \n\nAs they mature, Yucca plants can grow about 2 metres in height so make it the perfect feature plant for your space. They are very slow-growing though so if you don’t have as much space, a smaller plant won’t outgrow the room very quickly.\n\nThey are very low maintenance and can adapt to most light levels, temperature and humidity levels but unfortunately, they are toxic to keep that in mind if you have pets or small children. \n&quot;}" data-sheets-userformat="{&quot;2&quot;:769,&quot;3&quot;:{&quot;1&quot;:0},&quot;11&quot;:4,&quot;12&quot;:0}">A staple of many homes, the Yucca is one of the most popular houseplants and you’ll often see them around offices, shops and restaurants too! They’re super easy to care for so are perfect for all plant parents. They were very popular in the ’70s so are a great way to get a little bit of vintage style in your home.

As they mature, Yucca plants can grow about 2 metres in height so make it the perfect feature plant for your space. They are very slow-growing though so if you don’t have as much space, a smaller plant won’t outgrow the room very quickly.

They are very low maintenance and can adapt to most light levels, temperature and humidity levels but unfortunately, they are toxic to keep that in mind if you have pets or small children.
</span>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2>Basic Philodendron Birkin Care</h2>
<p class="font-size-lg text-muted mb-7 mb-md-9">The once rare Philodendron Birkin is starting to pop up in plant shops across the world. They are easy to care for so are perfect for inexperienced plant parents. Below you will find all the information you need to properly care for your Philodendron Birkin.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">Common problems for Philodendron Birkin</h2>
These plants are fairly easy to care for and will be forgiving to some extent. However, there are still a few common issues that might arise over time that are good to watch out for.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_intro]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fe484bd4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_manual_related_plants]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f603084bd7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>They prefer bright, indirect light</h3>
As with many houseplants, Philodendron Birkin thrive best in bright spots with indirect light. Too much direct sunlight can damage the leaves, and low light areas can make it leggy and stunt growth.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_0_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Let it dry out between waterings</h3>
Philodendron Birkin like to have moist soil but will struggle if they are consistently overwatered. We recommend checking the soil moisture before watering to make sure it has dried sufficiently.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_1_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Philodendron Birkin love warm temperatures</h3>
As they are native to the tropics, Philodendron Birkin will struggle in colder temperatures. Make sure it is not near any drafty windows or doors as the colder air from outside will over time harm your plant.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_2_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>High humidity is a necessity</h3>
Philodendron Birkin require medium to high humidity levels to properly thrive. Don't worry if you have dry air in your home as we have a guide specifically on how to <a href="https://fiddleandthorn.com/how-to-increase-humidity-for-your-houseplants/">increase the humidity for your houseplants</a>!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_3_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Fertilise your Philodendron Birkin regularly</h3>
We recommend you fertilise your Philodendron Birkin once a fortnight in spring and summer. Use a soluble houseplant feed at half the recommended strength. Make sure it includes calcium and magnesium as this will encourage healthy growth.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_4_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Propagate your Philodendron Birkin using stem cuttings</h3>
You can easily propagate by taking a stem cutting. Place the cutting in water for a few weeks, replacing the water every other day. Once roots begin to develop you can pot your cutting in fresh soil. We recommend propagating in spring.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_5_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<h3>Philodendron Birkin are toxic to pets and children</h3>
Unfortunately, digestion of any part of your Philodendron Birkin plant can cause minor irritation in pets and children so try to keep them out of reach.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_detail_content_6_plant_detail_content_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f5fae84bd2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5e0f601784bd6]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Why does my Philodendron Birkin have dry leaf tips?]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_title]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed2594c1eda4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[If you notice brown dry leaf tips on your Philodendron Birkin, it is often an indication of underwatering. Check the moisture levels in the soil and adjust your watering accordingly.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_plant_common_issues_0_plant_common_issues_single_copy]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_5ed259591eda5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[plant_common_issues_1_plant_common_issues_single]]></wp:meta_key>
